DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF FORMER SENATOR THE HON. MALCOLM FOX SCOTT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 31 May 1989 of former Senator the Hon. Malcolm Fox Scott, a senator for Western Australia from 1950 to 1971.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 31 May 1989, of the Honourable Malcolm Fox Scott, a Senator for the State of Western Australia from 1950 to 1971, and a Minister of the Crown from 1968 to 1969, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to the members of his family in their bereavement.

Malcolm Scott was born in Western Australia in 1911. He was a Liberal senator for the State of Western Australia from 1950 to 1971 and Minister for Customs and Excise in the Gorton Government from 28 February 1968 to 12 November 1969. During his time in the Senate, Malcolm Scott served on various parliamentary committees including the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, the Senate Select Committee on Road Safety and the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. He also served on various delegations. He was Government Whip in the Senate from 8 March 1966 to 28 February 1968.

Prior to entering Federal Parliament Malcolm Scott was a farmer. Malcolm Scott was a hardworking and respected member of the Senate. I did not personally know him but I recall his period as Minister for Customs and as chairman of some committees. On behalf of the Government, I extend to his family our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I wish to support the motion which has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and to support his words about the late Malcolm Scott. Malcolm Scott was a farmer before he came to Parliament and a man who had wide interests. In that sense, I suppose, he was the 1950 to 1970 equivalent of Senator Panizza, in that he had extensive interests in mining and agriculture and brought the value of that experience into this place. He was for many years the Leader of the Senate team in Western Australia and, as the Leader of the Government has said, was ultimately a Minister in the Gorton Government, when he had the job of being Minister for Customs and Excise.

SPEECH.PARA: That was a period not without its difficulties for the then Senator Scott, because the issue of censorship was as sensitive then as it has been on subsequent occasions, and Senator Scott had his moments in the chamber in defending his own very firm views on the matter of censorship. But I suspect there will be many people in Australia who would wish, with the value of hindsight, that his view of censorship might have been given a little more credit in the intervening 20 or so years. Senator Scott was described by the Chief Censor, with whom my colleague Senator Durack had dealings, as the only Minister who ever gave clear directions which would guide the Censor. The clarity of his direction comes out in an interview which Senator Scott gave to the Sydney Morning Herald in 1969 during that period, when he made it clear that he wished to make sure that `filthy trash' was not imported into the country. He said:
I just don't believe in showing the sex act on the screen. I never have, and I'll stand by that. I'll stand by that.

That ceased, of course, to be a very fashionable view, but I think many people would wish in retrospect that Senator Scott's view had prevailed. When Senator Scott left the Senate he had a number of things to say which I think all of us wish we could say at the same point. Having been in the Senate for more than 20 years, he said:
In the time that I have been here it has been very heartening to see the growth that has taken place in Australia and the improvement of conditions for all people who live in this country.

For a politician to be able to say that at the end of his career is a splendid thing. In the more difficult days that Australia faces now, those senators who leave this place will not necessarily be able to say the same thing at the time of the next election. But Senator Scott, at the end of his 20 years, was able to say that, and I do not believe that anyone would doubt that that was true. He also said:
I go out of this chamber knowing that the Senate has improved tremendously since we became senators 20 years ago.

I think it is a point of some significance that the Senate in the late 1960s and early 1970s was going through a period of great renaissance, and all senators at that time, including Senator Scott, were entitled to take some pleasure from it. He thanked Senator Murphy, who was then the Leader of the Labor Party and the Leader of the Opposition in this place, for his comments at that time. I thought it would be interesting to see what Senator Murphy had to say of him. On the date of Senator Scott's retirement, he said:
. . . I and my colleagues, and I think the whole chamber, take him to be a man of unimpeachable integrity.

I think that is a very worthy comment to have made about a senator at the end of his career. I wish on behalf of the Opposition to say to the family of the late Malcolm Scott that we remember his contribution to this place with respect and affection and we extend our sympathy to them at this sad time of his death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HAINES
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I support Senator Button's condolence motion and extend my Party's sympathy to the family of the late Senator Scott. Indeed, I endorse Senator Chaney's comments a moment ago that something we should all strive for is to be able to say, as Senator Scott did at the end of his 20-year term, that the country had been improved and people were better off as a result of the changes made during our period in this place. Perhaps it is a little unfortunate that senators these days do not ever get the opportunity to look forward to a 20-year career in this place, politics having become somewhat more volatile. Nevertheless, I hope that all of us share that concern for the country that Senator Scott indicated that he did. We offer our sympathy and condolences to his family.

1. The Australian Taxation Office disregarded its privacy obligations to the citizens of Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory in February by sending an admitted 55,000 to 77,000 tax file number letters to people who were either deceased or had changed address.

2. The Australian Taxation Office disregarded its privacy obligations to the citizens of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory in March by sending an admitted 29,000 to 58,000 tax file number letters to people who were either deceased or had changed address.

PETITION.TITLE: Solar Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate a petition, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form, from 6,056 petitioners requesting that the Government urge South East Asian nations to grant asylum to Indo-Chinese refugees and not seek their repatriation and to respect the United Nations convention relating to the status of refugees, in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Although the Communist Government of Vietnam has recently proclaimed a policy of openness and although greater difficulties have been created for Vietnamese boat people after their arrival on the shores of neighbouring countries in South East Asia, the flow of Vietnamese refugees has shown no signs of abating.

At the Kuala Lumpur conference on Indo-Chinese refugees last February, it was provisionally decided that plans will be made for resettlement of those who arrived at transit camps in South-East Asia prior to the cut-off dates (June 1988 for Hong Kong and 14 March 1989 for South-East Asia), except for the cases of unaccompanied minors, which will be considered at a subsequent date. For those reaching the same shores after the cut-off date, their resettlement is subjected to strict screening procedures. Those, whose refugee status is acknowledged, will be accepted for resettlement, but those who are not considered as genuine refugees, will be placed in transit camps awaiting repatriation. Concrete measures will be taken at a conference on Indo-Chinese refugees to be held on June 13-14 in Geneva.

We the undersigned Australian citizens, respectfully request the governments of Australia and other countries as well as international organisations which will be represented at the forthcoming conference to:
1. expedite plans for resettlement at the earliest possible date of 65,000 Indo-Chinese refugees who arrived in camps throughout South East Asia prior to the cut-off date.
2. accept for resettlement all unaccompanied minors, who arrived in camps before the cut-off date.
3. accept for resettlement for those unaccompanied minors, who arrived in camps after the cut-off date and came under the following categories:
orphans having no relatives inside and outside Vietnam.
orphans whose relatives are living overseas and are prepared to sponsor them.
children whose parents are still in Vietnam and are being discriminated against and persecuted by the Communists regime (e.g., former South Vietnamese army officers, public servants, etc.)
4. establish screening procedures in such a way as to ensure impartiality and fairness.

5. guarantee a minimum standard of living (including the right to education and medical care, the right to follow religious practices, as well as the right to communicate with friend and relatives elsewhere) to those unqualified for the refugee status and awaiting repatriation.
6. establish practical and effective supervisory bodies to ensure that those who are repatriated to Vietnam will not face persecution and revenge by the Communist regime.
7. publicise as widely as possible all decisions reached at Geneva so that the people of Vietnam are made aware of the difficulties they would encounter if they should leave Vietnam.

SUMMARY OF THE COMMITTEE'S SCRUTINY
Passports Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 No. 39 and made under the Passports Act 1938.

The Committee's concern in relation to these Statutory Rules was a requirement that applications for Australian passports and other travel documents and for certain endorsements and renewals ``shall be in accordance with a form approved by the Minister''. These forms were not subject to tabling or disallowance and there were no criteria to guide the Minister in the exercise of the power.

The Minister provided a detailed explanation of the content of the forms and the background to them from the viewpoint of the personal rights of applicants. The Minister also explained the administration of the Passports Regulations generally and the changes in them which were made periodically.

The Committee noted the advice from the Minister and the fact that the forms were now required by the legislation to be approved personally by the Minister, and agreed to remove its notice of motion of disallowance.
The Committee thanks the Minister for his co-operation.

Dear Bob,

Thank you for your letter dated 24 April 1989 in which you asked whether the Passports Regulations could be amended to provide for the tabling and disallowing of applications for Australian passports and other travel documents for certain endorsements and renewals.

It would be possible for the Regulations to be amended to provide for the tabling and disallowing of passport application forms and associated forms. I feel however, that such a course of action would be undesirable for a number of reasons which I outline below.

At least half of the details appearing on the form are for the guidance and information of the public when applying for a passport. These details include the fee for issuing a passport, the location of the various passports offices, the passport information telephone number and other procedures to be followed when applying. Many of these details could be subject to change and in any event are matters of fact which do not require parliamentary scrutiny.

Applicants are requested to provide the information that will appear in the personal particulars page of the passport, i.e. full name, date and place of birth, sex and two specimen signatures, one of which is inserted in the passport and the other to provide a backup if the passport is inadvertently spoiled during processing. Some supporting information is also requested to establish the applicant's bona fides. This information includes evidence of Australian citizenship and a certificate of proof of identity. In the case of minors, written consent of both natural parents is also required and is in accordance with the provisions of the Passports Act. The form also asks for details of who is to be contacted in the case of an emergency. This is a desirable and indeed a sensible feature as the Consular Section of my Department often has to contact relatives or friends in Australia when travellers fall sick or are injured whilst overseas. These details do not infringe on personal rights of applicants and would not appear to be matters with which the Committee would wish to concern itself.

It may be helpful if the Committee understands that around three million application forms are printed each year (in three printings of one million each) and there are smaller printings of the other ancillary forms. At each printing, minor amendments are incorporated and one printing (in July each year) includes the updated fees for passport issue. These fees increase each July by the percentage increase of the Consumer Price Index as at the end of March. There could be a delay in the issue of the new forms if they were to be subject to scrutiny, with the consequential issue of out of date information to the public until a new form was agreed upon. My Department cannot start processing the new forms until at least mid-April when the March quarter Consumer Price Index figures are published.

The Committee may also be interested to know that 772972 passports were issued in 1987 and for the period January to April 1989, 280056 have been issued. If issues remain at the current level the anticipated total issue for 1989 will be 840168, an increase of 9 per cent over 1988. While the ratio of applications printed, to passports actually issued, is high, my Department's experience has been that a large number of applicants do not read the form carefully with a relatively high error rate resulting.

I acknowledge the need for parliamentary scrutiny of the Passport Regulations but suggest that the passport application forms are merely for administrative purposes and not designed nor intended to intrude on applicants' personal rights and as such no criteria to guide the Minister are necessary. The design of the form currently in circulation was arrived at after a firm of consultants suggested improvements and it has seen widespread approval by the public.

I do not believe therefore, that the referral of the passport application form to the Committee for scrutiny and possible disallowance by the parliament is necessary. I am however, enclosing a copy of the current form for your information.
Yours sincerely
GARETH EVANS

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and, not surprisingly, relates to the slaughter in Beijing at the weekend by the Government of China, through its army, of hundreds if not thousands of innocent, unarmed men, women and children who had been demonstrating in the capital for greater freedom and democracy. As all Australians would denounce this awful violence and want the Australian Government to do all within its power to press the Chinese authorities to end the carnage, I ask: Has the Australian Ambassador been recalled for consultations as a minimum of diplomatic protest; and if not, why not? Has the Government initiated any action in the major human rights fora of the world to bring international pressure to bear on China at least to accept the right of the Chinese people to demonstrate without fear of attack from that country's military forces? Has the Government consulted its major Western allies with a view to coordinating a response to this wanton violence which has the capacity to escalate into a conflict with major international consequences?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's response to the weekend's tragic events in China has been a strong one. It has been conveyed this morning by me to the Chinese Ambassador to Australia, Mr Zhang Zai. I will indicate to the Senate what I told him because I think it will show the force of our reaction which, I believe, stands for the views of the Australian people. I told him that the Australian Government was deeply distressed at the appalling and tragic events which have taken place in Beijing over the last 48 hours: we profoundly deplore what can only be described as the brutally excessive use of force against peaceful demonstrators which has resulted in a massive death and injury toll. I told him that in the view of the Australian Government the violent suppression of what has been manifestly a peaceful demonstration involves issues of fundamental human rights, and Australia deplores human rights violations of this kind wherever they occur; throughout past weeks the Australian Government has consistently expressed the hope that the impasse between the Chinese Government and the demonstrators could be resolved in a non-violent manner consistent with fundamental human rights; we had admired the restraint that had been demonstrated by the Government until the weekend; and we have been shocked at the extent to which that restraint has now been abandoned.

ANSWER.PARA: I said further to the Ambassador that the Australian Government very strongly urged the Chinese authorities to appreciate the damage that had already been done to China's reputation and standing in the world and to now once again exercise that restraint so as to avoid further bloodshed. I further advised the Ambassador, at the request of the Prime Minister, that in the circumstances Mr Hawke's planned visit to China in October will not now go ahead. I further advised the Ambassador formally that, as the Prime Minister had already indicated publicly yesterday, the planned goodwill visit to Shanghai by the Australian ship the HMAS Parramatta, scheduled for this week, will not now take place. I also advised the Ambassador that the Australian Government believed, in the circumstances, that it would be inappropriate to proceed with the visit scheduled to commence this coming weekend of the 19-person delegation from the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations and Trade and the Foreign Finance Administration, which visit was designed to discuss concessional finance for development projects in China.

I indicate, just to conclude the record, that the Ambassador was also given a copy of the advice to Australian travellers issued by my Department yesterday recommending, in view of the developments over the past two days, that all travel to China be postponed. I told him that we sought the assurance of the Chinese Government that the safety of Australian diplomatic and consular personnel and other long term residents, particularly students and visitors to China, would be guaranteed. I indicated finally that the Australian Government had welcomed the policies of reform and openness which have brought evident benefits to China and to the rest of the world, including Australia, and we hoped that, through restraint, stability might be restored swiftly to enable these important reform processes to be maintained and strengthened, creating the conditions for continuing close and productive relations between our two countries.

I think it will be appreciated from the text, in effect, of what was conveyed to the Chinese Ambassador that Australia's reaction has been, as I have said, a strong one. It is certainly no less strong than that of any other country in the world, and considerably stronger than that of a number of others.

We have not as yet addressed the question of recalling the Australian Ambassador to China. We prefer to hope that in the light of the very strong reactions that have now been received in Beijing from around the world, including from ourselves, the Chinese Government will come to its senses and there will be a return to more acceptable conduct in that country. At the moment the Ambassador is doing an extraordinarily important and delicate job extraordinarily well. In particular, he is looking after the interests of the very large number of Australians presently in China and in Beijing in respect of whom, although to our knowledge they are all presently safe, obvious difficulties arise about how to ensure their continued safety in what are very fluid and difficult circumstances. In those circumstances we believe, at least for the present, that Australia's interests are better served by the Ambassador staying there, particularly given the strength of the reaction and the other steps that we have taken to put beyond doubt Australia's strong feelings in this respect. The normal reason why one recalls an ambassador is to make an appropriately symbolic gesture of discontent or distaste for a course of events. If one can express that in other ways the point can be made very effectively.

As to instituting action in other human rights forums, that is a question that can be addressed in the period ahead. It has not been addressed at this stage, but I repeat that we regard what has happened as involving fundamental human rights violations. The suppression by violence of peaceful dissent and peaceful demonstrations is not something that can be regarded as a country's internal affair. These days it is very much the proper currency of international discourse and international focus and attention by the kind of agencies to which Senator Hill refers. Finally, Senator Hill asked me whether there had been any action with other major powers to develop some coordinated response to this. At present there has not been any such action. The appropriateness or otherwise of that is something we will address in the period ahead.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BUSINESS: DEBT TO EQUITY RATIO

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Did the Minister see an article entitled `Money, Credit and the Demand for Debt' in the May 1989 issue of the Reserve Bank Bulletin? Did that article note that the debt to equity ratio of stock exchange listed Australian businesses has risen from around 45 per cent in the early 1980s to about 100 per cent now? Is the Minister concerned about this development, and does the Government expect the debt to equity ratio to continue to increase?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read the whole article, but I have looked at the various statistics presented in it. The article does note that in the course of the 1980s Australian business came to rely much more heavily on debt finance as opposed to equity finance. I am certainly concerned about that development, and I have been for a long time. Among other things, it means that business is more unstable and more vulnerable to swings in the business cycle. It is also not unrelated-indeed, it is probably quite strongly related-to the build-up of the Australian private sector's international indebtedness.

ANSWER.PARA: Whether it is reasonable to expect the trend of the 1980s to continue into the 1990s depends on what the causes of the 1980s trend were. They include the old-fashioned double taxation of dividends. Under that system there was a clear incentive for equity to be replaced by debt. We have got rid of double taxation with the imputation system. The Government moved to that remedy in July 1987, but that still left a problem if the source of the debt financing was a body not paying tax. Under those circumstances the interest payment was completely tax-free, not taxed at any point.

On the other hand, dividends were subject to one layer of taxation instead of the previous two. Therefore, superannuation funds still faced a massive incentive to provide finance via debt instruments rather than company shares. In response to that, in the May 1988 economic statement, the Government moved to bring superannuation funds into the imputation system and the level playing field.

For reasons similar to the treatment of interest payments being tax deductable in the hands of the payer but not taxable in the hands of an exempt body which was receiving the interest, as against equity which was taxed once or which is now taxed only in the hands of a company, the still existing arrangements which the Government moved to correct in May 1988 favour investment in foreign equities as against Australian equities, investment in real estate or speculation instead of equity in businesses engaged in productive activities-factories, mines and so on-and also provide incentives to superannuation funds to engage in joint ventures instead of company shares; that is, in the process bypassing the corporate taxation point and eroding the corporate tax base-an erosion, were that position allowed to remain unaltered, which would probably proceed at an accelerating rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. What action can the Government take to correct these distortions and their effects on domestic employment, economic growth and foreign debt?

—The Government is trying to correct those distortions which I have outlined, which damage Australia's economic growth, international account and employment, with a package of Bills now before the Senate. Unfortunately, we are being sabotaged in that attempt by an opposition which does not even know what it is doing-supported, up to this stage, I regret to say, by the Australian Democrats, who are repudiating their rhetoric of the last six years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a report that the New South Wales Premier, Nick Greiner, directed or asked his Minister for Natural Resources, Ian Causley, to reopen negotiations with the Commonwealth over the south-east forests in New South Wales. ANSWER.PARA: Resource availability has always been the crucial issue, as you correctly identify.

with the conclusions of ours. Senator Puplick interjecting-

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Can the Minister inform the Senate how many Australian taxpayers paid tax under the new capital gains tax provisions in respect of the 1986-87 financial year? How much of the total capital gains tax paid was paid by persons who had incomes of over $50,000 in that year? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Taxation Office publication Taxation Statistics 1986-87 was published last week and shows the figures in Table 25. That table shows that in that year just over 21,000 Australians paid tax under the new capital gains tax provisions. The total number of taxpayers in that year was 8.3 million. So one taxpayer in 400 pays capital gains tax. Of total capital gains tax collected, more than 65 per cent was paid by people with incomes above $50,000, and nearly 80 per cent was collected from people with taxable incomes above $35,000. I ask the Senate to bear in mind that those figures are for 1986-87; they are now two years old. So it is very clear that any move to abolish or dilute the capital gains tax would benefit only a tiny proportion of taxpayers-one in 400-and that the tax is skewed very heavily in favour of high income earners.

ANSWER.PARA: If capital gains tax were to be abolished or diluted, the revenue would have to be raised somewhere else. Of course, if a government were to follow the irresponsible fiscal policies and the irresponsible example set by the last coalition Government, that revenue loss would be offset by letting the deficit blow out. However, if the responsible course were chosen instead, the rates of tax on middle and low income Australians would have to be increased. The major beneficiaries of the abolition or serious dilution of the capital gains tax, as proposed by the Opposition the last time it said something publicly about this, would be those people who organise shonky rearrangements of company shareholdings, such as the Federal President of the Liberal Party.

—Is the Minister for Consumer Affairs aware of an article appearing in the Daily Mirror on 30 May under the headline `Bankruptcies Highest Ever'? Is it correct, as the article claims, that the latest personal bankruptcy figures are the worst ever? Can the Minister say what is the trend in bankruptcies in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Faulkner for his question. As he says, the report in the Daily Mirror is one of a number of reports which I have seen in recent days and which indicate that bankruptcies are at their highest level ever and are, in fact, increasing. That particular article to which Senator Faulkner refers claims that the latest personal bankruptcy figures indicate that.

ANSWER.PARA: Many of these reports have been based on information contained in the latest bankruptcy annual report, which was tabled quite recently. However, since that report, and even preceding that, a number of figures have been released for periods since the financial year 1987-88. Those figures indicate that progressively over the last nine months from July 1988 there has been a substantial decrease in the number of bankruptcies. For instance, for the March quarter 1989 there has been a decrease of 20.9 per cent in bankruptcies and administration orders, a decrease of 40 per cent in part 10 deeds and compositions, and a decrease of 22.8 per cent in the combined figures for all bankruptcies and insolvencies. This is the third consecutive quarter to show a decline in new bankruptcies and part 10 arrangements. In fact, for the nine-month period from July 1988 to March 1989 there has been a decrease in all bankruptcies and part 10 arrangements of 14.7 per cent. Far from the latest personal bankruptcies going up, there has been a very clear and consistent decline over the last nine months.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. In asking this question I would like to make it clear that I neither condone nor advocate violent acts. I ask the Minister: Is he aware of the deep concern felt by the Chilean community and its supporters in Perth, Western Australia, over the immediate future of Chilean trade unionist and activist, Mr Sergio Buschmann? Is it true that an undertaking was given by the Minister or his representative that Mr Buschmann would not be arrested or detained if he voluntarily came out of hiding to talk with officers of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs? If so, was this undertaking subsequently broken? Is it a fact that the Chilean Government sought to have Mr Buschmann sent back to Chile? If so, at what stage are these discussions? Has a decision yet been made? If so, what is that decision? If not, when is a decision likely to be made? Is it possible that Mr Buschmann may be sent back to Sweden because of allegations made with regard to irregularities not in accordance with the provisions of his visa? If this is found to be the case, what guarantee can the Minister give that Mr Buschmann will not be detained in transit in Singapore or Hong Kong, and thus sent back to Chile?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of certain concern expressed by members of the Chilean community in Australia. That does not surprise me. For the most part, they have been fed a whole variety of stories, none of which has been true. There has never been a question of Mr Buschmann being deported to Chile. He is no longer a citizen of Chile; he has refugee status and resident status in Sweden. Therefore, my Department's attitude to Mr Buschmann is that if he were to be deported from this country it would be to Sweden. It has been a deliberate policy of Mr Buschmann's supporters to mix together all those issues in order to get an emotional response from the Chilean community. I think they have been sorely and badly advised in this particular matter.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to Senator Jenkins's second question, yes, undertakings were given to Mr Buschmann on the Friday that if he came in he would not be detained. Prior to that we issued several invitations and several appointments were broken. That undertaking was kept. May I say that the undertaking that he would not be detained is not unusual. In most cases where visa breaches occur, we much prefer to give the person concerned an opportunity to leave the country voluntarily. In most cases, this method obtains. After all, it is even cheaper: if we do not deport them we do not have to pay for their air fares. So it is normal in these circumstances. That occurred on the Friday. On the Saturday when Mr Buschmann was asked to come in, no such guarantee was given. Indeed, my officers were asked, `Will you guarantee he will not be detained?'. My officers continually said, `No, we won't give any such guarantee. We require Mr Buschmann to come in on the Saturday morning'. So, the answer to question No. 2 is yes and then no.

With regard to question Nos 3, 4 and 5, I have had no advice, no contact in any way, with the Chilean Government. No doubt, maybe the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade or the Attorney-General's Department has but certainly my Department has not. We are acting purely on immigration matters and what we regard as a breach of immigration matters. I might also add that I have had no contact from any multinationals putting pressure on me. I can only describe the garbage put out by Mr Buschmann's supporters-I now have three of them on the public record saying that this Government is acting to deport Mr Buschmann because of pressure from multinational companies-is not only outrageous but also untrue and deliberately deceptive. They are playing on the susceptibilities of some of Mr Buschmann's more innocent supporters.

In question No. 6 Senator Jenkins asked whether Mr Buschmann would be sent back to Sweden. The matter still is at least peripherally in the Federal Court inasmuch as there is a temporary injunction, but it is my Department's intention to deport Mr Buschmann-and to deport him to Sweden. As I say, he was given an opportunity to leave voluntarily; he did not avail himself of that as many other people do in similar circumstances. His supporters insisted that he continue part of his tour; that he go to Adelaide for a concert, et cetera. It is hardly likely that my Department will grant permission to someone who is already in two direct breaches of his visa conditions to continue to breach them.

As to the final question-again, there has been a lot of misleading information about this-the timing, the travel route and the privacy of the arrangements regarding Mr Buschmann's departure are subject and will be subject to negotiation with Mr Buschmann. As he is a refugee, I would always seek that, when he leaves the country, by which route he leaves the country and the secrecy of that be handled in such a way as not to make him vulnerable to any other activity against him so that he can have safe passage through to Sweden. That has been our position from day one and it remains it today. We have no intention of placing Mr Buschmann in a situation where his life may be endangered or he cannot travel back to Sweden, where he has refugee status. I think that that answers the seven points to the honourable senator's question. I do not comment on Mr Buschmann's political leanings. My colleague Senator Evans has done so in a press release last Friday. Personally, I endorse all those remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Treasurer tell the Senate what the respective anticipated revenue gains are from each of the following proposed superannuation taxes: firstly, the introduction of the 15 per cent tax on employer contributions; secondly, the introduction of a 15 per cent tax on investment income; thirdly, the capital gains tax on superannuation funds; and, fourthly, the 16.25 per cent tax on end benefits over $60,000?
—The Minister may want to answer the question but, as the relevant Bills are before the chamber, technically the question is out of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is probably true, Mr President. I was just waiting for Senator Puplick to raise a point of order. However, that is just another demonstration of his double standards.
—The point was taken last week. I am allowing the question.

—The revenue under most of the heads of revenue, or possible revenue, named in the question will depend upon the investment policies of superannuation fund managers and whether superannuation fund managers are allowed to take advantage of dividend imputation, as the Government proposes, or not allowed to take advantage of dividend imputation, as the Opposition proposes. What the Government proposes is that superannuation funds which invest in foreign equities will, firstly, pay the tax which is due in the foreign country and, secondly, pay tax again in Australia on the dividends when they are returned to Australia, but that superannuation funds that invest in Australian enterprises not pay tax on the dividends. What the Opposition proposes is to get rid of that principle-that is, of encouraging Australian superannuation funds to invest in Australian equities-by relieving superannuation funds of the tax they would otherwise have to pay on dividend income received from foreign investment. In other words, what Senator Bishop-I presume in crass ignorance-moved and had this chamber carry last Thursday night was a proposal to encourage Australian superannuation funds to invest in foreign equities instead of Australian equities. That is only the beginning, of course.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order--
—Ah, now it is out of order! Here come the double standards again.
—Order! I call Senator Chaney.

—I think I could hear a Minister debating a question, Mr President, and according to the Standing Orders he is prohibited from doing so. He was asked a series of questions about the revenue implications of certain matters which the Government is raising. It was a straightforward question. The Minister may be saying that the Government has no idea what the revenue implications are, although the Treasurer actually gave an estimate of the overall cost. We are asking the Minister for a breakdown of those costs.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I was asked about the revenue implications of the package of Bills that the Government has before this chamber. Right at the beginning of my answer I said that that depends on the decisions that the managers of superannuation funds make in response to those Bills or in response to some bastardised version of them that the Opposition would have the Government endorse. I am going through some of the possible responses that are strictly relevant to the question asked. The incentive to invest in foreign equities is mainly the beginning of the damage.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Firstly, you have not given a ruling on my previous point of order. Secondly, we have a question which goes to the breakdown of the figure which has already been given by the Government as to the total cost. The Minister either is saying that he is unable to give a breakdown or has some figures which make up the gross figure of the $1.4 billion. The Minister is clearly debating the question at this moment. He is not seeking to answer the quite specific question. If he is not capable of answering the question, he should be asked to sit down so that we can ask another question.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Senator Walsh was asked for statistics. Those statistics were predicated on certain conditions. Senator Walsh is saying, `If the conditions are varied, this is the result'. For once, at least, he is being very relevant to the subject.
—Order! I will allow Senator Walsh to continue. I remind the Minister that he must not debate the question. I will listen very carefully to his answer.

—Thank you for that guidance, Mr President. The revenue which will be gained or lost depends on the investment decisions made by fund managers. The great majority of our estimate comes from the levy on funds paid into the superannuation fund.
—How much of it?

—I cannot remember off the top of my head. The ultimate revenues gained or lost depend on a number of other things. For example, if superannuation funds are provided with incentives to provide debt financing instruments instead of equity financing instruments, the interest received escapes taxation altogether. With equity financing instruments it does not; it is taxed in the hands of the company. The Government's proposals allow the benefit of that tax already paid by the company to be claimed by the superannuation fund. The Opposition would have that incentive-that is, for equity instead of debt financing-removed. Under its proposition there would be no taxing point whatsoever for debt financing.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition's amendments would also favour superannuation fund investment in central business district property, other real estate, and speculative real estate activity, instead of investment in productive Australian businesses. It would also encourage superannuation funds to become joint venturers instead of shareholders in companies, which would thereby escape any taxing point whatsoever and in the process erode the corporate taxation base, probably at an accelerating rate. It does not surprise me that the Opposition is putting this proposal up because, after all, it is taking its orders from John Elliott. It surprises me that the Australian Democrats can, without any apparent embarrassment, support that set of propositions, thereby repudiating their six-year-old rhetoric.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his dissertation, vitriol and abuse. I go back to my original question: Can the Minister quantify those four categories? As he is able to give a quantified amount of $1.4 billion for the total package there must be some estimate of the component parts. Can he give us a breakdown or, simply, will he not do so?

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 May 1989 Senator Knowles asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, a question relating to the administration of the Child Support Agency. As the answer runs to about 3 1/2 pages, I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

It is unclear precisely what Senator Knowles was referring to. The Registrar of Child Support-who is the Commissioner for Taxation and is responsible for the administration of the Child Support Act-has provided information in relation to two categories of case that may fall within the bounds of Senator Knowles's question. The first relates to the number of cases in which the Agency in attempting to contact a parent liable to pay maintenance has contacted the wrong person. The Registrar advises that there have been three such cases. Of course in each case the recipient of the notice from the CSA has had a statutory right to object to the notice. The Registrar has advised me that in each of these three cases the notice advised the recipient that that right was available.

Senator Knowles referred to there being hundreds of incorrect notices in Western Australia. She was probably referring to cases where the Agency has registered liabilities arising under court orders made since 1 June 1988 even though the custodial parent has made no application to the Agency. I dealt with these cases in an answer to a question from Senator Giles on 23 May. The crucial points are:
(i) these notices were not incorrect-they correctly notified recipients of liabilities that existed under the Child Support Act;
(ii) however, these notices were incomplete-they did not notify non pensioner custodial parents that they have an unqualified right to opt out of Agency collection;
(iii) the Agency has modified its procedures to make sure that in these cases non pensioner payees are advised of their rights to opt out;

(iv) the primary cause for the problem in these cases is not the actions of the Agency-it is the failure of the parties to comply with their legal obligation to advise the Agency of the making of a maintenance order or the registering of an agreement:
This obligation applies to everybody who gets a maintenance order or agreement;
It is clear many lawyers are, even after a year of operation of the Agency, failing to advise their clients of this obligation.

The Registrar has advised me that there were about 400 cases registered without applications from custodial parents before the change of procedures designed to make sure people are aware of their right to opt out of Agency collection.

Senator Knowles referred to what she called `misuse of the tax file number.' The Child Support Registrar has advised me that the tax file number is the standard identifier used in the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). The Child Support Agency is part of the ATO and use of the tax file number by the CSA is perfectly valid. There is no question of misuse of the tax file number by the CSA. For too long in Australia we have had a maintenance system which has been effectively voluntary. Custodians and their children have been left to rely on pension-at great cost to themselves, their children and the public. To address this the Child Support Act was passed by this Parliament unanimously. The Parliament there expressly directed the Tax Office to administer that Act to achieve two objectives. I quote from the Act:
(a) that children receive from their parents the financial support that the parents are liable to provide; and
(b) that periodic amounts payable by non-custodial parents towards the maintenance of their children are paid on a regular and timely basis.

Let me repeat: the Registrar advises that there have been three cases in a year where a notice has gone to the wrong person: three out of over 22,000 cases. In each of those cases the recipient of the notice had a statutory right to object to the registration of a liability against him or her and I am advised, was advised of that right. That is a record of administration which is squarely within the objects and principles of the Child Support Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented and seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald of 5 June 1989 written by Greg Roberts and headed `Anger over threat of renewed sand-mining' is one of the most slovenly, inaccurate and mendacious pieces of second-rate journalism which I have seen for a long time. Mr Roberts telephoned me at home on Sunday afternoon last to ask me a series of questions, most of them hypothetical, about possible future resource development proposals. The first point to be made is that I told Roberts that I would not be drawn into giving definitive answers or concluded views on purely hypothetical propositions, a point which is certainly not made in the slovenly report now printed. The device of saying that I `refused to rule out' something is rather a tawdry, dishonest trick, just as much so as failing to make the point that I refused to rule out the continuation of an export ban on Fraser Island mineral sands. It is a trick frequently used to elevate hypothetical situations into apparently real ones. It is an old technique resorted to by the dishonest and second-rate.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of Fraser Island, I made the following points: firstly, Fraser Island is unique and deserves protection; secondly, I personally supported the original Fraser Government actions in imposing a mineral sands export ban; and thirdly, any proposal for a renewal of mineral sands export activity would have to be considered by Cabinet and would be decided entirely on its merits, including, obviously, its environmental ones. At least the article notes my comment that it would not be possible to determine any outcome of such an application. It should be noted that the Commonwealth control in this area extends only to activities undertaken for export purposes.

Roberts equally misrepresents my position in relation to logging in North Queensland. What Roberts asked me was whether we would be reviewing current prohibitions on activities in World Heritage listed areas. I responded by saying that all federally imposed conditions would be reviewed, this being consistent with the commitments in our printed policy. Again I stressed that such a review would not necessarily mean that things would be changed. That is one of the few accurate quotes in Roberts's article. At no stage did I specify any policy on `rain- forest logging' in the way which is portrayed later in the Roberts beat-up article. The whole of the Roberts article is slovenly in the way in which it presents a series of prognostications as to what may happen or what has not been ruled out as constituting anything more than a determination on the part of an incoming coalition government to treat all environmental and resource matters and their resolution entirely on the basis of merit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the seventeenth report of the Committee of Privileges, entitled Possible Improper Interference with a Witness-Drugs in Sport Inquiry, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate endorse the finding contained in paragraph 34 of the report.

In the statement made on behalf of the Committee to the Senate on 11 May, I indicated that the Committee would be tabling a report, as soon as possible after the Senate resumed in May, giving reasons for its finding, in relation to the matter referred to it on 8 December 1988, that Mr Greg Blood's action in asking Ms Sue Howland to leave his house on the day after she gave evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on 30 November 1988 was not a contempt of the Senate, in that Mr Blood did not improperly interfere with, or inflict a penalty or injury upon, Ms Howland, on account of evidence she gave before the Standing Committee in relation to its inquiry into the use of drugs in sport.

Briefly, the Committee made the finding on the basis that Mr Blood was concerned about the escalation of a situation beyond his control, that he took the actions that he did in a state of stress, and was motivated by a desire to obtain relief from the stressful situation in which he found himself. Thus, the Committee has concluded that the intention necessary to establish an offence in this case did not exist.

The Committee makes the point, however, that actions taken by persons in order to prevent information being produced, or to impose a penalty as a result of the production of that information, would seriously impede a committee's inquiry, and is of the view that they would amount to a serious contempt of the Senate deserving of serious censure and penalty. The Committee reiterates that in the circumstances of the present case the requisite intention has not been established and thus a finding has been made that no contempt has been committed. I commend the report to the Senate and seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I table a revised explanatory memorandum and seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill amends a number of Acts administered within the Attorney-General's portfolio. Some parts of the Bill contain minor amendments designed to correct or update existing legislation. Other parts of the Bill contain more significant amendments designed to implement new policy and ensure that existing legislation is able to deal effectively with sophisticated crime.
A detailed explanation of the provisions of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum. I propose to address only the more significant aspects of the Bill.
Crimes Act 1914

The Bill contains a number of amendments to the Crimes Act 1914. There are significant amendments dealing with computer crime and fines under the Act are to be substantially increased. The Bill also inserts a new part into the Crimes Act that will provide for a scheme that will permit old convictions for minor offences to be spent.
COMPUTER CRIME

The provisions in the Bill relating to computer offences follow, substantially, the recommendations of the committee reviewing Commonwealth criminal law chaired by the former Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Harry Gibbs. The committee was asked to report specifically on the need for new legislation in this area, and its report was presented and released last November and tabled in Parliament on 12 April 1989. The need for new legislation arises out of three main considerations.

The first is the possible vulnerability of information in computer systems, by comparison with paper records. Unauthorised access to paper files can be prevented by relatively simple security measures, and when such measures fail it is usually because an offence, or at least a breach of duty, has been committed by a person with authorised access. Not so with computer records, where access to restricted information by unauthorised persons can in many cases be obtained simply by ingenuity in overcoming technical barriers. Such access might be obtained from inside an organisation by persons prepared to exceed a limited access authority, or through the telephone communication system by external `hackers'. Vulnerability does not relate only to access. Computer information can be exposed to risk of damage, destruction or alteration from a large number of sources within or outside the computer-using organisation. Such conduct could have a variety of motives. It might be for gain, as in the case of traditional embezzlement; it might be a malicious desire to cause damage or create confusion or disruption in an organisation; or it might be simple unauthorised experimentation. All such conduct is socially undesirable and its consequences can be disastrous, as reports of damage from so-called computer viruses have shown.

The second consideration is the widespread and growing reliance of modern society on computer systems and communications systems that depend on computers. We need to foster confidence in the security and reliability of such systems not only from the point of view of governments and businesses that use them but from the point of view of individuals whose private information might be contained in them.

The third consideration is the need for the law to be relevant to modern technology. Our criminal law relating to forgery, uttering, fraud and false pretences was framed with people, pens and paper in mind. Now we have machines, magnetic memories and electronic impulses. How traditional offences can be applied in the setting of new technology can be very uncertain. We should not leave this situation to be tested in the trial courts and the appeal process when it is possible to create new offences directed at unauthorised and deliberate acts of misconduct done with, or aimed at, computers.

The Bill creates a series of offences involving either deliberate unauthorised access to data, or more serious offences where such access is gained and the offender either, gained that access with intent to defraud or, knew or ought reasonably to have known that the data was of a specified type which is considered particularly sensitive. It is not intended that the question whether the person ought reasonably to have known involve an objective test but rather that the court be able to have regard to all the circumstances surrounding the offence including the characteristics, knowledge, skills and attributes of the particular offender when determining this question.

The amendments do not seek to cover computer crime generally. There is no need for such an approach as many situations can be more appropriately dealt with by State Laws and law enforcement authorities. Instead, the provisions in this Bill are directed at two classes of situation where Commonwealth provisions are either necessary or useful.

The first relates to the protection of Commonwealth computers and data in them. This is clearly a proper function of Commonwealth criminal law. The second kind of situation is where the misconduct (that is the unauthorised access, interference or damage) takes place by means of a Commonwealth facility, whether or not the victimised computer system is a Commonwealth one. We have here in mind particularly the telecom communication system through which all major computer networks, and many smaller systems, will be linked. One of the advantages of covering such situations by Commonwealth legislation is that a common offence will apply across all Australian jurisdictions-thus enabling a prosecution to be brought in the most convenient venue when the elements occur in two or more States or Territories.

It is not intended that this offence of computer misconduct through use of telecom and such facilities will displace any State or Territory offences that may also have been committed. One or other offence or both could be charged, subject to the usual rules against double jeopardy. It will of course, be a matter for each jurisdiction to decide whether to enact specific computer legislation, and two have already done so.

In accepting the Gibbs Committee's recommendation for new offences involving use of Commonwealth communications facilities the Government is taking account not only of possible frauds and other offences that might be committed across boundaries but the potential use of such facilities for `hacking' and for the deliberate causing of computer malfunctions through viruses or other means.

I wish to make it clear that these new offence provisions are intended to protect information while it is in a computer system. They are not intended to give that information a special character so that after it has been obtained from a computer special penalties attach to its unauthorised use. Thus the ordinary law about unauthorised disclosure would apply in relation to a third party receiving the information. No new offence is brought into existence in relation to a third party except where that party is an accessory to the computer-related misconduct.
PENALTY PROVISIONS

The Bill makes two general changes to the penalty provisions of the Crimes Act. First, it will increase the maximum fine that may be imposed for certain Commonwealth offences-that is for most offences in the Crimes Act and those other offences for which no fine is expressly specified. The relativities between imprisonment and maximum fines were last adjusted in 1982. When I speak of `relativities', I should stress that specified maximum fines are not to be regarded in any sense as substitutable for, or to be served instead of, the corresponding period of imprisonment. As the review committee points out, maximum fines should have regard to the worst kind of breach that is appropriate for a fine rather than imprisonment. Therefore it is not possible to equate a fine with a particular period of imprisonment, for example by having regard to weekly earnings. Also, periods of imprisonment in default of payment of a fine are a quite separate matter. The new scale will be given effect by a simplified formula in place of a table. Some examples of the effect of the increased maximum penalties are:
6 months imprisonment-$3,000 fine instead of $1,000
3 years imprisonment-$18,000 fine instead of $10,000
20 years imprisonment-$120,000 fine instead of $20,000.
An offence punishable by a maximum of life imprisonment would become punishable by a fine of up to $200,000.

While the new relativities now provided for will be made generally applicable, through this Bill and future legislation directed to other offence provisions, the relativities will not be followed universally. Where a different relativity is justified as a matter of policy, special provision will be made for this.
In cases where a fine would be imposed on a corporation a multiplier of 5 will continue to be used.

Secondly, it is intended to follow the practice for new offences in recent years by providing in relation to the Crimes Act, and elsewhere where not otherwise specified, that a fine may be imposed additionally as well as alternatively to imprisonment. The aim of this approach is to make available to the court the greatest possible range of sentencing options within the limits of the maximum prison term and the maximum fine. For example it would be possible to impose a short or suspended prison term together with a fine.

Both the changes I have described are intended to be steps towards adoption of a more uniform and rational scheme of penalties for all Commonwealth offences. Further steps in that process will be taken in the light of recommendations to be made by the committee reviewing Commonwealth criminal law.
SPENT CONVICTIONS

The question of spent convictions has been the subject of a report by the Australian Law Reform Commission and extensive discussions in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. Queensland has had legislation dealing with the rehabilitation of offenders since 1986 which is more limited in scope than the ALRC proposals. As an exercise in uniformity agreement was reached in SCAG that all jurisdictions would enact legislation dealing with spent convictions broadly along the lines of the Queensland model.

The spent convictions scheme is designed to give people a chance to live down a minor criminal conviction. Clearly it is in the best interests of society, and the person involved, that where the person has been convicted of a minor offence, has paid the penalty and subsequently been of good behaviour for an extended period then they should be protected from those who might discriminate against them. The scheme is rehabilitative and will contribute to the Government's efforts to reduce crime. The Government's perspective of the benefits of the scheme is supported by experience with similar schemes in operation in the United States, most European countries and Japan.

I will now briefly outline the details of the scheme. The legislation will prohibit disclosure of, or discrimination against a person on the basis of, a conviction for a minor offence where the person has been of good behaviour for 10 years after conviction. The scheme also allows a person to deny that he or she has a conviction where it is spent. This is necessary to ensure that the scheme is not undermined by the implication that a person who refuses to answer questions relating to the person's criminal history has a spent conviction. The same approach has been followed in the Queensland Act and the Western Australian scheme has the same result. A minor offence is one where an actual sentence of 30 months imprisonment or less was imposed. The prohibitions on disclosure and discrimination will apply generally to Commonwealth employment and in the non-self governing territories in respect of all convictions, Commonwealth, State and foreign. The prohibitions are a consequence of conviction of a Commonwealth offence and therefore will apply throughout Australia in respect of convictions for Commonwealth offences.

Having established a general rule, there will inevitably be circumstances to which that general rule should not apply. To this end the legislation provides a scheme of exemptions. Some of these are spelt out specifically in the legislation. Clearly a court or a prosecuting body should be able to take spent convictions into account when sentencing or deciding whether to prosecute. Certain types of employment require, for public policy reasons, full disclosure of any convictions. Persons employed in law enforcement and national security will therefore be exempt from the scheme and have to disclose spent convictions. In other types of employment certain convictions will always be relevant. An example of this is where a person has been convicted of a sexual offence involving children and seeks employment caring for children or as a teacher. In addition to these statutory exemptions it will also be open to Government to make regulations exempting persons, or classes of persons, from the scheme.

The mechanism contained in the legislation is that an application may be made to the privacy commissioner for exemption. The privacy commissioner will then make a recommendation to government on whether regulations should be made to exempt the applicant, or the class of which the applicant is a member. The Bill enables the provisions which empower the privacy commissioner to consider and recommend exemptions to operate immediately on royal assent. The spent convictions scheme itself will not, however, come into force until proclamation or, failing that, 12 months after royal assent. The privacy commissioner has indicated that he will be able to advertise for applications for exemption, consider any applications received and recommend any appropriate exemptions to the Minister to enable regulations to be made within the 12 month period. The Attorney-General has undertaken that the privacy commissioner will consult with opposition parties on proposed exemptions.

Rather than create a range of offences to enforce the scheme the privacy commissioner will be given conciliation and civil remedies powers, similar to those conferred by the Privacy Act, to resolve breaches of the legislation.

The amendments will change the common law which provides that a pardon only relieves a person from the consequences of a conviction. If it is subsequently found that a person was wrongly convicted and a pardon is granted on that basis, justice requires that the person should be put in the same position as if he or she had never been convicted at all.
Customs Act 1901

In 1987 the Parliament passed legislation designed to strike at the heart of major organized crime by depriving persons involved of the proceeds of their criminal endeavours. That legislation, the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, was a major advance on existing legislation which dealt with the forfeiture of property and the imposition and recovery of pecuniary penalties such as Part XIII Division 3 of the Customs Act 1901.

Part XIII Division 3 of the Customs Act was inserted in 1979. It was stated during the second reading debate at the time that the objective of the legislation was to facilitate the imposition of ``a pecuniary penalty equivalent to the benefit derived from dealing in illicit drugs''. Section 243b therefore provided for the imposition of a pecuniary penalty, to be assessed in accordance with section 243c. Quite properly, section 243c provided that the court, when assessing the value of the benefit derived by a person from dealing with illicit drugs, could have regard to property acquired by reason of dealing in narcotics, that had been diverted by the dealer into the possession of a person other than the drug dealer. Most commonly, this might be property which is disguised as the property of a company controlled by the drug dealer.

However, it is a striking flaw in the legislative scheme of Part XII Division 3 that, when it comes to satisfying the pecuniary penalty, no provision was made for applying that other property in satisfaction of the penalty. That defect was cured in the Proceeds of Crime Act by the ``effective control'' provision (section 9) and the power to lift the corporate veil (section 28). Part 5 of the Bill now before the House will remove this defect from the Customs Act by inserting new provisions modelled upon the provisions of the Proceeds Act.
Part 5 of the Bill makes a number of other amendments to Part XIII Division 3 of the Customs Act with a view to harmonising its provisions with those of the Proceeds Act.
Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983

Part 6 of the Bill proposes two amendments to the DPP Act. The first, confers a general power on the director to file an ex officio indictment other than for a prosecution under the War Crimes Act 1945. This general power will not be delegable and a related amendment ensures that the general ex officio power must be exercised personally by the director. This will put the Commonwealth DPP in the same position as his counterparts in Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria.

The second enlarges the power of the director to give an indemnity. At present the Director may give a use indemnity which is an undertaking that evidence given by a person in specified Commonwealth proceedings will not be used in evidence against the person in any civil or criminal proceedings, other than proceedings for perjury. The Act is to be amended to provide for full use/derivative use indemnity. That is, the undertaking will extend to the use of evidence which is obtained as a direct or indirect result of the primary evidence given by the witness. This adopts a recommendation made by the Senate Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in its report on the National Crime Authority Bill.

A new power to give an indemnity against prosecution, to be known as a transactional indemnity, is also to be conferred upon the Director. Again, it is proposed that this power be exercised personally by the Director.
National Crime Authority Act

The Bill also provides for some fine tuning of the NCA Act. The inter-governmental committee on the National Crime Authority has recently concluded that there is a need to clearly establish the management responsibility of the chairman, while preserving the inquiry powers of other members. The Act is to be amended to make the Chairman responsible for the day-to-day management of the Authority with the power to make or delegate decisions in appropriate circumstances, give directions and undertake activities that are required to perform the functions of the Authority.

Certain Commonwealth agencies which are currently subject to s.19a of the NCA Act, which provides certain bodies with a discretion to provide information to the Authority upon request, will be made subject to sections 28 and 29 which enable the Authority to require the furnishing of information or production of documents at hearings. These agencies are operating as financial or quasi-commercial enterprises in the private sector and will be accorded similar status under the Act to private organisations in those fields. This is consistent with the Government's policy with regard to Government business enterprises. It is also proposed to amend section 19a to ensure that it provides sufficient protection for the requested agency from liability for breach of confidentiality. It is intended to insert a clause providing the requested agency with the appropriate protection.
The Bill also provides for a number of minor changes to the Act to streamline the Authority's day-to-day operations by reducing the need for meetings of the Authority wherever possible.
Financial Impact Statement

The measures outlined above have minimal financial impact. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission will require 1 extra person to handle workload generated for the privacy commissioner under the spent convictions scheme. While the amendments to the Customs Act will not require additional resources there is an expectation that the revision of Part XIII Division 3 will result in extra revenue to the Commonwealth. The other amendments have no financial impact. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
