SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move-

SPEECH.PARA: That Government Business, Order of the Day No. 1 (Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 and related Bills) be postponed till a later hour of the day.

The Government is requesting this postponement so as to give the Opposition time to prepare amendments to attempt to correct the chaos caused by its bungled amendments of last week. For almost 12 months since the Government announced this package and this policy-indeed, right until 9 May this year-there was no suggestion that the Opposition would oppose any of these Bills. Indeed, there was no suggestion in a sequence of statements and reports to the shadow Cabinet meeting on 6 May 1988, from the reported recommendation from Mr Connolly to the shadow Cabinet in June 1988 and the fact that industry representatives had advised the Government that Mr Connolly's office had told them the same thing during 1988 and, finally, from the Opposition's retirement income policy, that the Opposition would be opposing the policy then proposed by the Government. Quite the contrary-there was a sequence of statements indicating support. Mr Connolly's excuse for the eleventh hour change is that he did not have the legislation until this year, which is true. However, the principles were spelt out very clearly in the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of May last year-in particular, the principle which the Opposition is now amending which is that superannuation fund income would be taxed at a concessional rate and that tax liability could be wiped out by the receipt of a sufficient volume of franked dividends.

The amendment which the Opposition has proposed destroys the logic and the symmetry of the package. There are a number of possibilities. The first is that the amendment was a cheap, cynical stunt designed to ingratiate the Opposition with some of the sleazier sections of the industry, not expecting, of course, that the Australian Democrats would support it. Secondly, in a biblical sense, it was a case of `Forgive them, for they know not what they do'. That is, the Opposition left the carriage of this matter to a lightweight member of the front bench who does not understand it.

The Opposition certainly demonstrated its incompetence in this area by introducing an amendment last Thursday night although half the industry was left out of its ambit. It is that damage-that bungling incompetence-which the Opposition now seeks an opportunity to have time to correct. Incidentally for the record, Mr Connolly now admits that, having attempted on Friday to deny that half the industry was left out and having asserted that I owed the Parliament an explanation for not pointing out the defects in the amendment. May I say, in response to that, that I am always pointing out to the Opposition its mistakes, but it is either too malevolent or too stupid to take any notice.

Presumably, the amendments which the Opposition is trying to prepare are aimed at extending the exemptions, which it moved and had carried in the Senate on Thursday night, to pooled trusts and life offices. If that is the case, it will again reveal the Opposition's incompetence, because last Thursday night it voted against an amendment moved by Senator Haines to extend, for a limited period, exemption to pooled trusts. If the Opposition is to come back, seeking to extend the ambit of its amendment to pooled trusts, I hope it will also explain why it voted against the same amendment when it was moved by Senator Haines last Thursday night.

I want to make three principal points concerning the policy issues covered by the Opposition's amendments. The amendments proposed by the Opposition, relative to the policy proposed by the Government, will have these effects--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind Senator Walsh that the motion before the Chair is a matter of postponement. He should not develop an argument on the nature of the Bills themselves; he should merely say why they should be postponed.

—I suppose, thanks to Senator Bishop, that I was given the opportunity during Question Time to spell out the policy issues. So, I have referred to them in some detail already. I hope, firstly, that when the Opposition comes back with its amendments it manages to get them right in the sense that they will say what the Opposition wants them to say. That would be in marked contrast to what the Opposition did last time. Secondly, I put it to the Australian Democrats: how could they vote for an amendment which will favour investment by Australian superannuation funds in foreign companies instead of Australian companies; which favours debt instruments, instead of equity; which favours investment in central business districts and other real estate instead of investment in productive enterprise; and, above all, which would induce superannuation funds to go into joint ventures instead of taking corporate equity, thereby escaping any taxing point and eroding-probably at an accelerating rate-the corporate tax base? The Government's position on those amendments has been made perfectly clear and I trust we can at least deal with the legislation before we rise tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In seeking to postpone this debate, Senator Walsh has indulged in his usual vitriolic abuse as distinct from substance. It is interesting to point out that the Government has had 12 months in which to consider this legislation; senators have had only days to come to terms with it since its introduction into this place from the House of Representatives. It is interesting to note that the Government has tax drafting experts instructed by high level officers from the Australian Taxation Office to do this kind of work. It is not easy, and it is not getting any easier, with the complicated legislation which this Government chooses to bring in, to have amendments dealt with in a short, easy and accurate manner. It is interesting that in the lower House the same amendments were moved and, at no point, did the Government draw attention to the so-called technical deficiency.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to ask Senator Walsh two questions: Firstly, when did the Government discover these impediments and when did Senator Walsh personally find out about them? Secondly, did he merely choose not to do anything about them until last Thursday night because it was a good, technical debating technique not to encourage good and honest debate but, in his usual cynical way, somehow to disrupt debate and not bring good legislation into this place? The Clerks of the Parliament have had to consult draftsmen for the simple reason that these areas are so complex and the Government so devious that there is an absolute need to use experts from outside this Parliament. I repeat: the Government has had high level expert officers in the Taxation Office to advise it, yet it could not pick up the so-called technical flaw until after 10 o'clock last Thursday evening.

It is just not good enough, Minister. It is not good enough for the Government to have 12 months in which to draft legislation and then, at the end of the session, to rush it through the House of Representatives and introduce it into the Senate. The Government thinks that it can bluff its way through. It was too smart by half by not bringing anybody's attention to the so-called flaw.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order, Senator Bishop! Will you please address your remarks through the Chair.

—Mr Deputy President, the good Minister asked why it was that we did not support the Democrats' amendments last Thursday night. We did not do so for a good and reasonable reason. Very simply, Senator Walsh chose, in his remarks to the Democrats' amendments and our amendments, to raise a point that we could not authenticate. It could have been that the Minister was, in his wily way, introducing yet another red herring. We had no evidence with which to establish that what he said was in any way accurate. Because of the nature of the way in which the Minister deals with matters in this chamber, nobody can be blamed for believing that there might not be substance in his allegations about the technical flaw. Nor did we know at that stage, even if he were correct, whether the Democrats' amendments would address that so-called technical flaw. Accordingly, the decision was taken that we ought not support the Democrats' amendments, that they would be better dealt with if deliberate attention were given to them. That is the situation which we are in now and that is why the Minister is seeking to have the legislation dealt with at a different time. That is the one sensible decision which has come out of this debate so far.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HAINES
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats cannot see any point in delaying debate on this legislation. Delay will cause only additional problems for the industry. Our position has been, and still is, perfectly clear. We spoke to the Government last July about our concerns. I have taken on board Senator Walsh's oft repeated comments about debt versus equity, and he is certainly right in his interpretation of our concerns. But here we were faced with a situation where one principle that we supported, namely, encouraging Australian life and superannuation funds to invest in Australian companies rather than going offshore, was running slap into another concern, namely that, contrary to the comments of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that nobody would be one cent worse off under this legislation, large numbers of people who had taken early retirement and rolled over their superannuation payouts into fixed interest funds would be several thousand dollars worse off over the next couple of years.

SPEECH.PARA: We told the Government last July that, if we could quarantine those people, it would get its earnings tax on the other funds. We told the Government that in July; we told it that in August; we told it every month through until we rose in December, and we told it again this year. The Government broke off discussions last week, presumably because it thought that the Opposition would go to water, as it had already done on the health reinsurance fund and on the wheat legislation, to say nothing of voting against its own amendments on the privacy legislation last year. So I guess there was some justification for the Government not undertaking any discussions with the Australian Democrats with regard to ensuring that those people who had rolled over their generally small lump sum superannuation payments into fixed interest funds would not be disadvantaged. The fact is that by their very nature fixed interest funds are not in a position to take advantage of imputation and, therefore, the people who had invested in those funds would be worse off.

What the Government essentially is saying is that people will be disadvantaged for being safety conscious, for wanting their lump sums to be protected for their post-retirement income. It is no good the Government saying that those people should go into capital guaranteed funds. Many of those have a 40 per cent exposure to the share market. I can see no real reason for us to delay this legislation. Either there is a principle involved in not dealing harshly with people who put security first, or there is not. If there is, the Government will accept our amendments to quarantine those people aged 55 and over who have already put their lump sum payments into those funds. If the Government does that, that is the end of the matter. There will be no need to proceed with any amendment from the Opposition, regardless of its merit as far as drafting is concerned.

The simple matter that we are concerned about is that, if it is possible to give life and superannuation funds the incentive to invest in Australian companies instead of going offshore, while at the same time protecting the investment of those people who have chosen safety over risk and who, after early retirement, have put their funds into fixed interest funds, that is the way we should go. That is what this place and this Parliament are here for. It would certainly keep the Treasurer to his promise that nobody would be a dollar worse off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to intervene in this debate in part because of the attack which the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, made upon the Opposition, which is wrong in fact and, in many respects, quite unfounded, but also because I want to place on the record a request to the Government that might enable us to deal with this complex and important legislation in a more orderly and satisfactory way. The problems that the Parliament faces at the moment and that are now faced by the life insurance industry and potentially by some citizens simply flow back to the Government's tendency to legislate by press release.

SPEECH.PARA: We have here a complex set of proposals announced not by the introduction of legislation but by the issue of a statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), followed by about a year's delay before the details of those changes were put before the Parliament and hence before the Australian people and the industry. When the Treasurer made his statement in May 1988, it was immediately made clear by the Opposition that it had reservations about the Government's proposals. This is one of the points where Senator Walsh was inaccurate in what he said a few minutes ago. Within 48 hours of the Treasurer's statement, the honourable member for Bradfield, Mr Connolly, pointed out that, whilst the Treasurer had claimed that no-one would be worse off, in fact it was extremely likely that individual Australians would be worse off.

Mr Connolly expanded on that in a speech that he made on 26 July 1988 at a seminar run by Price Waterhouse Urwick. The speech was released and I understand that it received some publicity. Mr Connolly pointed out that the Treasurer's statement that no-one would be worse off was not accurate and that the new taxation arrangements would fall heaviest on blue-collar workers, skilled tradesmen and small business people trying to provide for their retirement income. I remind the Minister that the important point that was made by Mr Connolly at that time was under the heading `Passage of Budget Bills' when he said:

The Opposition parties have respected the right of government to pass through Parliament key elements of its Budget package. While we continue to support this principle, let there be no doubt that the Liberal and National parties would expect the appropriate superannuation legislation to meet the letter of the Treasurer's unambiguous commitment that `the new taxation measures would not reduce an individual end benefit pay-out by one cent'.
Mr Connolly went on to say:

If he is unable to meet this commitment, or make the necessary amendments to ensure that he does, the government has no right to expect that the Opposition will support automatically the easy passage of this legislation through the Parliament. We will not be a party to perpetrating a fraud on the Australian people.

It has never been the Opposition's position that this was legislation that it was not entitled to amend. After it had taken the Government a year to produce this complex package of legislation, and after it had given the Opposition a few days in which to respond to it, the Opposition moved an amendment in the House of Representatives which made it clear that it was seeking to threaten only one of the four taxation elements of this package.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true; you have two amendments which would do that.
—The amendments were referred to by Senator Bishop in the question she asked Senator Walsh today. The Opposition has been seeking from the Government information and advice--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order, Senator Walsh!

—Senator Walsh should understand that, whilst everybody in the Senate is tired, not everyone feels able to give rein to his or her irritability in the way that Senator Walsh feels able to do. If we are to deal with this complex legislation in a satisfactory way, it will require a bit of self-control on his part. The point is, as I think eventually Senator Walsh conceded in his response to the supplementary question put to him, that the Opposition amendments do not touch the major source of finance that flows from this legislation, the tax which is imposed on the payments which are made--
—Not in the short term.

—The Minister intervenes `not in the short term'. The fact is that it is quite clear that the Minister and the Government would have estimates from the Treasury and from other officials as to how this alleged $1.4 billion, which will be raised by the superannuation package, is made up. It is the clear view of the Opposition that the amendment that we are moving touches a relatively small part of the revenue raised by these Bills. It would assist the public understanding of this legislation if, before the Bills come back for debate, the Minister were to make the facts clear instead of suggesting, as he did last Friday and which resulted in a lot of newspaper publicity, that the Opposition was in some way putting under threat a whole lot of things, including the taxation treatment of lump sum payments which have already been received since this legislation was announced, the deductability of superannuation payments which have been made in excess of $1,500 by the self-employed and so on. The Minister knows that the Opposition's amendments do not touch those matters. If the Minister was being honest in the matter he would have said, `If the Opposition succeeds in amending this relatively small part of the legislation-which we do not like because we say it destroys the symmetry of the legislation-we, the Government, will as a matter of pique refuse to pass the rest of the legislation'. This will impose terrible penalties on half a million Australians and will cause great administrative inconvenience to those life insurance companies which have geared up their operations in line with the announcements made by the Government in a statement over a year ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is approaching the Senate on the basis of putting political pressure on us not to do our duty. The Government says that the Senate should not be permitted to review this legislation or to make any suggestions because, if it does, the Government will take its bat and ball home and impose great hardship on a whole series of individuals in the community. That is an unworthy and stupid approach on the part of the Government. I hope that the Minister might reconsider it. The Opposition will insist on a proper consideration of its amendments in a cool and reasonable way so that a proper judgment on the public interest can be made and so that the public are able to make the same judgment.

I refer now to what Mr Connolly has said was an error in the amendment that was moved in the House of Representatives-an amendment which has been in the hands of the Government for some time and which, according to Senator Walsh in his interjection, he did not know about until last Thursday when the legislation was debated. This is very complex legislation. The Opposition has had amendments prepared by the parliamentary draftsman, Mr Geoff Harders. I am advised by Mr Connolly that Mr Harders's advice is that, due to the complexity of the Bills, he cannot guarantee that the amendments would withstand the most intense scrutiny and that it would take a week's work to give that sort of guarantee. It is notorious that under this Government tax legislation in this country has become virtually unintelligible. Tax accountants are unable to keep track of it. Lawyers find it difficult in the extreme to be sure that they are dealing with the law in any definite way because of its volume and complexity. The Government is indulging in pathetic and base games in this Parliament to ignore those very real difficulties and to make, as the Minister did last Friday, serious misrepresentations of what the Opposition was doing. I do not blame the media who misreported this issue. It is good that the Age newspaper at least managed to get behind the Minister's farrago and to report the matter accurately. This legislation is beyond the comprehension of most tax lawyers and accountants. The Minister misrepresented the Opposition by suggesting that a lot of evil results would flow from the Opposition's amendment when, in fact, those evil results flow from the Government's decision, if taken, that an amendment to a relatively small part of this legislation would lead to the whole legislation being withheld-not by the Opposition but by the Government. Retirement incomes are of fundamental importance to everybody in Australia. There is intense interest in the community, not just among those who are nearly retired but also among those who are looking at a lifetime of work ahead of them, to know what the situation is with respect to their eventual retirement benefits. This Government is making superannuation somewhat less attractive by the additional revenue that it is taking out of the system and the additional taxes that it is imposing. It is doing this in a way which is proving to be complex and confusing for the industry and for superannuants. It is now expecting the Parliament to deal with those matters in a peremptory way and is then criticising the Opposition for the difficulties we face. It is a pathetic failure of responsibility on the part of the Government to legislate properly and to give this Parliament a chance to do its duty.

I think Senator Walsh's demeanour during Question Time and during the debate this afternoon is an indication that it is not a matter of suggesting that Senator Bishop should not be dealing with this legislation on behalf of the Opposition. It is time that someone with a slightly calmer temperament, and a greater sense of the public interest than Senator Walsh appears to have today, was put in charge of this legislation. I never thought I would invite Senator Bolkus to assume these responsibilities, but I ask him to do so, since he is the Minister at the table, so that a Minister who is capable of being a little more rational and sensible in these matters can look after them.

We have a large legislative program. Senator Walsh, by his performance, has again led us to take more time than any of us would have wished to go through the procedure of having this legislation stood over for a time so that it can be dealt with properly. I formally repeat my request that, rather than engage in the sort of nonsense that we have seen in this chamber, the Minister should make available--

TALK.START.PARA: —I will pass that on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the telecommunications package of Bills, a very significant package but ultimately one that is very disappointing because it represents the outcome of high expectations created by this Government. The statement which the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, delivered on 25 May 1988 states:

SPEECH.PARA: In describing the Government's third-term agenda, the Prime Minister has given greatest emphasis to micro-economic policy: the structural adjustment of key industries, and the relationships between them, with a view to establishing and sustaining longer term growth . . .
The Australian telecommunications services industry is well placed to make a major contribution to these goals of efficiency and trade competitiveness in the information economy . . .
The second reading speech of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) is in like vein. It states:

. . . the Government released a policy statement . . . was an integral part of the Government's third term micro-economic agenda, which emphasised the need to improve the efficiency of our economic infrastructure . . .

The Australian telecommunications industry is of strategic importance to both the manufacturing and service sectors of the Australian economy. It is a key to export led growth. The importance of information industries in the world economy is growing. The world's telecommunications market is currently estimated at around $400 billion per annum, more than computing, pharmaceuticals or air travel. The Australian market is about 2.5 per cent of the world market or $10 billion. Australia's telecommunications industry must be established on a sound and efficient basis, so that it can adapt to changing technologies and user needs. This will contribute to Australia's ability to compete effectively in the rapidly growing world market.

That is the sort of high rhetoric that accompanies this package. One might reasonably expect that the Government would have delivered the goods, but sadly that is not so. Perhaps the high watermark of rhetoric was delivered by the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, Mrs Kelly, who was reported in the Australian Financial Review of 15 May last as saying:
I think we are on the verge of revolutionising the telecommunications industry in this country.

If Mrs Kelly was talking about this package of Bills she was deluding herself; she was certainly not deluding the Australian community. The reality is that what will be in place once this package of Bills goes through is perhaps the most conservative and regulated telecommunications environment amongst developed countries in the Western world. One does not have to look just at New Zealand, which is probably the high water mark of deregulation. Indeed, one can understand the desperation that drives the Labor Government in that country to throw open the floodgates. But, if one looks around the world, one finds that the rest of the world is moving rapidly into a competitive environment whilst Australia is locked firmly into the monopoly mould. Japan, the United States of America and the United Kingdom all made strategic decisions at least five years ago to enter into a brave new world of competition, and they are reaping the rewards. Now we find that even the European Community, with 1992 in mind, is very much concerned to deregulate. It has decided that the monopoly presently available to the postal, telegraph and telephone utilities, PTTs, should be confined to switched voice, and should not include data and text. Indeed, the American situation since divestiture in 1984 has shown dramatic growth. There are now three long distance carriers competing frantically amongst themselves: American Telephone and Telegraph, with about 70 per cent of the market; MCI with about 10 per cent; and Sprint with about 8 to 10 per cent. They are all thriving, as indeed are the hundreds of local telecommunications companies and all 22 of the regional Bell operating companies. It is quite clear that Americans are reaping the benefits of those dramatic changes. The Business/Finance section of the International Herald Tribune of 23 May last, states:
Long distance is the growth industry of the 1990s, and we have only just begun to scratch the surface.

Deregulation brought in some five years ago, has seen the three leading American long distance telephone companies finding that business is booming. Rates for calls are steadily dropping and the demand is exploding for such services as toll-free 800 numbers-
that is 008 in our language-
computer data lines, facsimile transmission and international calling.
The number of long-distance transmissions in the United States, both domestic and international, has increased 46 per cent in the past five years.

The fibre-optic lines owned by the phone companies are being used by an increasing number of corporations and financial institutions to transmit huge amounts of data domestically and overseas. A five-minute day-time call from New York to Los Angeles costs $1.26, down from $2.70 five years ago. Facsimile machines are turning up everywhere. In two years, the number of these machines in the United States has doubled, to an estimated one million units. With rates down about 40 per cent since the break-up of the Bell system in 1984, residential customers are dialling outside their area codes more frequently than every before. Analysts predict that long-distance revenues, which reached $50 billion in 1988, are expected to approach $60 billion this year, up from $33 billion in 1984 . . .

It is quite clear that the explosion in the United States has not seen any deterioration in the financial situation of those companies operating in the long distance markets. Quite the contrary, there has been an enormous expansion of demand, which they are meeting. It is clear that competition in the United States has delivered significant benefits to the community. A duopoly in the United Kingdom has been in place for some five years. The result is that British Telecom (BT) still has about 95 per cent of the market, but Mercury as a niche marketer is increasing competition in the central business district of London and the major provincial cities. It is quite clear that Mercury will continue to expand and put pressure on BT, particularly to bring down its rates. Anyone who understands anything about contestable market theory will know that even the mere threat of the entry of a new carrier can often be sufficient to drive those rates down towards market levels. Japan similarly has four or five long distance carriers, all thriving despite the fact that NTT is by far the dominant carrier and occupies in excess of 95 per cent of the market. But again, its rates are being forced down by its smaller competitors.

If we look at Europe and at the major industrialised countries of the Western world, we find that they are all in the process of liberalising their markets. Sweden and the United Kingdom are about to liberalise resale and shared use of circuits this month. Sweden already has a second cellular mobile phone service provider, a second international operator. Most other developed countries have at least two cellular mobile telephone service providers. What does Australia have? As a result of this package, Australia will have the greatest degree of formal protection ever provided to a dominant carrier. In many senses this package of legislation, particularly the Telecommunications Bill, can be described as the Telecom monopoly preservation package. The package does that. Whilst it purports to define the monopoly areas for the Overseas Telecommunications Corporation (OTC) and Aussat Pty Ltd, they are defined in terms which protect Telecom. That is the tragedy of this whole package, because Telecom does not need that protection. Telecom is a very aggressive and effective competitor. It is a lion locked in a cage of the Government's own making. If it were able to roam the competitive jungles, I have no doubt at all that it would thrive. But because this Government is driven by an unholy desire to pander to the left wing of the Australian Labor Party, the anti-privateers, those members of Caucus who live in rural areas and a whole range of nervous nellies, the end result is that it is not prepared to recognise the competitive advantages that every other country is increasingly acknowledging.

Where are we? In the world context we are in company with countries such as Turkey, Greece and Portugal, all of which are, in effect, developing countries, although in the European Community. They have penetration rates of about 50 per cent of households, whereas our rate is about 94 per cent. So those countries can perhaps be excused until such time as they get to the point where they have effectively household saturation. We were at that point perhaps as recently as 1970, but there has been an enormous change since that time. Particularly in the last 10 years there has been an explosion of telecommunication services and a rapid dismantling of protective barriers. But this Government chooses to put its head in the sand and ignore all of those developments.

That is a tragedy not just for the industry, not just for Telecom, but for the Australian community, because it is quite clear in my view that Telecom would prosper in a highly competitive environment. Telecom has a very good board, a very competent and capable chief executive officer, who has recently been reappointed, and it has a number of very senior people who would be able to take advantage of the enormous market opportunities which would open up if it were placed in a competitive environment.

It is really very disappointing to find that the sorts of specious arguments that are used to justify the retention and expansion of Telecom's monopoly derive from the so-called May statement of 1988, which I find internally inconsistent in its logic and in many ways perhaps so conservative as to be unbelievable. I will give a couple of examples, because it is the May statement which drives this Bill. Paragraph 3.7 states:
There are two fundamental considerations in determining appropriate boundaries to the monopoly areas. First, the infrastructure itself, or certain parts of it, may-
I emphasise the word `may'-
possess `natural monopoly' attributes as a result of pervasive economies of scale and scope.

Well, the natural monopoly argument is totally discredited in this area. It may have had some validity prior to the advent of optical fibre, but the reality is that no other country recognises the validity of the natural monopoly, and nor does the Australian Government or its advisers have the temerity to suggest that is does; it simply `may'. It continues:

In these circumstances, any competing provision could lead to long-term inefficiency, in the form of excess capacity and the uneconomic duplication of facilities. In addition, relying on market forces to resolve infrastructure issues may have other undesirable outcomes . . .

3.8 Secondly, competitive provision of certain services may be inconsistent with the Government objective of maintaining and extending universal service, in the sense of ensuring broad access to telecommunications throughout the national territory and to all sections of the community. This inconsistency arises from the pursuit of universal access through a price structure that contains extensive cross-subsidies, both between and within services, that may not be sustainable in an unregulated commercial market.

That is a disgrace. In terms of logic and commonsense, the Government and its advisers do not have the courage even to make these assertions without pathetic qualifications. These are to be put as a collection of shibboleths to pander to those in the Government who are not game to bite the bullet. I do not include the Senator Walterses of this world in that category. It is quite clear with the statements that have been made, even by the very cautious and conservative Mr Willis, that he has now seen the light, that he has joined the bulk of the economic rationalists in the Cabinet who acknowledge not just the need but the imperative for competition to drive government business enterprises. That is the only way one can guarantee effective and efficient outcomes. One really has to ask why a document such as this is couched in such careful and cautious tones. Why are there all these caveats? They are there for political reasons only.

This document is riddled with justifications for preserving the monopoly based on the need to preserve Telecom's community service obligations. What is the cost of those community service obligations? Telecom's revenue last year exceeded $8 billion. Its profit was up 19 per cent, to $776.2m. Telecom will be flat out keeping that profit figure below $1 billion in the next few weeks. It only achieved that figure below $1 billion last year because of some pretty fancy accounting techniques which managed to turn depreciation on motor vehicles, plant and equipment the preceding year from $25m to a figure in excess of $350m. In other words, Telecom's profit figure last year should have been about $1.3 billion. Unless it manages to discover any more creative accounting approaches, it will be of that order this year.

We are talking about a gigantic enterprise-whose staff is about three times the size of the Australian Army and which has operations about twice the size of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-somehow needing some protection from the rest of the world, the rest of the Australian community, and all those others who are desperate to get into the game. What is the cost of those community service obligations? We simply do not know. We know that in 1982 Davidson said that he could not get to the bottom of the figure and recommended that an accounting inquiry be conducted. Telecom did not want to take that hint so it was left to Ergas in 1987 to say that, similarly, he found it very difficult to get to the bottom of the figures.

So we limped on to the May statement which, of course, arose after nine months of intensive effort on the part of a task force consisting of a range of experts in the community, all of whom had very good credentials for making judgments about these matters. What did that task force then discover about the cost of community service obligations (CSOs)? This is what came out in the May statement, at paragraph 3.40:

It is not clear how much economic loss actually arises from the current pattern of cross-subsidisation . . . it is not possible to sufficiently disentangle separate service costs within Telecom's present management information and accounting system to enable a reliable calculation of the costs or levels of these cross-subsidies or to enable proper consideration of possible alternative service-delivery arrangements.

Telecom's figure to the task force was $670m. The task force's official estimate was an alternative figure of $250m. What was the outcome? The May statement said that the Government would commission the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics to conduct its own survey, with the assistance of Telecom, and report to the Government by January of this year. It is now June and that report still has not been presented. I think that the Government is now finding itself in an intolerable position trying to defend its decision to keep the results of that survey private. I think it will now be forced to publish that figure. As a result, it is now desperately trying to inflate the figure. My suspicion is that the figure is something in the order of $200m, which would be consistent with the official finding referred to by the task force. It probably goes a long way to explaining why it has taken so long for the task force's report to surface at all.

In order to be taken into account in the corporate plan which Telecom will have to provide to the Minister in the not too distant future, it is very important indeed that he have that figure as well. It is even more important that he should follow the practice of Australian National, formerly the Australian National Railways, which publishes its corporate plan, of Sweden's Televerket, which publishes both its level of CSOs and its corporate plan. I hope that the Government will have the good sense to come clean on those items. Unless it does, it will be fuelling the inevitable conclusion that one must reach, that the cost of Telecom's CSOs and the level of cross-subsidies is pretty small beer-nowhere near sufficient to justify the range of monopoly protections contained in this package.

It is an absolute disgrace to find that the Caucus liaison committee, the anti-privateers, the Public Service unions and that whole clutch of conservatives on the other side of the chamber were able to succeed not only in protecting the basic network as a monopoly but also in going beyond that point so that non-core services such as public switched data services and public switched text and video are also getting protection. Why should public mobile telephone services be protected? The May statement is flat out justifying that. It is quite clear from the verbal contortions that the task force itself thought that that should be a competitive service.

Now Austel will have to review the situation but I do not have any confidence that that will emerge into competition in the near future. Looking at leased circuit services, again Sweden and the United Kingdom are prepared to allow competition in those areas, but they are heavily protected. Again there is no reason why integrated service digital network should be protected. Why on earth should public telephones be protected in this country? They can be provided by others quite simply and cheaply. A whole range of alternative cabinets and telephones can be made available. There can be minimum requirements for locations so that those who need telephones in particular areas, such as rural areas, can be assured of easy access. There is absolutely no reason at all why we need to have a monopoly on those services any more than on CT2s, or telepoints, when the Government eventually gets around to allowing them to proliferate.

We find here a very cautious and conservative document. We welcome the establishment of Austel. Austel has a whole range of charter obligations, but nowhere does one find an obligation to act in a pro-competitive manner. As far as this Government is concerned, Austel is about protecting the Telecom monopoly, defining the boundaries and making sure that no-one infringes them. I regard that as a very negative and inward looking approach. The first phone monopoly is another outrageous monopoly protected area. While the Government pays lip service to the need for a review by June of 1991, it is quite clear that, despite costs to the Australian consumer of the order of $250m, the unions will not have a bar of that being made open to competitive and enterprising technicians as occurs in many other countries. So we have a very heavily protected new environment, one that is at odds with the approach adopted in the rest of the world. We also find that there is a whole new system of licence arrangements for value added services, for private network services and customer cabling. Most of those are unnecessary. They are bureaucratic responses which are, in a sense, a self-justification. They provide the opportunity to raise fees on the time-honoured principle that where you see a service you tax it. They will then become self-fulfilling, perhaps even to the point where they start to raise revenue for the Government.

The alternative approach would have been much simpler, cheaper and more effective-to give Austel the power to seek an injunction to restrain any potential infringement, to prosecute and to require that damages be paid if there is any infringement. But no, the alternative approach has been adopted where anyone seeking to vary a class licence has to get permission not only from Austel but effectively from Telecom because it has to be put in the picture at the outset. That raises very serious concerns about competition because it clearly puts Telecom in a position to become aware of any new developments or new technological devices.

I do not have any confidence in the Chinese wall; I do not see any reason at all why Telecom should have that privileged position and premature access to information. Austel's charter, if it is allowed to operate in the way that the Government has promised and not in the way that the structural adjustment committee would like it to operate-and that is, by reducing its budget by the order of $1m and reducing its staff from 70 to 58-will still be swamped by a whole set of technical requirements. It will not be spending much time on policy issues. Even if it does, the Minister has power to give directions to absolutely emasculate it if it ever gets out of line. I have a great deal of confidence that Robin Davey, the Chairman designate of Austel, will bring a degree of intellectual rigour to the task of ensuring that Telecom does not get a free ride. But I fear the worst, particularly with Mr Willis. If there is any indication that Austel might be flexing its muscles or that Telecom might be brought back to the field, I fear that the Government will give directions to expand Telecom's community service obligations, as a specious justification, in the way that the Commission for the Future set out to do before it got kicked to death. I would hope that the Government will not give any such directions, but again I have no confidence that that will be the case.

There is a series of subsidiary Bills which are also relevant to Telecom. There is one in relation to Australia Post which again simply expands the ambit of Australia Post's operations-the fines, the letter monopoly-in a way that I regard as unnecessary. It gives it opportunities to expand its services into couriers and mail houses, which are quite amply serviced by the private sector. Australia Post should be required to publish its CSOs. Indeed, Austel's obligations should extend to supervising Australia Post in due course.

There are a number of areas where the Government has simply come up with a whole new series of formulae designed to disguise the fact that this is a bureaucratic and anti-competitive solution to the need for change in the telecommunications industry. Consumer price index minus X, the price factor, may well be some degree of improvement on rate of return regulation, but at the end of the day it is not a free market answer. It does not do anything more than pay lip service to the need for competition. Indeed, the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) recently found that Telecom's total factor productivity over the last decade has been of the order of 5.4 per cent per annum. So it is quite clear that Telecom could have accommodated a `factor X' of at least 5 per cent. But no, the Government has again cosseted it from reality and competition by giving it a 4 per cent figure.

The IAC's draft report on international trade in services quotes, and presumably therefore endorses, the Australian Institute for Public Policy claim that the efficiency of Telecom is about 20 per cent below that of its Canadian counterpart and that $250m is a conservative estimate of the welfare cost of Telecom's pricing policies. It also mentions the fact that Telecom milks OTC quite unjustifiably to the tune of about $60m to $70m for charges that it levies supposedly for administration expenses, for billing OTC customers, when in fact the cost would be well below $10m. It does that by charging fees as the rate of either 21c or 31c a minute for the connection of long distance calls when they should not be charged at any more than the local call rate.

In passing, it is of interest that the Prices Surveillance Authority has today disallowed Australia Post's application for an increase and has deferred any further consideration of the matter for at least two months. I regard this package as worthy of deferral because it does not address any of the fundamental issues. It will not do anything to enhance Australia's competitiveness. It will not give Telecom the opportunity to get out there and compete on the world stage in the way that it is more than capable of doing. It will simply encourage Telecom to try to knock off Aussat wherever possible, to try to get into joint ventures to pre-empt competition in the private sector wherever possible and to go on justifying its whole range of indefensible monopoly areas on the specious basis of community service obligations.

The sooner the figure is out in the public domain the better, because we will then realise that, if necessary, Telecom could absorb that figure without any form of compensation. Even if it were to be provided with compensation, there are mechanisms that would be readily available to ensure that there was no reduction in services in rural areas or, indeed, no reduction in prices. That can be done simply by capturing those technological gains that are readily available and, hopefully, some of the productivity gains that this Government refuses to force on Telecom, particularly in the customer access network.

So at the end of the day what we have is a very disappointing response to a very dynamic environment. We have a recipe for conservatism and so-called efficiency at the expense of the real virtues of competition and a failure to come to grips with what is happening in the rest of the world. It is a politics driven solution to a very important business problem where costs are increasingly becoming important in export competition terms. All that we find here is a recipe for driving those costs up as much as possible.

I conclude by saying that the creation of Austel is about the only worthwhile outcome from this package. Austel's prospects of success are very much in the balance. I do not believe that it will get any sympathy or support from the Government if it tries to step out of line. At the end of the day, what we will find is a telecommunications industry that will be waiting for the day when there is a change of government when it and Telecom and the other carriers can truly enjoy the virtues of real competition. In regard to the Australian Telecommunications Corporations, Bill 1989, I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate criticises the Government for its failure to specify or detail the exact nature or extent of the community services obligations of Telecom''.
In regard to the Telecommunications Bill 1989, I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate notes:
(a) the Government's failure to introduce meaningful deregulation of, and competition into, the Australian telecommunications industry; and
(b) that while the monopolies proposed for the Telecommunications Carriers are based on the needs for cross subsidies to deliver on community service obligations:
(i) the Government has nevertheless failed to specify or detail the exact nature or extent of the community service obligations of Telecom; and
(ii) no community service obligations are imposed on OTC or AUSSAT Pty Ltd so that there is no justification for OTC or AUSSAT remaining wholly in public ownership''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of telecommunications Bills has been promoted as one of the most significant reforms in Australian telecommunications since the formation of Telecom Australia in 1975. We all have our views on that. I suggest to the Senate that Senator Alston, on behalf of the Liberal-National coalition, would like to gut at least Telecom. The Government is simply after a few entrails by way of this package. On the other hand the Australian Democrats would like to see Telecom as a healthy, vitalised body and a major player in the telecommunications revolution which has already started in this information era.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Senate will be aware, the package arises from the Government's May 1988 statement called Australian Telecommunications Services: A New Framework, which was itself the product of a major review of telecommunications policy. I think it is worth paying some attention to that statement. In his foreword to the statement, the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, noted the Government's emphasis on micro-economic policy reform-the structural readjustment of industry with a view to establishing and sustaining longer term growth. The statement emphasised goals of efficiency and competitiveness, balanced with the important social objectives associated with the central role of the telephone in the Australian community. More particularly, the policy articulated a number of objectives for its telecommunications policy. Those objectives were as follows: firstly, to ensure universal access to standard telephone services throughout Australia on an equitable basis and at affordable prices, in recognition of the social importance of these services; secondly, to maximise the efficiency of the publicly owned telecommunications enterprises, Telecom, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) and Aussat Pty Ltd, in meeting their objectives, including fulfilment of special community service obligations and the generation of appropriate returns on investment; thirdly, to ensure the highest possible levels of accountability and responsiveness to customer and community needs on the part of the telecommunications enterprises; fourthly, to provide the capacity to achieve optimal rates of expansion and modernisation of the telecommunications system, including the introduction of new and diverse services; fifthly, to enable all elements of the Australian telecommunications industry-manufacturing, services, information provision-to participate effectively in the rapidly growing Australian and world telecommunications markets; and, sixthly, to promote the development of other sectors of the economy through the commercial provision of a full range of modern telecommunications services at the lowest possible prices.

Some of the statement's policy directives were implemented on 1 January this year, but major changes have really had to wait for translation into this legislation and, in particular, for the new administrative body, the Australian Telecommunications Authority, or Austel, to take over the present regulatory functions of Telecom. Upon the passage of the earlier legislation, the Australian Democrats went on record as being quite disturbed that the steps that were taken initially last year were taken without Austel being in place. We welcome this aspect of the legislation most warmly. I will have some more to say about that in a few moments.

No-one would argue that the implications of this package for both business and consumers, in what is a technologically complex and rapidly evolving industry, are quite enormous. In addition, the pressures emerging from each of these areas are in conflict in some respects and, as I said earlier, this is reflected in the postures adopted earlier by the different political parties in this place. The Government has deregulated as far as it dares at this stage. As we have heard in the past, and no doubt will hear again in the future, the Opposition wants to go much further down the deregulatory path-more and more so under the privatising hand of Senator Alston. The Australian Democrats want to ensure that this major public utility is recognised and protected as such and is structured in a way that efficiency is promoted and the interests of consumers and the general public are properly served.

While it is inevitable that no perfect solution can be found-and this package certainly needs clarification in a number of areas-the Democrats believe that the new regime will go a long way towards ensuring faster and clearer decision-making on new services and equal treatment for competing telecommunications service providers. Telecom's business competitors will no doubt take issue with that assessment on our behalf, but the operation of private networks and the ability to compete in value added services are extended under the deregulation in this legislation.

At this point I would like to outline the key elements of the major Bill, the Telecommunications Bill, which are central to the whole package. They are: the establishment of the Australian Telecommunications Authority, Austel, as the telecommunications industry regulator, with both technical and economic regulatory functions; the definition of those telecommunications services which will, for reasons of network development and social objectives, be reserved to Telecom, OTC and Aussat; the creation of a streamlined licensing regime for other services which, combined with safeguards against discriminatory behaviour by the carriers, will allow free and fair competition in the provision of value added services and the efficient operation of approved private networks; the assurance of fair and open competition in the customer equipment market; and the provision of mechanisms to ensure that consumer interests are protected and the Government's social objectives achieved by the telecommunications industry.

From every point of view in that important range of measures the role of Austel is absolutely critical. As the new industry regulator outside the ambit of the carriers, Austel's operations will have a far-reaching impact on both the competition and consumer protection aspects of telecommunications in this country. We have a prospective chairman in Robin Davey. It is of concern to the Australian Democrats that the two further major appointments to be made in the two deputy chairmen must cover the full range of responsibilities, interests and expertise which will achieve all the policy directions outlined by the Government, particularly the consumer protection aspects about which we are so concerned. I will have a little more to say about that later.

Austel is expected to have about 70 people on its staff and will be closely involved in all aspects of the industry-from regulation, policing the monopoly rights of the big players to ensure that legitimate competition is not crushed, to setting standards for equipment to be attached to the communications network. One of Austel's prime roles-this is of particular concern to the Australian Democrats-is that of a consumer watchdog, monitoring and reporting on the performance of the carriers in their delivery of reserved services. Part of this role encompasses the administration of the Government's formula for price capping basic services to ensure that the average price of a basket of basic telecommunications services will fall in real terms. Effective price control is high on the agenda of the Australian Democrats' concerns, as it has been for the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations and others representing the interests of consumers. As this legislation is dealt with, we want to emphasise that Australia must avoid the problems which arose in Britain when its Oftel, the equivalent of Austel was set up and which took four years to correct.

Assurances were given in the May 1988 statement and I will be seeking specific comments from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade during the committee stage following last week's announcement of the formula. It has been a disappointment to some of us that we are looking at the price capping system with one basket comprising the formula. Given that the Government has made that decision, we believe that close scrutiny must be the order of the day. Voices from outside Austel will be heard where there is concern or if it looks as though we are getting into some of the problems which were experienced in the United Kingdom. If necessary, measures should be taken to redress the situation earlier than in the three-year time frame set. We do have the experience to guide us and we will be calling on the Government to use that experience and to ensure that we do not get into significant problems in this country.

Austel also has the responsibility of reporting to government on Telecom's performance in meeting its community service obligations, including its responsibility to provide universal service and other socially necessary services, such as public telephones. It has been noted by more than one commentator that there is a growing realisation of the centrality of telecommunications in many aspects of social and economic life. This was acknowledged by the then Minister in his May 1988 statement.

The Australian Government is not the only government to have undertaken a major review of the communications sector, motivated by the very many new technological developments and the enormous potential for more. In fact, late last month I attended a Commission for the Future conference in Melbourne. It was quite clear from many of the presentations that public perceptions about this issue are quite extensive. At one presentation in particular verbal information was given to people at the workshop concerning the pilot stage of a very important research project which is currently being undertaken by Telecom. The presentation pointed out that public perceptions about the role of Telecom and, in particular, its community service obligations were really probably much further ahead of most politicians' perceptions of the public's view.

It is clear that the public's view centres on a number of different areas; first of all on the technical components of the facilities which are involved. The public appears to believe that automatically universal access to local, subscriber trunk dialling (STD) and international subscriber dialling (ISD) facilities ought to be considered as part of the community service obligation. The public also expressed a very high consensus on the fact that itemisation of calls should be a basic component of a fair and efficient telephone service. As a parliamentarian, one of the most frequent complaints I receive, particularly in my role as communications spokesperson for the Democrats, is that itemisation of calls is not available. According to the brief information which we were given on a preliminary basis, this is an issue of high priority in the community. It is also interesting, though, to note in this context that itemisation appears to have been considered to be more important for STD calls than for ISD calls. This reflects something which was also reported on; that is, that as a service is diffused and more widely used in the community it then becomes considered more readily as a service to which there ought to be universal access.

The second area was the service component-people breaking down their approach to telecommunications services and simply saying that they require a fast and efficient service. I do not think that any politician is surprised at that. The third area was access. There seemed to be quite a high consensus of view that value added services of the kind which this legislation is designed to encourage, such as data transmission and so on, ought to be available to everybody who wants or needs it. The feeling in the general public seems to be that access to the newer types of service should be available, but on a user pays basis.

It is interesting-here I refer to a point I made a few moments ago-that as the service becomes more widely used it is apparent that it becomes more generally considered a basic service. Some examples given were some forms of data transmission and in particular the facsimile service. An increasing number of people believe that these sorts of services ought to be considered part of the basic service. It is important to note this in the context of this legislation. In fact, the more a service is widely diffused through the community the more it becomes considered something to which there ought to be universal access-in other words, part of Telecom's community service obligation. These findings are particularly significant because one of the points that the Australian Democrats wish to make most strongly about community service obligations is that we must do nothing in this legislation to prohibit the future possibility that any definition of community service obligations will be able to take account of the changing perceptions in the community.

I interpolate some other comments that were made at the Commission for the Future workshop, which indeed brought together people from the academic sector, the political spectrum and so on in the telecommunications industry. It was said that in the whole consideration of community service obligations and in the context of this upcoming legislation we really need to think differently-from the Democrats' point of view that is a certainty-about these issues than we are, largely anyway, across the political spectrum at the moment. The point was made in general terms, in policy terms, by several people at the conference that-of course, we have just heard one speech by Senator Alston and we will hear one next by Senator Austin Lewis, which will confirm this view-we are in a reductionist era where we are limiting our views of many of these issues and community service obligations no less to the sort of economic side of the question. One speaker at the conference actually referred to that approach as silly. I suggest that it is in fact quite disastrous.

The Democrats say that to determine what ought to be the community service obligation of a public service provider such as Telecom we should establish first what kind of society we want and, in the case of telecommunications specifically, what kind of society we want in the area of telecommunications and information. We should then establish the economic ground rules and indeed establish the economy to provide that kind of society-not the other way around. As we in the Democrats have often said, and will continue to say-and I am delighted that another participant, although not a Democrat, at that conference said-we cannot and must not separate the social, economic and political aspects of issues such as these.

I find it disturbing that, particularly in the past few months and particularly this week here in this place, we have been going through a whole process of altering and, unfortunately we feel, moving towards the dismantling of public service organisations. If there is a change of government there is certainly no question of altering and dismantling public service instrumentalities and institutions-public community service bodies-in this country. What is being offered in their place? Senator Alston and his ilk, when referring to community service obligations made available through cross-subsidy up until now, tell us, `Let the organisation define how much it costs and then let the Government put it up front as a Budget item'-in other words, move away from the community service concept to a welfare service concept. They want the Government and Telecom to say how much it costs to serve country people, poor people, old people and deaf people and then put that figure up front as a welfare service every year as part of the political football of the Budget.

I think that we have to change our ways of thinking in this and a whole lot of other areas. We have to recognise the value of community service. In the case of this legislation specifically we must, as I said before, make sure that we take no action that will limit any possible interpretation or implementation of community service obligations of Telecom or any other public service organisation as the community at that time may wish to define it.

Given the sort of work that is coming out of the pilot project which Telecom has undertaken and which I have referred to briefly, it also seems that politicians need to open their eyes and ears a little more and listen to the public. If they did this they would not be trying to limit those definitions, as they are on both sides of the chamber, but most particularly the Opposition, thereby limiting the service available to all in the community. This is a matter of general concern to the Democrats. As I have said, in this place we are constantly talking about the need for these sorts of public services not to be sold off. The telecommunications industry is one that is burgeoning and one in which a great deal of money is to be made. There is nothing inherently wrong with that but we are saying that, as it develops and as that money is made, no-one in this community should be any less better served and everybody should be able to expect to be better served as time passes and as the telecommunications industry develops.

Going through my files on this issue I came across an article by Ian Davis in the Canberra Times of February last year. He talked about what happens when we let our community service infrastructure break down. Quite early in the article he states:
The roads of the British Empire-as of the Roman empire before it-were not simply well constructed public services . . . they were also a military asset.

He then goes on to point out what happens when public services, which are a vital part of any growing, well balanced economy, break down. It is interesting to note the ones that he refers to. Honourable senators should think of the list:

The breakdown in the sewerage system, which has led to the deterioration of Sydney's magnificent ocean beaches . . . the inability of telephone exchanges . . . to cope with demand for lines at times of peak demand-
This is the sort of problem we are trying to address in this legislation. He continues:
. . . the progressive deterioration of agricultural land in the Murray River basin . . . the lack of an adequate airport in Sydney . . .
He then talks about the problems on the waterfront caused by inadequate facilities. He goes on to talk about Sydney's gas mains and so on. I make this point directly from the article. It states:

. . . characteristic of the infrastructure of an economy is that it exists to support other economic or social activities rather than as an end in itself; that it has a relatively high initial capital cost; relatively long life; and should be managed and paid for on a long-term basis.

That sort of message is one that we really ought to recognise. We are talking about an investment in a public facility and a public utility which is there to serve the people, not there to serve the economy in the first instance.

I would also like to put on the record a comment made again last year by a former chief financial adviser to the Queensland Government, Sir Leo Hielscher. He spoke very strongly against the headlong rush into privatisation. I do so because of that rush, which is now being led from the front bench by Senator Alston and which, if it succeeds, inevitably will be to the detriment of the isolated and the less well-off in our community. Sir Leo said, inter alia:
. . . public bodies should be privatised only if they could better provide the services required.
And you have to remember that if you privatise a government instrumentality, you have to make it much more efficient and much more profitable to achieve an equivalent result . . .
As a private company, it will have to pay tax and then dividends, so it needs to make a lot more profit.

And so the article continued. Those are some of the points which, it appears, the Opposition is all too readily able to ignore. Those comments were made by a very longstanding public servant, having served a Queensland National Party government for many years.

It is significant that the Opposition's main complaint about the legislation is that it does not live up to the rhetoric contained in the May statement and even in some of the commentary, including the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). Having looked closely at the legislation, we take considerable comfort from that fact. It is almost worth saying that it appears to those in the Australian Labor Party who are concerned, as are the Australian Democrats, about the issues of public and community service and access and equity in our democratic system, of which telecommunications is such an integral part, as too is the media-a battle which we have fought and been rolled on by the combined Government and Opposition-that rhetoric is all that has survived since the May statement. We take comfort from that. At the committee stage we will try to pin down some of those elements of the statements vis-a-vis those in the legislation in order to further comfort ourselves and others in the community who are concerned about possible deprivation, possible negative results of the legislation. In general terms, we believe that there has been sufficient movement since the 1988 May statement to introduce legislation, a package of which is before us today and which we have not felt moved to oppose. However, we do need some clarification at the committee stage of a number of areas, particularly the definitions of community service obligations.

We too have been critical, as have others in the community, about the very short time available for comment on the exposure draft of the legislation. While appreciating the process, only a few working days were available to us and others in the community who were concerned about the legislation. While the Government claims wide consultation, and to a degree can justify that claim, it is very important to note that only a relatively short period was allowed. However, since and during that time the Government took cognisance of a great many of the concerns of people in the community.

The Australian Democrats will not support the second reading attachments put forward by the Opposition, although probably we could do so. One of Senator Alston's second reading amendments asks the Senate to add the words:
but the Senate criticises the Government for its failure to specify or detail the exact nature of extent of the community services obligations of Telecom.

We could make a similar complaint, but we would be making it for the opposite reasons. Since it is not an infrequent occurrence for the Democrats to find themselves on the same side as the Opposition for all the wrong reasons, it is unnecessary for us to do so on this occasion because it would mean that I would have to reiterate all that I have said. If there is any need to seek more detail on the nature and extent of the community service obligations of Telecom, we will do so at the committee stage. However, we believe that, having looked at the whole package of legislation as well as at the Minister's statements in his second reading speech and the explanatory memorandum, in large measure we would not want to make that criticism.

Finally, I emphasise that that is very much dependent, as is the whole package, upon the workings of Austel, and that is very much dependent upon the appointments yet to be made at Austel. We believe that with appropriate appointments it will be a body able to advise government adequately. Government must take account of the community views which are coming through in research and publicly. In general terms, we support the passage of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a package of Bills. Due to shortage of time it is necessary for us to consider Bills dealing with the industry, technology and commerce package and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (SMEC) with the telecommunications package. I agree with Senator Powell's assessment of what is happening here-that from the coalition's point of view the Government is once again demonstrating that, while the rhetoric was there when the Government talked about what it would do in these areas, the legislation as produced in this Parliament does not live up to the rhetoric. I acknowledge that the Australian Democrats recognise that that is the point which we keep making about the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said repeatedly, the Government has failed to live up to the promise it made during the July 1987 election campaign that it would put down as a top priority for this nation-using the jargon of the time-micro-economic reform. However, what we are talking about is efficiency in government business enterprises, the introduction of competition into government business enterprises, and a reduction of regulations to enable private enterprises to compete adequately and, indeed, to enable public business enterprises to compete in a way which would keep down prices and provide a broad range of services for the people of Australia at reasonable prices instead of at regulated prices, which pushes prices up and lowers services.

The Government was full of rhetoric about that but the package of Bills which it has introduced does not live up to the rhetoric. Once again, the Government keeps talking about it. Over the weekend Mr Willis talked about the privatisation of Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines. That debate has been placed back into the public arena of the Australian Labor Party. But the Government has been talking about that for two years and has not acted. This parcel of legislation presented the Government with at least two opportunities on which to act in the privatisation field and one area in which it could have achieved substantial micro-economic reform. The first areas which presented opportunities for privatisation were in relation to the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) and SMEC. However, those opportunities were not picked up by the Government. Another area where there was a major opportunity to introduce competition and efficiency was in the legislation dealing with Telecom Australia. But, as I say, the Government has failed to perform.

I turn, firstly, to the Australian Industry Development Corporation. The Bill contains a number of minor amendments and introduces a corporate planning process; in other words, some way whereby the Government will try to direct the Australian Industry Development Corporation into appearing to be a private enterprise. There is only one way to make a business act like a private company-that is, to make it a private company. The Government is prepared to go 30 per cent of the way with the AIDC, but not the whole way. If the Government is prepared to consider privatising Qantas and Australian Airlines, why does it not consider privatising the AIDC? After all, the AIDC operates exclusively as a commercial enterprise and there is no essential public interest reason for maintaining Federal government ownership of the body. That is acknowledged on all sides of the debate, in both the public and the private areas. Senator Button has repeatedly acknowledged the need to privatise this body, yet all he can persuade his Party to do is to sell 30 per cent of its shares to the market. In due course the coalition parties will ask the Senate to resolve that the Government should sell the Australian Industry Development Corporation in its entirety to the private sector as soon as possible.

The other area in this package concerns the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. If we were to talk about this body as SMEC people would not hold it in the high regard in which they currently hold it, going back to the time when the Snowy Mountains scheme was built. But that scheme was completed a long time ago, and we are left with a body which is purely and simply a private consulting firm in the engineering field. There is no reason why it should remain in Commonwealth ownership. The Commonwealth has contributed capital of $16.6m to this body. At one stage it received some $3.3m back in dividends, but the Corporation lost money between 1983 and 1987. During that period it was necessary to inject a further $12m of taxpayers' funds into this body just to keep it going.

The Corporation shows a return of some sort of profitability but when one looks at its balance sheet for the year ended 30 June 1988 one sees that there are practically no provisions for any possible liabilities. There is some provision for insurance, but one wonders whether there are any risks in relation to creditors or actions for damages which may have arisen out of some of its work. There are no liability provisions there. On my assessment of the statement of profit and loss for that year it seems that the only reasons it made a profit were a net gain arising from a special review of projects-whatever that was all about-and an extraordinary item relating to the sale of some seven houses which then became part of its income, in other words, a conversion of capital into income.
