As a result of that it ended up with a minor profit at the end of the year.

This is a body which operates exclusively in the private sector. There is absolutely no reason for it to be in the public sector. The coalition's policy is to convert it to a private consulting firm and give SMEC's management and staff first option to purchase the Corporation. In due course, the Senate will be asked to resolve that that should happen.

I now turn to the telecommunications package of Bills. Here is where one sees that the Government has really fallen down. This package was mooted in the early part of last year, in May 1988, as some marvellous new package which would introduce competition into the telecommunications field in Australia. When we finally saw the legislation only a couple of months ago we were quite staggered-I believe this was a wide perception around Australia-at how little competition was introduced and how much the measures were aimed to protect Telecom Australia. That is quite staggering because, after all, Telecom is, I think, the largest business in Australia. Its turnover this year will be in excess of $8 billion. It is bigger than the Department of Defence, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and the Coles-Myer group. Last year it had an announced profit of $776m but if we look at the extraordinary write-offs we would have to guess that its profit was in excess of $1 billion. Yet this Government is not prepared to allow Telecom to face genuine competition, except in a few very small areas.

There will be no competition for public pay telephones and no competition for the first telephone. If we think of the service on public pay telephones we can see why there ought to be competition in this area. Private enterprise ought to be able to set up public telephones in every garage and corner store and in stores open 24 hours a day. But, because this service is exclusively maintained in a monopoly for Telecom, all we can find are public telephones out in the street, usually wrecked by young people who seem to take delight in tearing these public pay phones to pieces. If there was an opportunity for public pay phones to be set up in a competitive area they could be located in places where they could be protected by people who would look after them because there was a profit in them. There is no competition for the installation of the first telephone.

Then we get to the areas where there are real opportunities for development during the 1990s. There is absolutely no competition allowed in the legislation for what are called public switched data services or public switched integrated service in digital networks. There is no competition for public switched text and video services, for leased circuit services or for public mobile telephone services. We ask why the Government is protecting Telecom from competition in these areas. It is a genuine question. What answer do we get? The Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, Mrs Ros Kelly, says it is all because of the need to provide community service obligations. One wonders what the community service obligations are that the Government is providing. According to a newspaper article:
Mrs Kelly said the community service obligation of Telecom was its main rationale for retaining its monopoly over the basic telecommunications network and some other profitable services.
So the main rationale for returning its monopoly is the need to provide a basic telecommunications network and to provide community service obligations. The article continues:

She said the entrenchment of monopoly areas in legislation would make it more difficult for the Opposition to privatise Telecom or the Overseas Telecommunications Commision (OTC), if it came to power.

That is one of the very significant things that the Government is doing. In this case it is trying to get in first and entrench these monopoly areas in legislation so that when the Liberal and National parties get into government we will have great difficulty in privatising Telecom or the Overseas Telecom- munications Commission (OTC), or taking whatever steps we want to take to introduce more competition for Telecom. I do not know why Mrs Kelly says that we would be privatising Telecom because that is not part of our policy. We would be introducing more competition into these areas, but the Minister was saying that she wanted to entrench the monopoly areas in the legislation in order to make our actions more difficult when we get into government.

Let us look at the community service obligations of Telecom. These obligations are much more fuzzy in this Bill than they were in the old legislation. In the old Bill there was a specific provision that the special needs for telecommunication services of Australian people who reside or carry on business outside the cities would be taken into account by Telecom. That provision is not in the current Bill. The current Bill has a much fuzzier definition of community service obligations. One wonders what Telecom intends to provide for community service obligations. For example, as recently as 15 May this year Telecom changed part of its community service obligations so that all Telecom cable to be installed to private homes which exceeds 30 metres in length would be subject to an additional installation charge of about $8 per metre. Previously, Telecom had been providing cable up to 300 metres in length, but when our then shadow Minister for communications, Mr John Sharp, asked Telecom for the reason for this change, Telecom said that the metropolitan city areas, which require only short lengths of cable, had been carrying the cost of country services so it had to reduce the cable length supplied under the standard charge.

Is that a community service obligation or not? We certainly do not know from this legislation. There is no definition set out in this legislation that would enable us to answer that question. It seems to us that Telecom is interpreting the definition of community service obligations as Telecom sees fit. One wonders whether Telecom's purpose is to change things before Austel is established-Austel being the regulatory body created by this telecommunications package which is before the Parliament.

One needs a proper analysis of community service obligations before the monopolies become entrenched. One wonders why Telecom has been acting in certain ways before this legislation goes through, before Austel is created. For example, I have had representations that there should be a computer link between terminals at each community library around Australia. That is a very expensive operation. I wonder whether that should be a community service obligation. I have had representations that there should be hearing aid compatibility on public telephones. I wonder whether that should be a community service obligation. Without proper analysis we do not know what community service obligations Telecom is accepting, and we do not know what community service obligations Telecom should accept. Without proper analysis it is not possible to make a fair assessment of the extent of Telecom's community service obligations and, therefore, it is not possible to ascertain what is the cost of those obligations. If one follows it through logically, one arrives at the next step: how on earth can we ascertain what extent of monopoly powers has to be given to Telecom in order to enable it to provide these community service obligations? It seems to me that the Government and the Minister have failed to follow through the logical progression in order to establish the reason for their granting Telecom the monopoly powers.

The Telecommunications Bill defines and entrenches very broad monopolies for Telecom, OTC and Aussat, and it carefully protects those monopolies. Examination of the explanatory memorandum which accompanies the Telecommunications Bill would disclose what I have just said to be the truth. For example, the explanatory memorandum states that the Bill gives a clear definition of the carrier monopolies with Austel having the role of economic and technical regulation of the industry. We understand what is meant by the `regulation of the industry'. Regulation means government control or, in this case, Austel control, with a clear definition of the carrier monopolies. As if that were not bad enough, the explanatory memorandum goes on to acknowledge that all three carriers, Telecom, OTC and Aussat, have their monopolies confirmed by this legislation. The monopolies are confirmed and defined by this legislation, and Austel has the role of regulating those monopolies. And as if that were not enough-I am talking about Telecom, the biggest industry in Australia-the Bill goes on to establish a class licence mechanism which is specifically designed to ensure that people who move into this area, which the Government says it is opening up to competition, and who find that they are competing with Telecom will have to be involved in this class licence system and in an additional permit system to ensure that any competition is absolutely at a bare minimum and regulated by Austel absolutely and completely.

What on earth is the Government on about in introducing this sort of legislation and saying to the Parliament, `We are going to deregulate the telecommunications industry.'? Clearly, the Government is not deregulating the telecommunications industry. In any event there is no provision for OTC and Aussat to provide any community service obligations, so there is no backing for their monopolies which have been granted in this legislation. As I said, when one looks at the legislation the Government has introduced, one sees its defects. As a result, the coalition parties, as my colleague Senator Alston has already indicated, will be introducing a very substantial number of amendments which would promote competition as an object of the Act and a function of Austel, and would reduce the range of monopolies reserved for Telecom. The amendments would delete the class licence and permit systems. That might provide some genuine competition in this industry.

Telecom would benefit from some competition in this industry. Telecom is a large, vibrant and viable enterprise with a large number of very able people working in it. If Telecom were given the opportunity to go out there and compete fairly on the market, I am sure it would do extraordinarily well. With competition, people working for Telecom would be able to see what others were coming up with in the private enterprise field and match them with other thoughts that Telecom officers might have. There would be genuine competition. But the legislation which this Government has introduced does not do any of those things. It simply entrenches the monopoly which already exists. It makes sure that when the Liberal and National parties get into government we will not be able to change that. It regulates the industry and the people who are trying desperately to enter into it. It controls it so that Telecom will be in a position to always maintain a monopoly.

The Government could not even bring about a position where there would be some competition in the public mobile telephone service-the least little thing that the Government could have done. Because of the control which the unions exercise through the back bench Caucus committees of the Australian Labor Party, this Government is unable to introduce the sort of competition which it should have been introducing and the sort of competition which this country desperately needs. The point is that this country is desperately going down the drain. We are in a position where the country has to do something about becoming competitive, and using its own products instead of having to import. The way to do that is to introduce competition-that is what will bring about the sort of recovery this country needs. Here, with this legislation before the Senate today, was an opportunity to privatise SMEC and the AIDC, and introduce genuine competition and efficiency to Telecom. What has happened? This Government has failed on all three counts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are discussing in a cognate debate a number of Bills dealing with telecommunications and postal services, and also the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (Conversion into Public Company) Bill and the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill. It is the last two to which I shall address my remarks, Senator Powell having picked up the debate with respect to the several Bills dealing with telecommunications.

SPEECH.PARA: The words which kept coming through in Senator Lewis's speech were competition, competition, competition. He seems to think that is the only way in which we will get a more efficient Australian industry. That ideological view is widely shared by the Opposition and by many members of the Government side. It happens to be a view which is not shared by the Australian Democrats. There is certainly a need for increased efficiency in a number of industries, but competition is not necessarily the way to go. That ideological commitment to competition and the operation of a free market very often is inimical to the provision of more comprehensive and better services to the public. One only needs to observe that, in the case of an industry which is spread through a number of competing sectors, there is a duplication of capital investment. As we have seen with the airline industry in the United States of America, often that competition leads to some of the participants going to the wall and enormous capital investments are simply lost. Of course, the Opposition may naively argue that those capital investments are lost by private investors, but it represents a failure by the citizens of a country to invest that capital more profitably and so benefit all the citizens of that country. It does not really matter too much where the money is lost; if it is lost it becomes a penalty against the whole community.

The two Bills to which I wish to direct my remarks, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (Conversion into Public Company) Bill and the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill, in a sense represent two parts of the same process. The Government has sought to privatise the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC). It began that process some months ago with the privatisation of 30 per cent of the ownership of AIDC through the creation of a subsidiary company, and the floating of 30 per cent of shares in that company. The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (SMEC) has not gone as far as that. This legislation before us proposes that the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation shall be turned into a wholly owned government company. Of course, one can read the writing on the wall; that is, it is a step down the road towards partial and then, perhaps, complete privatisation of SMEC. Interestingly, the next step for the AIDC will be that the subsidiary company will be permitted to float off further subsidiary companies, and those subsidiary companies will not be nearly as accountable to the Government as the parent company. Indeed, the auditing of the accounts of those subsidiary companies will no longer necessarily be a function of the Government audit process.

As I have indicated, one sees in these two Bills two parts of the same process. The AIDC has gone some way down the road. One can see that SMEC will be following down exactly the same road; it has not gone quite as far at the present time. It is difficult to understand that philosophy. It is one that is not shared by the Australian Democrats. As I have indicated, we are not ideologically committed to the idea that the operation of the free market necessarily serves the common good. In fact, there is abundant evidence that it does not, and I have spoken about that before. Nor are we committed to the idea that competition necessarily leads to a more efficient allocation of resources. Indeed, there are a number of examples which illustrate that point.

Let us look at the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (Conversion into Public Company) Bill. As I have said, it intends to convert the Corporation to a public company but, in the first instance, a public company in which the Government will hold all the shares. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) used a number of euphemisms in his second reading speech. This is something that stands out repeatedly in ministerial statements and speeches from this Government. When it does something it describes it as a reform. It talks about improving the performance of government business enterprises. It gives the impression that these changes will necessarily lead to improvement, although the sorts of improvements which might flow from the changes are not necessarily argued very cogently or very well. When one reads the Minister's speech, one finds that he is at pains to point out `the Corporation's outstanding international reputation for engineering excellence, particularly in the Asia Pacific region'.

The Minister himself says that the organisation has performed extremely well as regards the quality of its work. In his speech he says that it was ranked 62 in a 1988 world survey of international engineering consulting firms. I would have thought that, given the large number of engineering consulting firms there must be in the world, and given the size of Australia, coming No. 62 in a survey again indicates the very high standing of this organisation's work. The Minister refers to the Corporation `both as a winner of export awards and in assisting the development of the Australian engineering consulting industry through joint ventures and in gaining an overseas track record'. He is again drawing attention to the quality of the work being done and the standing in which that work is held by people in Australia, by the Australian consulting engineering industry in general and, through joint ventures, by overseas countries.

The Minister is not in any way criticising the quality of the work which this organisation is carrying out. It seems to me that that in itself, in relation to a major engineering venture, is a very important consideration. Senator Lewis asserted simply that this organisation did not have a social function. I would have thought that the social impact of major engineering enterprises which significantly affect the environment and the quality of people's lives for a very long time into the future-one can think of projects like the Snowy Mountains scheme, which Senator Lewis mentioned-is indeed a very important consideration to be taken into account. The quality of that work is not necessarily improved by introducing competition, by exposing the company to free market forces or by privatisation. The Minister pointed out:
Since 1970 SMEC has completed 1,350 projects in 50 countries with a capital value of $4,500 million and has earned consulting fees of $294 million.
Picking up on the figures which Senator Lewis mentioned, the next paragraph in the Minister's speech pointed out:

It has received a capital contribution from the Commonwealth totalling $16.6 million while returning dividends to the Government totalling $3.3 million. In addition it has paid corporate taxes amounting to $11 million, as well as $7 million in State payroll and lands taxes and $1.3 million in local government taxes.

If one adds all those amounts together, one finds that there has been a net profit to Government of roughly $6m plus the consideration of $294m in total earnings-a not inconsiderable amount and, I would have thought, a very significant contribution to the Australian economy and to the standing of Australian engineering in world terms. The Minister also stated that it is anticipated that a substantial dividend will be forthcoming from the 1988-89 result.

So, clearly, we are dealing with a company which has already performed extremely well in terms of quality. It has been profitable and it has been engaged in a large number of ventures, both inside and outside Australia, of very significant social impact. Clearly, we need to be concerned about that sort of impact-there needs to be a much wider spectrum of analysis than simply looking at its economic returns directly to government.
The Minister then proceeded to talk about the planning and accountability of the new structure. He said:
New planning and accountability mechanisms include the provision by SMEC of a three-year rolling Corporate Plan.

This relates to the introduction on 4 November 1987 by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) of the policy paper Guidelines for Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises. Senator Walsh made some very interesting and relevant statements in his speech to the Senate on that date; they are very relevant to what Senator Lewis said. Senator Walsh said:

Assumptions that an enterprise will deliver services more efficiently if it is privately owned, or that private ownership is synonymous with competition, have no more validity than an assumption that because an enterprise is publicly owned its resources are necessarily being deployed in a manner which will maximise the public benefit.

I could not agree more with that statement that efficiency and service to the public are variables which do not necessarily bear on the question of who owns the company or to what extent the company is exposed to competition and market forces. Relevant to the other Bills with which we are dealing this evening, Senator Walsh went on to point to the provision of telephone services in this context. He said:

Telephone services cannot be produced economically in an isolated community nor can the cost of such services be fully recovered from the recipients. An attempt to recover the full cost of such services to isolated communities would necessarily result in prices higher than the market will bear. The consequences of that would be continuously increasing average costs and therefore prices in response to continuously falling demand, and continuously falling demand in response to continuously increasing average costs and therefore prices. Eventually all services would be terminated outside those major population centres where average costs are within a range which the market will bear. Losses on services to these areas are currently covered by cross-subsidies at a cost to Telecom of some $500m per year.

I guess that that general consideration applies to a large number of government instrumentalities where one expects those instrumentalities to take into account in some measure the public good. The Australian Democrats certainly are concerned that all publicly owned enterprises should remain in public hands and should certainly take into account their service to the public good.

In his second reading speech on the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (Conversion into Public Company) Bill, the Minister stated that the share capital will be fixed at a maximum of $5,207,807-a remarkably accurately described figure which represents the capital contributed by the Commonwealth as at 30 June, less accumulated losses. The capital will be divided into $1 par shares with all shares to be held, at least initially, by the Commonwealth. The words `with all shares to be held, at least initially, by the Commonwealth' are very instructive. In that we see the direction of the Government's thinking. Clearly, the Government intends that further down the track this organisation will follow the path already taken by the AIDC-something which is presaged by statements by some Government Ministers in recent days with respect to Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd.

In the very next paragraph of the Minister's second reading speech one reads that there is the possibility of a scheme being considered in which the workers in SMEC would become shareholders. Of course, the Australian Democrats would have no ideological objection to such a proposal. But clearly, without some control on the further selling on of those shares, the door would be left open for the gradual takeover of this company by interests well beyond the workers within SMEC. We note with some concern, in view of the way in which this company is already on the road towards privatisation, that there is a provision in the Bill for the company's exemption from the Freedom of Information Act. While we have no objection to this in relation to sensitive information with respect to contracts which are being negotiated, quite clearly there would be other areas in which this organisation would be in possession of information that should really be in the public domain.

In reflecting back to the Guidelines for Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises, I point out that the Minister for Finance is clearly looking towards guidelines of a financial nature only. In his speech on 4 November 1987, to which I referred earlier, he said:

The precise structure of the target will depend on the nature of the enterprise concerned but, unless there are compelling reasons to the contrary, will take the form of a specified rate of return on the enterprise's assets . . .
He also stated:
The introduction of financial targets will require the development of appropriate accounting and reporting practices.

The whole tenor of his statement is in terms of the financial management, financial returns and the profitability of the organisation. We are concerned that a major engineering company would be necessarily involved in major impacts on the environment. Nowhere in the guidelines is any consideration given to the sorts of contracts that SMEC may or may not take up. Yesterday I was in the Cairns region of north Queensland. Again, I noted that the Tully millstream hydro-electric development scheme is still being considered. I understand this scheme is one in which SMEC may have an interest. It is extremely environmentally sensitive. The Government should exercise some continuing control over the impact on the environment of projects undertaken by such an organisation-after all, it is under government control at this time-not only with respect to its financial management but also with respect to the sorts of contracts that it accepts, rejects or seeks to modify.

The last point I wish to make relates to the Industry Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 which seeks to allow the AIDC subsidiary, which was recently created and which is currently 70 per cent owned by government-30 per cent of the shares have been hived off to the public-to act as a commercial enterprise. The most significant aspect is that those sorts of subsidiaries may no longer be directly accountable to government. They may appoint their own auditor which, in many cases, probably would not be the Government auditor. This is quite unsatisfactory because the money involved is substantially a government investment. We are dealing with an organisation which until recently was totally within government control. It was created to encourage the development of particular sorts of industry and, in line with government policy, by implication, it was specifically not created to provide help to other sorts of industry. Yet it is moving further and further towards a totally market driven, competitive system and its accounts will not even be audited by the Government auditor.

We will move amendments to this legislation. The effect of those amendments will be that the accounts of subsidiary companies should be audited by the Auditor-General and those accounts will then come under close government scrutiny. We are doing this because we have no ideological confidence in the private audit system as expressed, apparently by implication, by the Government and certainly expressed, quite explicitly, by Senator Lewis a short time ago. We note the recent Four Corners program dealing with the Bond companies and the way in which audited accounts to the end of 1988 were apparently presented. As a consequence of the revelations which were made in that Four Corners program, I noted in a news item a month or so later that the Bond auditors were adjusting their annual statement, having regard to those claims which had been made in the earlier statement with respect to sales which were not genuine and which were, therefore, not properly listed in that annual report. When major companies behave in that way, I think there is a very good reason for the subsidiary company under the AIDC to remain within the area of the Government audit. For that reason we will move the amendments which were circulated about a week or so ago.

In summary, we are concerned that in these two pieces of legislation we see yet again a move to privatise progressively government property and businesses. This is a process of selling off the farm. One can only sell it off once. We are not convinced that this will necessarily lead to improvements in economic efficiency or better service to the public. One can produce considerable evidence to the contrary. We are concerned that the Opposition is even more ideologically committed to this path and that the Government is merely setting up a situation which, should the Opposition ever gain government, will make it even easier for it to further privatise these important public properties. Both these organisations can serve a very important social role as well as an important commercial role. They have considerable impacts. They can at the moment be somewhat directed by Government policy. The Australian Democrats certainly believe that that situation should continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —According to the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray):

SPEECH.PARA: A central plank in the Government's micro-economic reform agenda for restructuring the public sector is that Government Business Enterprises (GBEs) should be as efficient as possible and responsive to consumers' needs.

The Government sees the commercialisation of the GBEs as a necessary and fundamental pre-condition to improvements in efficiency. GBEs such as Telecom are being placed on a more commercial footing, bringing them more into line with private sector competitors, and subjecting them increasingly to the disciplines of the marketplace.

That is all very well as far as it goes. However, it leaves many of those bodies in an intolerable and quite disgraceful halfway house where they are removed from the level of scrutiny to which, as government enterprises, they had been subject, particularly by way of Senate Estimates committees, and are put into a sort of no-man's land where, as corporations, they are not subject to the sort of scrutiny to which they should be subjected by this Parliament or to the sort of scrutiny to which they would be subjected if they had public shareholders. If this is the first step towards privatisation, let the privatisation come quickly so that the proper degree of responsibility can be implemented.

This is a real problem. When government business enterprises reach this halfway house, there is a massive added burden of responsibility on them to behave with propriety and to be responsible to somebody. We have already seen an unhealthy trend towards a reduction in that level of scrutiny. I am not necessarily blaming Telecom Australia on this occasion. I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that when former Senator Gietzelt was Chairman of the Senate Estimates Committee which dealt with Telecom, some Committee members were particularly disappointed that we were not given the opportunity to ask the sorts of questions we believed we had every right to ask of Telecom.

It is on that issue that I now raise some very serious and scandalous matters. I believe there is a real prospect of both impropriety and illegality in the tender process under which a company called Compass Debt Collection Services Pty Ltd has recently been given the tender to collect Telecom bad debts in the metropolitan area of Sydney, and to endeavour to recover what had been written off as irrecoverable bad debts in the metropolitan and northern country areas of New South Wales. Telecom has a special responsibility, as a government monopoly, to be particularly careful about the manner in which it conducts its business. In this matter, it seems that there are links between Compass Debt Collection Services, which received this tender, and another successful tenderer for another and much larger debt collection tender. I wish to be assured-the Senate deserves to be assured-that these links do not indicate that one was behaving as a front for the other. It is of major concern to me.

These tenders relate to multi-millions of dollars. The Compass Debt Collection Services' tender relates to debts worth $4.8m. Commercial Debt Collection Services was the successful tenderer for a debt of around $19m. As I understand it, there is no concern within the debt collecting industry about Commercial Debt Collection Services winning that tender. I understand there was no suggestion of impropriety in that matter. There is real concern, however, within the debt collection industry and a degree of concern within the New South Wales Police Force, which is investigating this matter, about the successful tender by Compass Debt Collection Services.

Compass was awarded the Appendix A, Metropolitan North, and the Appendix E tender, Metropolitan and Country North previously irrecoverable debts, as a result of its submission of a tender document on 3 February 1989. It was awarded it on, I think, 3 May-at least, information was given to unsuccessful tenderers that Compass had won that tender on 3 May. However, under the laws of the State of New South Wales Compass Debt Collection Services Pty Ltd was precluded from lodging a tender as it did not hold a commercial agent's licence. It is said that one of the principals of the company held a licence of a kind. As I understand the law, the company is required to hold a licence. Obviously, the company also feels that it should because it made an application to the court in New South Wales for the licence on 6 April 1989, presumably when it was advised that it had been the successful tenderer. At that belated point it made an application to the court for a commercial debt collector's licence and, as I understand it, it was granted one only towards the end of last month.

The New South Wales Police Department is now in the process of investigating whether a breach of the State law has taken place, whether charges should be laid, and naturally, as a consequence, whether the licence should be cancelled. I know of that for a variety of reasons, but mainly because I made inquiries of the New South Wales police to assure myself that Telecom was cooperating fully with the New South Wales police in their investigations. As I understand it, the New South Wales police made a request to see the tender document because they had been advised that Compass did not have a licence at the time tender documents closed. I am glad to say that after some toing-and-froing and some telephone calls to Telecom from me-I kept it advised of this matter-Telecom, being aware of my concerns, eventually provided the New South Wales police with a copy of the successful tender document so that the police could proceed with their investigations. I understand the reason why an organisation like Telecom must be careful in providing this kind of information, but I would have hoped that perhaps a more speedy response might have followed the request.

However, some other problems developed. I simply wonder why Compass-a company which was incorporated only on 1 February, two days before the tender closed, and having no track record or commercial standing-should be awarded a contract of this magnitude for the recovery of $4.8m in bad debts, which would probably involve a revenue collection of around $1m; at least, that is the forecast in the letter of information to other tenderers. I note that the company that received the biggest tender-and I have no complaint about that-the Metropolitan South tender for about $12m in bad debts, was Commercial Debt Collection Services, which has as its managing director Mr Terry Clee. However, I also understand that the principal of Compass Debt Collection Services, a Mr John Ludlow, is the holder of a commercial licence as a subagent to Mr Terry Clee. I understand that was the situation at the date of lodgment of the Telecom tenders. As I say, that information was given to me and I cannot vouch for it.

However, I understand-I have been assured that this is fact-that Mr Ludlow's previous business address was that of Commercial Debt Collection Services; in other words, it was Mr Terry Clee's address. This rival, who received another tender, had the same address as the successful tenderer for the large contract. I wonder why-and Telecom owes us an explanation-Compass Debt Collection Services has its office at 42 City Road, Chippendale, a property owned by someone called Chantelle Clee. I know that to be a fact because I received a fax from the South Sydney Council advising me of that fact. It says that the owner of 42 City Road, Chippendale, is Ms Chantelle Margaret Clee of 61 Drumalbyn Road, Bellevue Hill. If Compass Debt Collection Services is totally unrelated to Commercial Debt Collection Services, someone should tell us so. Otherwise it will be suggested that it is related. I am not necessarily making that suggestion. I am saying that there is a special need for us to find out so that we can be aware of whether Mr Clee, directly or indirectly, will end up having almost total control of the Telecom debt collection contracts in New South Wales.

I would also like an assurance that no Telecom officers are involved in any way with Mr Terry Clee-that is, Telecom officers with a sufficiently senior role and an involvement in this matter. I was told by some people in the debt collecting industry that at least one senior Telecom officer is resigning to join Mr Clee's firm. I want to make sure that the tender process has not in spirit been breached by what could well be some kind of association and particularly the curious manner in which a company with no experience and no licence can magically get a substantial Telecom debt collection contract. I do not know what Telecom will chose to do about it. My inquiries of various firms in the industry have brought universal surprise-in fact, in some instances astonishment-that Compass won that tender. One of the companies said to me, `We were disappointed that we did not get the tender and we had never heard of the winner'. Another said to me, `We are extremely surprised we were not successful because Telecom told us we were the cheapest tenderer'. Another was sufficiently enraged to write me a letter about it, the detail of which I do not want to go into because it implies all sorts of impropriety.

There are some matters of further concern in this area, relating to whether or not an offence has been committed. It seems to be that the New South Wales law is very clear on this matter. I hope that Telecom would not, in knowledge of the law, set out to grant tenders to people who appear to have broken it. Part II of the Commercial Agents and Private Inquiry Agents Act in New South Wales says, in section 6-I shall just read the relevant sections:
6. (1) Subject to this Act, no person shall
(b) advertise, notify or state that he exercises or carries on or is willing to exercise or carry on; or
(c) in any way hold himself out to the public as ready to exercise or carry on,
the business or any of the functions-
(i) of a commercial agent, unless he is the holder of a commercial agent's license;
It goes on:

(2) Any person who contravenes or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this section shall be liable, in the case of a corporation, to a penalty not exceeding $5,000 and, in the case of an individual, to a penalty not exceeding $500 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months, or to both such penalty and imprisonment.

The reason I mention that is that I think organisations such as Telecom have an obligation to ensure that when contracts of this nature are awarded they are not in breach of State law. If there is a risk that they may be, would it not be a good idea for Telecom to state in tender documents that the holding of the appropriate licence in such a situation, where a licence was required, should be a requirement of the tender?

However, I noticed that a requirement of the tender is that tenderers supply Telecom with evidence of their commercial standing. Compass had no commercial standing because it did not exist until two days before the tender. Another requirement is that partnerships in companies must submit proof of their proper registration. If that took place and Telecom was advised of the details of Compass's proof of proper registration, it would have seen that it had an enormous commercial history lasting two days! Another requirement is that companies provide the names of referees from three large commercial and/or government organisations for which they are currently carrying out debt collection work. How could Compass, with two days of commercial history, provide referees from three commercial and/or government organisations for which it is currently carrying out debt collection work? A tenderer has also to advise details of the present size of its operations in terms of staff numbers, structure and financial worth.

As I was saying, it seems to me that there is a special obligation on government monopolies to adopt the greatest propriety in this kind of matter. It seems to me that Telecom has let those standards slip. As I said, I have been having lengthy discussions with Telecom on the matter of providing material to the New South Wales police. I had suggested to the officer in Telecom to whom I have been talking over the last couple of weeks that if there were any people from Telecom he thought would like to contact me about the nature of this tender, about which I have great concerns, he should suggest that they give me a ring. To my knowledge I have received no contact. No attempt has been made by Telecom to contact me over my stated concerns to Telecom about the nature and the granting of this contract. I think it would have been a good idea had Telecom taken up my offer.

I wish to raise another little matter, which emerges from the size of the bad debts revealed in the tender document, which I now have. One of the questions I wanted to ask Telecom at the Senate Estimates meetings, when we had Telecom's annual report before us, was why on earth bad debts of $54m written off in the 1987 accounts should have been cut to an extraordinarily low amount of $20.4m-a cut of 63 per cent in the accounts for the year to June 1988. Are less than half as many people now failing to pay their bills? Has something magic happened? Apparently not, judging by the tender documents. When I see in those documents the amount of bad debts that have been referred to debt collecting agencies before being written off, I find the total for New South Wales in the coming financial year is $29m. I then look at the recovery rates-the expected turnover figures for the companies involved-in the letter of advice and see that about $25m will remain outstanding after the expected recoveries have taken place. In New South Wales alone $25m of debt will remain outstanding in the coming financial year, suggesting that something like $75m in bad debts will be suffered by Telecom. How and why, then, were only $20m in bad debts written off in the 1988 accounts? In fact, the provision for bad and doubtful debts was increased slightly because of a reduction in the amount actually written off.

As I said, a government monopoly has special obligations to report fully and properly. I think it is up to Telecom to explain to the Senate why, if the New South Wales figures for bad debts revealed in these tender documents are as large as they are, only $20m was written off last year. As I say, the Telecom people were not subjected to the sort of inquiry I would have liked to subject them to in the Senate Estimates hearings and I regret that, but I regret even more the whole manner in which this tendering procedure concerning bad debts has gone on.

I had no special brief for any of the people that I spoke to in the industry. I was alerted to this matter by one of the many companies which missed out on the tender, but all of them are cross about it. I suggest to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) that, if Telecom is unwilling to provide adequate responses, heavy pressure should be brought to bear upon it. As I said, it is all very well going down the track of creating these semi-independent organisations but, while they are in the position of being under the `control' of the Government, they must be absolutely fully responsible and answerable to this Parliament until they are in a situation where they are fully answerable to the public, which I hope would become their owner once they are privatised. They cannot be allowed to remain in this halfway house.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill 1989, the Australian Postal Corporation Bill 1989, the Telecommunications and Postal Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1989, the Telecommunications Bill 1989, and the Telecommunications (Application Fees) Bill 1989, and two other Bills. I want to summarise some of the changes that are incorporated in this series of Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: First, a new legislative charter is established for the operations of Telecom Australia. This supposedly introduces greater competition into the telecommunications industry. It supposedly gives Telecom a new commercially oriented financial structure because it will be measured against competitors in the private sector and will have to pay all taxes and government charges. The legislation also establishes Austel as an independent regulator in the telecommunications industry. I will have more to say about that later. It also provides a new legislative charter for Australia Post, as well as Telecom, which supposedly gives it a new commercially oriented financial structure as well. Incidentally, apart from all of these things, the Bills require the development of so-called corporate plans for Telecom and Australia Post. Obviously all of those matters are intended to be indications of the change of direction of this Government towards a more commercial, competitive and deregulated approach for those very large commercial enterprises comprised by Telecom and Australia Post.

The first thing that we ought to observe about the package as a whole is that the proposed changes-especially those to the telecommunications industry-are supposed to be the central elements of the Government's micro-economic reform. We remember, following the last election in 1987, the commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when he came weeping onto the television to tell us that the third term agenda of his Government would be to provide us with micro-economic reform. Of course, many people do not really know what that means. But, given the mess of our economy as a whole, it is fairly clear to increasing numbers of people that what is needed is a tough-minded government to take on issues such as the reform of the waterfront, of the airlines and of the telecommunications industry, to provide growth for the future and better economic performance on the part of those infrastructure elements of our economy.

Back in 1987 what the Prime Minister meant to say was that these things which he had in mind were meant to make individual industries more efficient and, consequently, more able to cope with the demands and pressures of overseas competition-and, of course, more effectively to deliver cheaper services to the Australian community. Obviously that government rhetoric was nothing more than that, because about a year ago the Government introduced into the Parliament statements that showed that it had done very little at all in the area of micro-economic reform, especially in the area of telecommunications. We saw the much vaunted approach to so-called privatisation amount to nothing as a result of that. Yet only today we see that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) is suddenly raising this issue again in respect of the airlines. From what I hear of reports of those on the left of the Australian Labor Party who were interviewed on television tonight, apparently those attempts to reach reform in the airline industry are going to come to nothing as well.

We see some action with more and more voluminous reports being released in the waterfront and shipping industries. It is very little and far too late. In the area of taxation, the Government has fiddled around the edges to increase the overall tax burden, not reduce it, and to maintain the mix of tax disincentives which favours debt over savings. There has been no attempt to increase the pool of savings in the Australian community to develop our own economy and make us less vulnerable to having to borrow from overseas. In the area of education, 20,000 students still miss out on higher education places, despite being eligible. In the area of transportation, I have mentioned the airlines. Under current proposals, they will not be deregulated until 1990. The railways are heavily over-regulated and monopolised. Even one of the stars in the crown of the Government, and even the crown of Senator Button-the Business Regulation Review Unit-has not lived up to its potential and has not been seen to produce the kind of reform that we thought may have occurred a year or two ago. These reforms are vital to turn around the state of the Australian economy and to produce long-term answers to the problems which we, as a nation, are facing.

Turning to telecommunications reform, the Government has failed to go nearly far enough to reform the telecommunications industry. All that it has done, when it all boils down, is rearrange the legislative and regulatory framework. There has been little, if any, reform at all. The Government has simply thrown aside the consumer oriented approach to telecommunications reform. It chooses to keep a monopoly for our telecommunications operators rather than look at what the market demands, at what the people of Australia want in terms of better service and new products, and to maintain its commitment to monopoly positions and, hence, lower customer service. It has been quite clear for many months now that the Government is simply captive to the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association. There is no foresight in the Government's approach to developing the huge potential of the telecommunications industry, to developing jobs and to reducing costs in this community. Even though we have this change, we are lagging behind the markets overseas, whereas we could and should be leading them in providing new job opportunities and high technology development.

Why does this legislation fail to deliver any of that kind of deregulation which the country is crying out for? Firstly, the legislation entrenches the very broad monopolies for Telecom, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) and Aussat. It does nothing to release them from those monopoly situations and expose them to private sector competition. In order to change the combination of the locks rather than undo the locks and free up the system, the Government has established two categories of telecommunications services, called reserved services and value added services. Reserved services are restricted to those carrier monopolies which we have just mentioned. There will be no competition in those areas at all, including public switched telephone services; public switched data services; public switched text and video services; public switched integrated services digital networks; leased circuit services; and public mobile telephone services. In other words, just about in every area where the ordinary person is touched on a day to day basis by his use of Telecom and other services, there will be no freeing up of Telecom's or the other carriers' monopolies. Under this arrangement even public telephones will be maintained as a Telecom monopoly. The resale of leased circuit services will be prohibited. A very small number of value added services will be allowed to engage in some competition. Although it cannot be denied that that will be of some assistance to the community, obviously it is a very minor part of what ought to have been done by this Government. Because of this exposure to such limited competition, these monopolies will retain their overregulation, overprotection and costliness-not to the Government, but to the Australian community.

I will contrast that with the policy of the Liberal and National parties. We would maintain a monopoly for only basic telecommunications services. In other words, subject to that limitation, all of the other areas that have been reserved will be opened to competition. The amendments that we will be moving later during the committee stage of the debate make those points clear.

The Government has said, `We have to maintain these monopolies for the carriers because we have to provide a service to the community in an equal way and at a reasonable cost to all those in the community'. Yet we do not know how much those community service obligations (CSOs) cost the consumer. There has been no attempt by the Government to find out precisely what it does cost. The Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics has not yet reported on its findings on those matters although the report was due last January. How can we therefore have legislation which is supposed to be setting out the mix of competitive against monopoly services if we do not know the extent of these CSOs? That vital question is the core of this matter. What are the costs of our community service obligations through Telecom and the other carriers? Does anybody know? Telecom admitted some time ago that it was as little as $250m while the Government has been parading around some figures in the past as high as $800m. But who knows? What is the real figure? Until we know that figure, we will not be able to establish whether we are performing an inadequate service for the population of Australia by not adopting a more competitive structure for our telecommunications industry.

The Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly) has been reported as saying that the Government intends entrenching the monopoly areas in legislation to make it even more difficult for the Opposition in government to implement the policy of deregulation that I have been talking about. What is the justification for that? The Opposition is presenting a policy which will deliver benefits to the whole Australian economy as well as the individual consumer and the Government is setting about establishing even more firmly the monopoly in favour of the carriers. Yet the Government would have the Parliament believe that it is somehow moving in the direction of freeing up the telecommunications industry. Obviously somebody is telling fibs or he does not understand what the Government is on about. It is probably neither, because most of this emanates from political pressure on the Government's own political structure. All of us know about that.

The position remains as simple as this: we will not get a more efficient and less costly telecommunications industry until there is deregulation, the area is opened up to competition and there is a fair approach on the part of Telecom to the provision of services rather than the arrogant monopoly approach it adopts at present. We have provided another number in the combination of the lock that has kept Telecom in its present structure by the establishment of Austel. The principle of the establishment of an independent regulator of the telecommunications industry is fine; it is certainly supported by the Liberal and National parties. The point is that as a result of this legislation Austel has been established all right, but all we have done is transfer all the regulatory forms which were previously held by Telecom into Austel so that instead Austel can do the bidding of Telecom. We have that kind of nonsense, which will merely restrict the future development of the telecommunications industry.

In the Minister's second reading speech we read that Austel will encourage the right environment for growth in the telecommunications industry. Obviously that is rubbish. I have just told honourable senators what the Minister has said. She has entrenched monopolies on the part of the carriers to ensure the Opposition policy of deregulation cannot be implemented. It is obviously a load of nonsense and the Australian Labor Party knows it. It knows that it is only carrying out a charade. Administering the regulatory framework through Austel will merely be seen as further entrenching that lack of competition. It has not been given a charter to actively pursue competition; it is just a toothless tiger where competition is concerned. On present indications it will turn out to be to the telecommunications industry nothing more than the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is to the broadcasting industry. Discretion is limited. Hence, we cannot see Austel becoming a truly independent regulator. Austel will be responsible to administer the licensing regime for competitive services but obviously it has been given no charter for further competition such as encouraging product innovation.

It will create a permit system, would honourable senators believe, for customer equipment, so that it can gain further regulation over the development of the telecommunications industry-another number in the combination of the lock to make sure that telecommunications stays locked up in the monopoly in which it currently operates. This system of permits is totally unnecessary. Obviously, it will not do anything to ensure the technical integrity of the telecommunications network but merely impose more bureaucracy on the growing and potentially beneficial telecommunications industry.

The legislation also empowers the new body, Austel, to make decisions on various matters in response to applications from the industry or the carriers within a 30-day period. Here is the rub: if Austel has not responded within that 30-day period, then it is assumed to have refused the application. This is written into legislation that is supposed to be freeing up the telecommunications industry. But what happens if I come along with a constituent who has a new idea in telecommunications and who seeks a permit from Austel? He takes that application to Austel and says, `I want this permit within 30 days'. If Austel says nothing for that 30-day period, that means that application has been refused without any kind of hearing, without any kind of proper examination of the issues. We end up in a situation where quite obviously Austel again becomes the tool of the monopoly carriers. That is simply outrageous because it locks up that monopoly even tighter than it otherwise would have been. Obviously, as a result, industry will be penalised and the present level of inefficiency will be maintained.

I believe that a number of other matters are of relevance. First, the legislation provides immunity from the common law liability for Australia Post, Telecom and OTC in relation to the supply of a monopoly service. If a service provided by each of those monopolies, is done negligently and has some third effect, there is no common law right to pursue those organisations in the courts for damages. That is certainly not the level playing field that we were led to believe was part of this new package. No government business enterprise should be immune from actions for negligence in the delivery of services and especially not monopoly services which, of course, those carriers have.

Another point is that the legislation will allow Telecom and Australia Post to carry on any business or activity that is capable of being conveniently carried on by the use of resources that are not immediately required in carrying out Telecom's principle or subsidiary function. Obviously, that offers opportunities for those organisations in monopoly situations to become involved in business where they can put the competition out of action. Such a provision is not warranted and we have an amendment to that effect. The Bill gives Telecom very wide powers to enter land relating to the inspection, installation and repairing of facilities. It is inappropriate for Telecom to be given the power to be able to enter people's land to inspect it and do what it wants to do when that is not related to the direct purpose of telecommunications. Obviously, that provision ought to be struck out. I hope that the Senate will support our amendment in that respect.

A further piece of legislation gives Australia Post the power to develop and lease land and buildings not immediately required by it. That opens up the possibility of Australia Post becoming a land developer. Perhaps the Government has that kind of privatisation in mind, which may well be the way in which it rewards its trade unions for being compliant in other areas. Who knows? However, the point is that there is a prospect of the development of alternative competitive arrangements, given the monopolies already involved, and that could open up vast opportunities for such organisations in future against the true interests of the Australian private sector.

In conclusion, I will quote from a document produced by the Australian Society of Accountants called Long Road to Reform-Privatisation and Corporatisation in Australia. Essentially, what we are talking about here is corporatisation, if you like, the developing of the concept of accountability. At page 2 of the document in the section entitled `The State of Play' the Society says:
Very few Australians would understand immediately that-
a person is quoted-
is getting at two quite political ideas, these being what distinguish arguments for privatisation and corporatisation from the more traditional critique of public sector performance.
This comes to the main point I want to bring up:
The first is that consumers can provide better information about the services they want through direct private transactions than governments can by attempting to guess their needs for them.
That is the essential argument in favour of deregulation, competition and privatisation. The second point mentioned is:

. . . governments will lose sight of the original point of its interventions, and that the government institutions formed to achieve certain objectives will eventually serve the interests of those who provide services before those who are intended to receive them.

I think those two points summarise what these pieces of legislation are all about. We have here a government on the political hook, having declared after the 1987 election that it was interested in privatisation, corporatisation, deregulation and delivering micro-economic reform, which has now failed to meet that obligation through political pressures of an internal kind. It has turned to find a means by which it can present an image of doing something. It has done this through this set of legislation and earlier announcements. When we examine that legislation, as we have done in the last hour or two in the Senate, we find that it has done nothing to further improve the free competition in the telecommunications industry and to provide a means by which the industry can develop in the future.

As I said earlier, this legislation merely locks up tighter the way in which monopoly services will be delivered by these organisations. Minister Kelly admits that. She says that this legislation entrenches further the monopoly positions of those carriers so that the Opposition, when in government, will not be able to unlock the doors to deregulate those industries. That is the point of this legislation. It is an attempt to fool the people that deregulation is occurring. What is occurring in effect and in essence is that the locks are being closed even tighter. The numbers on the combination will become more difficult to unscramble than they were before if this legislation is enacted. That is the essence of this legislation. That is why we are moving through our amendments to change the legislation so extensively. We seek the support of the Australian Democrats in achieving that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating eight Bills cognately. I intend to address my remarks mainly to the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1989 and to briefly address the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1989. The transition of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (SMEC) from a statutory corporation into a company incorporated under the Companies Act 1981 by virtue of proposed section 21 is a step in the right direction. It is made up of four main factors: firstly, the creation of share capital; secondly, the repeal of sections 41 and 42 of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Act 1970; thirdly, the transition of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation into a company; and, finally, the repeal of section 6 of the SMEC Act that established SMEC as a statutory corporation to take effect immediately it is registered as a company.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is worth recounting a little bit of history about the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. It was established in 1970 but had been going since 1950. Honourable senators will recall that in 1949, within four or five years of the end of the war, a decision was made to proceed with what turned out to be the greatest construction that this country had ever seen. Since that time there have been constructions of equal or greater magnitude, but it was a massive project. As we did not have the necessary expertise in those days, it was necessary to form a coordinating group to oversee the construction of what turned out to be the Snowy Mountains scheme with its dams, tunnels and hydro-electric generation equipment. It was built primarily for irrigation and the secondary effect was that of producing hydro-electric power to cope with the peak requirements in both New South Wales and Victoria.

That is the background of the scheme. It did an incredibly good job. It became a training ground for engineers, for operators, and for people using large equipment such as large bulldozers that we had not seen in this country before and massive earthmoving equipment. From that training ground people moved into engineering consulting businesses. Many senior partners in engineering consultancy groups today have their origins in the Snowy Mountains Authority. It attracted people from all around the world. It was the beginning of our immigration program. Countless numbers of ethnic groups participated in the great Snowy Mountains scheme.

In 1970 the Government of the day decided to form the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. The idea was to consolidate civil, electrical, mechanical, water resource development, power generation, transmission, irrigation, land development and road engineering expertise. All those great areas of expertise were coordinated under the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. Now, nineteen years later-something like 40 years from the day the decision was made to go ahead with the scheme-the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation is being converted into a company with public company status but with all the shares being held by the Government.

My concern lies in not knowing how effective this move will be. This is a great organisation but there are equally important consulting engineers in other parts of Australia-I could name them, but by doing so I would be giving a commercial and I might offend those I left out-who have a worldwide reputation. There is no doubt that if we let the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation off the leash it could form partnerships with other groups without having to get the Minister's permission. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the latest Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation report 1987-88, where reference is made to directions to the Corporation issued by the Minister between October 1987 and December 1987, which was not a long period. One of the directions was not to join in the formation of partnerships and joint venture companies without the prior written approval of the Minister. It is unclear from this legislation and from the second reading speech whether the Minister can continue to give those directions, although I notice from the second reading speech that the Minister says that he will be free to continue to issue directions. We cannot have an organisation competing with larger projects, not just against our own consulting engineers but against consulting engineers from around the world, when it has to meet certain requirements. It does not make any sense.

I note also that it is stated in the second reading speech that the Corporation is not to enter into contracts which conflict with Government policies. How can we expect an organisation to meet this requirement? I say this for the benefit of Senator Coulter, who earlier today expressed concern about its conversion into a public company and its being a possible step down the road to partial or complete privatisation. Senator Coulter could not understand how the free market could, in fact, offer an organisation like this better opportunities. All I can say is that he must have no understanding at all as to how the market operates in this area. It is a competitive area. He argues that this organisation has a social function. Everyone in this field, in one way or another, has some sort of social function.

The difficulty I have, and I know members of the Government certainly have, is to ascertain just what the Government's real position is on this. Is it step one down the track to privatisation? If so, why does the Government not come out and say so? It would not be hard to sell, least of all to the people who work for the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation itself. They would love it. Let me give the House an idea of the conflicting remarks that have been made. In July 1985 the Prime Minister of this country, Mr Hawke, at the Nunawading by-election, had this to say about privatisation:

Privatisation is a one-off fire sale, a sale of the century, of your assets-assets of the people of Australia. They would transfer them into the hands of a privileged few, to the cost of every one of us.
He also said in the Parliament on 21 November 1985:
. . . anyone who thinks about the issue of privatisation knows . . . it would mean higher prices, higher costs, higher taxes and higher fares . . . It is quite clear that in South Australia-
there must have been an election on-
as in Australia as a whole, privatisation would be an expensive and disastrous experiment.
The Treasurer, Mr Keating, is reported in Hansard on 23 May 1985 as follows:

No matter where one looks, whether at TAA or the other authorities, there is no case for the Opposition's argument in economics, except simply to indulge ideologically in a Thatcherite, vandalistic splurge to try and destroy these authorities.

However, the enormity of Australia's structural rigidities in the face of balance of payments crises finally hit home and, with it, the realisation that micro-economic reform could not be postponed any longer. All of a sudden, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer changed their tune and did a 180-degree turn. I understand from Senator Evans that he has always held this view, and I congratulate him on it. I hope he is in the ascendancy right now. According to the Prime Minister, privatisation is now a matter of a reasonable and rational assessment of public sector priorities. He was reported in the Economist of 26 August 1987 as follows:
The question should be not `why should we sell a given enterprise?' but: `why should we continue to tie up our resources in it?'
That is very sensible. He went on:
Privatisation, they argued, would save the Commonwealth hundreds of millions in capital injections which would then be available for social programs and even tax cuts.
Presumably, the social programs would be to try to hose down the antagonism and opposition of the Left of the Australian Labor Party (ALP). At a press conference on 27 April 1989, the Treasurer said:

Some assets may be used more efficiently outside the public sector. Sales of some assets would certainly relieve the Budget of ongoing subventions and, of course, all asset (sales) produce a capital appropriation to the Budget which either retires debt or slows down the build up of debt and hence, relieves the Budget of its very high public debt interest and commitment.

No wonder Australians are confused about the privatisation issue. Should they believe what the Prime Minister and the Treasurer told them about the perils of privatisation in 1985, or should they accept the new version about its benefits which the Prime Minister and the Treasurer now preach in 1988-89?

The Liberal-National Party Opposition, on the other hand, has consistently promoted the idea of privatising government enterprises since 1984. A Federal coalition government would raise between $5 billion and $10 billion in revenue from the sale of Commonwealth assets. The funds from those assets would be used to reduce our burgeoning national debt which, as we all know, is reaching crisis proportions. The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation was one of the instrumentalities that we indicated we intended to privatise on taking over government. The others have been spelt out by my colleague Senator Alston. They include: Australian Airlines-I will come to that again in a minute; Qantas Airways Ltd; the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation; Medibank Private; 49 per cent of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission; and the Commonwealth Bank. Employees will be encouraged to have a stake in their industry through share purchasing schemes.

In recent days this issue has been raised by Mr Willis. Yesterday he put privatisation firmly back on the ALP's agenda by expressing a personal preference for full sales of the two Government owned airlines, Qantas and Australian Airlines. He made these remarks on the Ten Network's Face to Face program. He said that even if the Government sold an entire enterprise, it would retain some control through a kind of golden share which would enable it to limit the degree of foreign ownership or the size of any one holding of the enterprise. Of course, this is part of the Opposition's policy platform on privatisation. It is a system that was used in sensitive, strategic areas in Great Britain when that country went into its privatisation mode. The Prime Minister yesterday-the very day on which Mr Willis made those remarks-supported him by saying, `I thought Mr Willis put the issues very fairly and directly'. However, in today's newspapers one of the leaders of the Left, Senator Childs, said that privatisation was akin to selling the family farm.

There is great dissension within the Government on this perfectly sane way of approaching the problems in our country today. I also note that Mr Peter Milton of the Victorian Labor Left stated that the issue was fairly divisive. He said that it is a great mistake to float this sort of idea in this way. It is patently obvious that an issue such as this is very divisive within the ranks of the Labor Party. As I mentioned earlier, Senator Evans stated quite categorically that he has had a view on this which has never changed. I congratulate him and hope he is successful. There is no doubt that if he is he will have the support of the coalition for what the Government hopefully intends to do. But I am unsure, as is the rest of Australia, of the Government's present position and the Government should clarify it.

The status of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation is now being transformed into that of a public company but nothing else has been said about it-except that in the Minister's second reading speech he says that all the shares will initially be held by the Commonwealth. That is a good sign because it indicates that the Government is thinking that it will move towards initial partial privatisation by management buy-out of certain shares and, eventually, the total sell-out of those shares either by sale to the management, through a buy-out operation, or by way of a merger with some of the leading consulting companies in Australia. If this is the plan, the Government should come clean and remove the confusion within its ranks and within the Australian community. If the Government comes clean, it can have no doubt that it will get the support of the Opposition. In the same way, Senator Chaney promised in another area of micro-economic reform that if the Government moved to free up the waterfront and pursue the recommendations of the Inter-State Commission, it would receive our total support. In this instance, the Government should put its toe in the water.

Compared with Australian Airlines or Qantas, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation is a small fish in terms of privatisation. So I recommend that the Government put its foot into the water. I know it is a small step for privatisation, but it seems to me it is a giant step for a Labor government. The effect of such a step would be to let off the leash those who work within the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation-those top operators, those people whom we all admire-so that they can go out and enhance an organisation that has done an excellent job to date.
I would like to touch very briefly on the amendment to the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! That will be dealt with in another debate. It is not part of this debate. I think you will have a chance to speak on it later.
—Is it not a cognate Bill?
—Not with these Bills.

—Finally, I believe that this legislation is a move in the right direction. I hope sincerely that it is the first step in what will end up as privatisation of an area which can only be of benefit to the people who work in the organisation and to the country as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of Bills we are debating this evening-in particular, the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill 1989 and the Telecommunications Bill 1989 to which I wish to direct attention-demonstrate the way in which the Government has failed the test of an adequate commitment to so-called micro-economic reform. That reform is essential if the living standards of all Australians are to improve through the 1990s and into the next century.

SPEECH.PARA: The supposed purpose of the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill is to improve the efficiency of Telecom through redefining its objectives, functions and powers, and also through financial restructuring.
