The Bill places three obligations on Telecom Australia: firstly, a commercial obligation; secondly, a community service obligation; and thirdly, general governmental obligations. Beyond that, it fails to introduce the sorts of reforms that are necessary if we are to see a competitive situation develop with regard to telecommunications in Australia.

A key aspect of micro-economic reform strategy for the restructuring of the public sector is that government business enterprises should be as efficient as possible. This legislation in some respects will place Telecom on a more commercial footing in line with private sector competitors. It retains its statutory community service obligation as a supplier of a standard telephone service as efficiently and economically as practicable. However, the Bill maintains an excessive degree of monopoly power in the hands of Telecom. In particular, Telecom ought not be able to use funds which it derives from the exercise of its monopoly powers to compete in the private sector. That is a significant shortcoming in this legislation.

Perhaps the more important Bill is the Telecommunications Bill 1989. This is the Bill which purports to provide greater competition in the area of telecommunications, particularly with regard to the provision of value added services and private network services. However, the legislation is totally inadequate in establishing the circumstances for this to occur. Indeed, as other speakers on the coalition side have said earlier this evening, Telecom's monopoly in the field of telecommunications effectively remains. The legislation sets aside specific telecommunication services for Telecom, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission Ltd and Aussat Pty Ltd, defined in the legislation as the carriers. These are the so-called reserved services. The legislation also establishes the Australian Telecommunications Authority, Austel, which will be the statutory body responsible for regulating the telecommunications industry.

Australia's telecommunications industry has been excessively restricted for too long. This legislation is an inadequate response to that excessive restriction and regulation. The proposals which the Government has put forward and which it has hailed as significant micro-economic reforms, are in fact false claims, because in this legislation the Government supports the retention of Telecom's monopoly powers. While there is a lot of talk about deregulation, no significant deregulation is being introduced in practice. The best example of this is Telecom's retention of the exclusive right to provide the first home telephone until 1992. It is not possible, under the legislation, for this monopoly to be broken until there is a further review, which in turn has to go to the Minister for decision.

There are also questions with regard to the present legislation which prevents Telecom's customers from taking legal action against it if they have suffered financial loss caused by its actions. This immunity is retained in the legislation. Most significantly, as I have said, the legislation entrenches the very broad monopolies for Telecom, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and Aussat and very carefully protects those monopolies. The legislation also establishes an extensive regulatory and permit system which will be an additional burden on the private sector in the very limited areas that the Bill does open up to private competition.

Two categories of service are identified in the legislation: those defined as reserved services, that is, the services that are reserved for the carrier monopolies; and those defined as value added services, that is, services which can be provided either by the private sector or by the carriers competing with each other. The legislation also provides that Austel will determine the technical standards for customer equipment and customer cabling. The legislation further creates a cable licensing system for persons to install customer cabling and to connect it to the carrier networks.

The coalition believes that too much is retained in the arena of reserved services in the legislation-that is, that area retained in the monopolistic hands of the Government's own authorities. Those reserved services include: public switched telephone services; public switched data services; public switched text and video services; public switched integrated services digital networks; leased circuit services; and public mobile telephone services. In addition, there is the retention of the monopoly on the provision of the first home telephone. Another monopoly retained for Telecom is the provision of public pay phones. The legislation also prohibits the resale of leased circuit services, and the carriers have exclusive rights to the provision of all services and facilities within the boundaries of their networks.

When we look at the area of reserved services, we see it leaves very little to be provided by the private sector, those so-called value added services which the Government claims it is opening up to competition. That range of value added services is too limited. That is why, as I said at the outset, the Government has failed the test of micro-economic reform with regard to the telecommunications industry. The coalition believes that the monopoly for the public carriers ought to be restricted to the basic public switched telephone network, and the provision of those other services that I outlined a few moments ago as being reserved for the monopolistic main carriers in this legislation ought to be opened up to competition along with the value added services.

Another failure in the legislation is that it does not create Austel as an independent regulator. All Austel has been given the power to do is to administer the regulations that will be set out in the Bill, so it has a very limited degree of discretion to be an effective regulator. The class licence provisions will discourage product innovation and development of the industry for three reasons. The main one is that there is no provision in the Australian Telecommunications Act for persons to apply for the issue of new class licences. All that is provided is the opportunity for an informal approach to Austel with a suggestion that it look at issuing a new class licence; there is no provision in the Act which requires Austel to do anything about that matter. That will make it extremely difficult for innovation to occur in the industry-an industry in which innovation is the hallmark and which is one of the most rapidly growing areas of technology, not only in this country but around the world. The legislation again falls short of the claims that were trumpeted by the then Minister for Transport and Communications, now the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), on 25 May last year, when he made that statement on telecommunications reform to the Parliament. The legislation falls well short of the goals that the Government set at that time.

I want to deal in detail with a few of the quite specific shortcomings of this legislation with regard to its adequacy in establishing real competition in the telecommunications industry. There is no provision in the objectives of the Act for the promotion and maintenance of effective competition between persons engaged in the commercial supply of telecommunications services in Australia. If the Government is fair dinkum about opening up this area to competition, obviously that ought to be one of the objectives of the Act. By regulation under this legislation the Government could allow the monopoly reserved services area to encroach further onto the area of value added services. There is no provision in the legislation to prevent the Government, by regulation, extending in the future the area of reserved services. The legislation also prevents any shared use or resale of simple carriage of communications over private telecommunications networks; that is, there is no opportunity for the private sector to resell leased circuit capacity-again an unnecessary restriction if the Government is fair dinkum about opening up this industry to real competition.

There are also regulations authorised by the legislation to define the boundaries of the public switched telephone network or, indeed, any other network. This is an area which Austel ought to determine itself. The legislation ought to provide that Austel monitors the appropriateness of the boundaries of the public switched telephone network and makes recommendations concerning desirable amendments. That ought not to be undertaken through regulations attached to this legislation.

The legislation defines the exclusive rights of the monopolistic carriers, whereas it ought to allow the carriers to subcontract various areas without Austel needing to become involved. In other words, if those monopoly carriers want to use the private sector and want to involve subcontract activities in some of their own areas of responsibility, they ought to have the right to do that without seeking the approval of Austel. The legislation provides that Austel shall not authorise a person to supply, install or maintain and operate a facility that is connected to and within the boundaries of a network operated by a carrier unless that carrier has agreed. Again that is an entirely unnecessary provision if what we are seeking to do is open up this area to greater competition. Shortcomings of this nature raise serious questions about the extent of the Government's commitment to deregulation and, indeed, greater competition in this very important industry. There are others with which I could deal, but I know that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade is anxious for the debate to be drawn to a conclusion so that he can respond, so I will not take up any more time. However, I direct his attention to those shortcomings in the legislation.

In summary, the legislation really means that the Government is maintaining its commitment to Telecom's monopoly powers. There is a lot of talk about deregulation, but in actual practice this legislation goes nowhere near far enough in ensuring that the telecommunications industry is opened up to the competition which would provide benefit to the majority of the Australian people. The coalition will in the committee stage move a series of quite specific amendments to various clauses of the legislation to open up the industry to that greater competition which is necessary and which will be beneficial to the Australian community. If the Government refuses to accept those amendments, we will have to wait until after the next election to see those better provisions introduced.

Coalition policy will require Telecom to operate on a competitive and commercial basis. We certainly remain committed to the provision of cross-subsidy. In government, we will convert Telecom to a public company. We will retain Telecom's responsibility for the basic telecommunications network, but all those other services that have been reserved as a Telecom monopoly in this legislation will be opened up to competition. Of course, that is the key to seeing an improved provision of telecommunications services to the Australian community.

This is an arena in which there is tremendously rapid technological change. New technologies are being developed with great rapidity. If Australians are to gain the benefit of developing technology, it will be achieved only if a maximum degree of competition is allowed within this sector. That is why this legislation is inadequate. The amendments that will be proposed by the shadow Minister will certainly go a long way towards making the legislation more adequate, but what is really needed is a coalition government to implement the policies we have developed with regard to this very important industry. I would urge the amendments on the Senate but, failing that, I look forward to a coalition government being in office after the next election to open up this area to effective competition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —While I cannot claim any but the most fleeting ideological parentage of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (Conversion into Public Company) Bill and the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill relating to the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC), honourable senators will be aware-indeed, a number of their sallies during the course of this debate have made it all too clear that they are aware-that in one of my previous incarnations I had a hand in the development of the Government's policies on telecommunications regulation and the management of the government business enterprises that were announced on 25 May last year. I am not very sorry about many things in relation to my change of portfolio on this occasion, as indeed on previous occasions, but I am a little sorry that my change in portfolio in the middle of last year meant that I was unable to participate directly in the fun task of translating these government policy decisions into legislative form. Nevertheless, it gives me some pleasure, a little residual frisson, as one might put it, to wind up this debate in the Senate, and I thank all honourable senators for their contributions to the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill and the four associated Bills represent the final legislative step in implementing the Government's policy decisions of last year and a major milestone, on any view, on the Government's structural adjustment agenda. However, for the telecommunications industry it is only a beginning. On 1 July there will be an independent regulatory agency, Austel, which will have a clear role of working with all sectors of the industry in providing detailed and timely advice to government on the adequacy of existing regulatory arrangements. The Opposition has moved amendments in relation to the second reading of the Telecommunications Bill and the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill. I only wish that the paucity of its amendments to the motion for the second reading had been accompanied by a similar degree of self-denial when it came to the committee stage, but we will deal with that when the time comes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't tempt us.

—It is a bit too late now for the second reading, but it can always be matched in the committee stage if the honourable senator feels a degree of discipline coming on. The amendment in relation to the Telecommunications Bill that is before us does express concern at the Government's `failure' to introduce meaningful deregulation and/or competition, and then goes on to acknowledge that there is indeed a need for monopolies. How else can Telecom be expected to continue the cross-subsidy arrangements that are so dear to National Party hearts? The amendment, however, then goes on, having given the game away in that respect, to complain that we have not properly specified Telecom's community service obligations. This is also the gist of the amendment in relation to the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill. It closes with a statement suggesting that there is no need for the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) or Aussat to remain in public ownership as they have no community service obligations.

SPEECH.PARA: The extent of deregulation and competition introduced into the Australian telecommunications industry by this legislation is very significant and honourable senators will be fully aware that the legislation is welcomed and supported by all sectors of the industry for this reason. Naturally, however, there has to be a balance, and the appropriate degree of deregulation must be constrained by the need to ensure the orderly and efficient development of the basic network by enabling the fullest exploitation of the efficiencies arising from economies of size and scope and by avoiding costly and uneconomic duplication of facilities. The fact is that the Government has initiated major regulatory reforms which represent a significant liberalisation of one of the fastest growing sectors of the industry.

The Bill states unequivocally in clause 52 that value added services will be open to full competition, and this is, on any view, a major reform. Secondly, our policy on private networks clearly permits the growth and development of private networks provided that they do not infringe the carriers' essential monopoly services. The Opposition has explicitly stated that it also recognises and endorses the need to safeguard the Government carriers' monopoly over basic telecommunications services.

Both Senator Alston and Senator Powell spoke of the importance of community service obligations, or CSOs. Senator Alston mentioned the study being carried out by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics (BTCE) on the costs of Telecom's CSOs. It is true that that study was not completed within the timeframe envisaged. However, this simply reflects the sheer size and complexity of the task. Far from being a cover-up, this Government has initiated the most fundamental and searching analysis of the CSO issue ever undertaken by any government in the world. The BTCE report is now approaching completion. But most honourable senators would agree that CSOs are not just an economic and cost issue. Austel will have a mandate to monitor not only costs but also the adequacy and appropriateness of Telecom's strategies in meeting its community service obligations. The fact is that this reform package will allow the Government to make better informed decisions about CSOs and we will be able to manage the way in which CSOs are met on a more rational and equitable basis than ever before.

In relation to the specification of community service obligations, the Government has set down its expectations of Telecom in some detail in clause 27 of the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill, which states:
(1) Telecom shall supply a standard telephone service between places within Australia.
(2) The public switched telephone service shall be the standard telephone service.
(3) Telecom shall supply the standard telephone service as efficiently and economically as practicable.
(4) Telecom shall ensure:

(a) that, in view of the social importance of the standard telephone service, the service is reasonably accessible to all people in Australia on an equitable basis, wherever they reside or carry on business; and
(b) that the performance standards for the standard telephone service reasonably meet the social, industrial and commercial needs of the Australian community.

The decision not to define the standard telephone service in precise terms in the legislation was quite deliberate. It is clear that the Government, in defining the CSOs that it expects Telecom to meet in each of its corporate plans, needs to be able to respond to the community's needs and expectations of the standard telephone service in the light of rapid developments in technology. Furthermore, Austel has a mandate to report to government on the appropriateness and adequacy of the strategies and policies that Telecom is following to carry out its community service obligations and its efficiency in carrying them out.

The fact that OTC and Aussat do not have CSOs imposed upon them is not a reason for removing their monopolies. The fact is that the limited monopolies accorded to OTC and Aussat are necessary to secure the available economies of scale and scope. In addition, the continuation of the monopolies of the three carriers avoids uneconomic duplication of telecommunications facilities. Moreover, the legislation gives Austel wide powers to ensure that OTC and Aussat do not abuse their monopoly powers. Austel has a specific mandate in clause 22 of the Bill to monitor the efficiency with which all three carriers supply the reserved services, the adequacy and quality of the reserved services provided by them and the appropriateness of the boundary between the reserved services and competitive services.

Senator Powell indicated a particular interest in the detail of the price cap arrangements and the question of two baskets in particular. Let me for a moment address some of her concerns. The Government has not resiled from its commitment in the May 1988 statement to have separate price control arrangements for residential and business consumers of telecommunications services. It has always been the Government's policy that all consumer groups would share the benefits of the efficiency improvements to be delivered by the new consumer price index minus X (CPI-X) formula. However, the only difference in telecommunications pricing between the business and residential sectors is the rental charge. Consequently, for reasons of administrative practicality, the Government decided to combine the standard services for both sectors into a single basket subject to a common CPI-X control, as announced in the ministerial statement on 1 June 1989.

The 1988 ministerial statement on telecommunications policy that I made foreshadowed that there would be separate formulas for the two sectors because, at that time, it was believed that that was the best way to limit the permissible change in the residential rental charge. However, we now believe that this objective is better implemented by placing within the one price cap formula a specific limit on permissible increases in the residential rental charge. I am sure that were I still around in the portfolio I would believe that too. A determination setting out these price cap arrangements will be issued when the Telecommunications Bill has been passed by the Parliament. This is expected to occur shortly.

Senator Powell also spoke of setting CPI-4-the CPI-X that has been identified-prior to the completion of the corporate planning process. The Government has seen enough of the broad planning indicators to make a decision on CPI-X. Having now taken that decision on the value of X, this is now a given factor for planning purposes.

There is one matter that has been of concern to the philatelic community, which is well represented in this chamber and in the other place, to which I am told I should feel obliged to make some further remarks. Some concerns have been expressed to the Government about the effects of the provision in the Telecommunications and Postal Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill that inserts a new section 85g in the Crimes Act on collections of forged stamps; that is stamps which are collected and sold as forgeries. The proposed section 85g makes it an offence to possess or sell forged stamps knowing them to be forged. This offence is based on the existing offence in section 86 of the Postal Services Act but some minor drafting changes have been made.

The current offence is expressed to apply to postage stamps of the kind issued by the Corporation; that is, Australia Post. The effect is that forgeries of pre-decimal currency stamps or stamps from other countries are not covered. Senator Puplick is positively agog with all of this! The new offence refers only to postage stamps and stamp dealers are concerned that it will now be interpreted to cover stamps issued before Australia Post was created in 1975 and possibly overseas stamps. It was certainly not intended to extend the scope of the offence in this way and the Government believes that the words `postage stamp' should be read in context as limited to stamps issued by Australia Post.

There is a definition of postage stamp in the Australian Postal Corporation Bill, which is incorporated in the Crimes Act by the amendments. This does not actually define the words but extends the meaning to cover marks, labels and designs authorised by Australia Post for the purposes of paying postage. However, in the context in which the words are used in the corporation Bill, the only sensible interpretation-Senator Puplick should be delighted to hear; I am sure he will not contest this-is stamps issued by Australia Post. For example, the words are used in the clause giving the Australia Post Board the power to determine terms and conditions about the issue and sale of postage stamps. I am identifying the legislative intent. If Senator Puplick could grunt acquiescence of that point it would no doubt help future generations of the judiciary to acknowledge that that is indeed the legislative intent.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you will be sensible on this it will be a very interesting precedent in terms of Australia Post and its prosecution policy.
—But Senator Puplick does acknowledge, for the purpose of the record, that this is the manifest legislative intent that we are now collectively about to implement.
—I am perfectly happy to take your word for it, Minister.

—Good. There it is. The Government is obviously concerned that the changes should not be seen as suddenly making it illegal to own or sell collectors items which it is legal to own or sell at the moment. To put the matter beyond doubt, I place it on record that the offence is intended to apply only to forgeries of postal stamps issued by Australia Post since 1975.
—As specific as an extrinsic aid?

—That is about as specific an extrinsic aid as it is possible to specify. I understand that the Opposition intends to move a number of amendments to the Bills-I think that at last count there were 58-but principally to the Telecommunications Bill. We will deal with those in committee briskly and expeditiously because I want to go overseas on Wednesday and I have a deep and abiding commitment to getting my packing done before then. The feedback that the Government has received to date from all sectors of the industry is that there should be no changes to the Bill. One hopes that that view of industry will be clear enough to the Opposition, such that it will confine its last charge on this matter to one that does not occupy us for too long. Industry clearly wants us to get on with the job of establishing Austel to commence a new era in the Australian telecommunications industry-one that holds great promise for the future.

SPEECH.PARA: In summing up the debate on the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (Conversion into Public Company) Bill, the Bill represents a further step in the Government's program of micro-economic reform in the freeing up of government business enterprises from the burden of detailed day to day bureaucratic controls, replacing these with strategic oversight through major planning and accountability mechanisms. It is also a further step in the Government's effort to ensure the full commercial viability of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, recognising its unique position as one of Australia's major assets as a government-owned consulting engineering firm, and its leading involvement as an Australian company in engineering consultancy projects in our region.

The Bill does not provide for the introduction of a staff equity scheme as that is still to be considered by the Government, but it does provide for a share premium account which is necessary should a decision be taken to introduce a scheme at a later stage. It does not represent in any sense partial privatisation of the organisation. Let me simply make the point, which should be obvious from everything I have said so far, that there is no case, as we see it, for full-scale privatisation of the organisation of the kind that is called for in the Opposition's second reading amendment. The introduction of the Bill is just one more example of the Government's continued commitment to achieving the future viability of the Corporation.

The Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill deals primarily with an amendment to the AIDC Act and represents another step in the Government's economic reform of government business enterprises. The Bill, again, will remove unnecessary bureaucratic procedures which have inhibited AIDC's commercial activities but at the same time will put in place appropriate strategic controls which will ensure a sufficient degree of public accountability.

The second reading amendment in relation to the Bill aims at the complete privatisation of the AIDC and an acceptance that there is no essential public interest requiring government involvement in such an organisation. Let me say in reply to that, and in urging the Senate to reject the second reading amendment, that the AIDC was moved to the industry portfolio in late 1983 when the Act was amended to expand the goal of the Corporation. The amendments at that time enable AIDC to provide finance for the restructuring and revitalisation of industry and for high technology and other growth industries in order to improve the competitiveness of the Australian industry. Since that time AIDC has made a significant contribution to the Government's industry objectives.

AIDC's ability to provide both loans and equity capital across the spectrum of new and old industries is a key characteristic that differentiates it from other financial institutions. Because of the contribution AIDC can make to industry restructuring plans, such as in heavy engineering and textiles, clothing and footwear industries and in projects such as the anti-malaria joint venture, the Government believes that it should maintain an on-going interest in AIDC. In saying this, however, I would quickly point out that the decisions made by the AIDC are based on commercial judgments. It has not been and will not be directed in its normal operations as to where it should or should not invest.

On the other hand, the AIDC is manifestly in need of fresh injections of capital. The float of up to 30 per cent will overcome that problem and will provide the AIDC with sufficient capital to pursue its leading programs, particularly those relating to equity. The AIDC has an excellent record and is an attractive investment opportunity for the Australian people. The float will allow the AIDC to continue its operations and will give a wide spectrum of the community the opportunity to participate to advantage in the AIDC. At the same time, those investors will be confident of the AIDC because they know the Government is going to continue as a major shareholder. We cannot get a more gilt-edged investment than that. With those remarks, I commend the Bills to the Senate and hope and pray for their speedy passage.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Alston's in relation to the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill 1989) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Alston's in relation to the Telecommunications Bill 1989) negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, subclause 16 (1), line 13, before ``The functions of Telecom include'', insert ``Subject to subsection (3)''.
(2) Page 4, subclause 16 (2), line 17, before ``Without limiting subsection (1)'', insert ``Subject to subsection (3)''.
(3) Page 4, after subclause 16 (2), add the following new subclause:

``(3) For the purposes of this section, the functions of Telecom, insofar as they include an incidental business or activity, are limited to such business or activity as is related to telecommunications.''.

Subclause 16 (1) of the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill specifies the functions of Telecom Australia. Amendments (1) and (2) are simply mechanisms to enable the third amendment to take effect. Having regard to the fact that clause 16 deals with the functions of Telecom, our amendments will limit those functions to such business or activity as is related to telecommunications. Otherwise, we have an elaborate charade which would enable Telecom to obtain an unlimited commercial charter, which we believe is not appropriate. It should not be getting into areas where it is not experienced. It should not, therefore, be engaged in activities other than those which are primary or secondary functions-certainly not functions which could be described as incidental. Therefore, we propose the amendments to limit its functions in that fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is aware that the Government has made a series of decisions to reform Telecom Australia to make it more efficient so that the services it offers Australian people and businesses can improve. As well as direct benefits to customers from a more efficient Telecom, there will be secondary gains because telephone and related charges are a significant input to the costs of most industries. Telecom has to make maximum use of its assets if it is to maximise its efficiency. The Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill confers on Telecom incidental functions to give it every opportunity to be as efficient as possible. This does not mean that the Government expects Telecom to ignore the major reason for its existence, or allow this to be swamped by other business. The Bill makes it quite clear that the principal function of Telecom is to provide telecommunications services for Australians. What is more, Telecom's community service obligations require it to supply standard telephone services as efficiently and effectively as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the planning and accountability provisions set out in the Bill there is also scope for the Government, as owner of Telecom, to be involved in the strategic planning processes. The Bill provides for prior notice to be given to the Minister of new business ventures. In this way, we have provided Telecom with the function of carrying on business incidental to its main business to enhance its efficiency without losing sight of its major role as a supplier of telecommunications services. In those circumstances we do not believe the amendments are justified.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister explain whether clause 16 (2) (a) is limited in any manner whatsoever? Certainly, by the use of the term `incidental' one can imagine that somehow those additional activities have to be, in some manner, related to its principal or secondary activities. I ask the Minister whether, on the face of it, that expression allows Telecom to engage in any commercial activities whatsoever, if necessary, totally unrelated to the telecommunications business. The provision that, by the use of resources that are not immediately required in carrying out Telecom's principal or subsidiary function it may carry on any business or activity that is capable of being conveniently carried on, surely means it can do whatever it wants to do.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The words are wide, but they are obviously qualified by the requirement that they involve the use of resources that are not immediately required in carrying out Telecom's principal or subsidiary function. In those circumstances, a very stiff and high hurdle to jump, there is a limitation on Telecom Australia embarking on some frolic of its own. Surely Senator Alston is not suggesting that it would be better for resources to stand by idle, unutilised, not generating returns for Telecom and the community, simply in pursuit of some ideological will-o'-the-wisp to which he has a passionate attachment. I would not think for a moment that Senator Alston would have any such approach. I am sure that, properly understood and appropriately interpreted and applied by the courts, as undoubtedly this Bill will be, if Telecom seeks to go outside its obviously intended limited mandate it will not in any way amount to the kind of open-ended extravaganza that he is postulating. I commend the recommendation accordingly.

—This is a very important clause. I want to be quite clear that what the Minister is saying is that if the Corporation is in debt it cannot invoke this clause; but, if it is in front and has surplus reserves, it can get into any type of business that it chooses. Is that right?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The use of the word `resource' does not just mean `financial resource'; it means buildings or equipment-things of that kind.
—As long as it has surplus resources it can get into any nature of business that it chooses?

—I am referring to the kind of activities which are no doubt envisaged. The clause is, of course, to be read in the context of subsection (1). It does not stand separate and independent from it. Without limiting the operation of subsection (1), the functions that are capable of being carried on are those which may involve resources not immediately required. The requirement has to be that the function in question must be `incidental to' within the meaning of subclause (1)-`a business or activity that is incidental to'. Read in that way, because it does not limit the operation of subsection (1), the clause has a confined operation in two ways: the one I described earlier and by reference to the fact that it has to be seen in the way I have just described.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are fascinated with the Opposition's proposition that, while we need deregulation and do not have enough, it apparently wants to limit activities even further. It claims to be opposed to this course in this legislation. The Democrats will be opposing this group of amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3A.) Page 6, paragraph 27 (4) (a), lines 33 to 37, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:

``(4) (a) in view of the social importance of the standard telephone service, that, insofar as it is in its opinion reasonably practicable to do so, its telecommunications services are made available throughout Australia for all persons who reason- ably require those services; and''.
Clause 27 as now worded stresses:
. . . that, in view of the social importance of the standard telephone service, the service is reasonably accessible to all people in Australia.

That is a variant of Telecom's universal service obligation. The Opposition sees that as moving away from the original charter provision in the 1975 Act in that it makes life a lot easier for Telecom because it no longer has to make those services available to everyone; it merely has to make them accessible to anyone. In rural and remote areas that means that if one lives in an Aboriginal community it could be said that one could travel to the nearest town and therefore the services are accessible. We say that, if one is to be serious about a universal service obligation, one must accept the responsibility of making those services available to all. That means providing them at the point where they are required. We therefore propose this amendment as a result of representations made by the Northern Territory Government, and in particular, my colleague Senator Grant Tambling, in order to reinstate the provision in its previous form, to provide that Telecom will be required:
. . . insofar as it is reasonably practicable to do so, its telecommunications services are made available throughout Australia for all persons who reasonably require those services . . .

If the Government is serious about the holy grail and all that has been said in support of the monopoly as being based on Telecom's community service obligations, surely the obligation to provide a universal service must entail providing it directly to those people who want it and not indirectly, as the clause presently provides.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of all the amendments proposed by the opposition, the amendment just moved by Senator Alston comes closest to gaining the support of the Australian Democrats, although the Minister has yet to respond. The concern has also been expressed to the Australian Democrats by the Northern Territory Government. Part of that concern related also to the difficulty experienced by some people in remote areas in achieving delivery of adequate telecommunications services. Therefore, the broader issue is also raised by this amendment. We are concerned about the change of wording and we would need to be convinced by the Minister's response that the situation has not deteriorated as a result of the change of wording in this legislation from that in the Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the Opposition amendment. The Bill imposes on Telecom an obligation to make its services, as the clause says, `reasonably accessible to all people in Australia . . . wherever they reside or carry on business'. The Opposition proposes to ignore this emphasis on geographical distribution and suggests that it is for Telecom to decide when it is reasonably practicable to make services available.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's intention in the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill and in the Telecommunications Bill is to place much greater emphasis and importance on Telecom's community service obligations (CSOs) and how they are carried out. The new planning and accountability mechanisms in the Corporation Bill require the Board to produce a corporate plan, which separately identifies the strategies and policies it will follow to carry out its community service obligations, including that of reasonable accessibility. The corporate plan must also include a financial target which includes an estimate of the costs of carrying out the CSOs. The Minister can then direct the Board to vary the statement of strategies and policies for CSOs and the financial target. Telecom's annual report must include details about the performance and an assessment of the cost of CSOs.

One of the functions of Austel, the new regulatory body, is to monitor and report to the Government about whether the strategies and policies that Telecom is following to carry out its CSOs are appropriate and adequate and whether Telecom is carrying them out efficiently. Telecom has the function of receiving and investigating consumer complaints which can include complaints about the provision of services. Austel can also direct Telecom to provide a particular service if Austel forms a view that it has failed to meet its CSOs.

All these provisions impose on Telecom a positive obligation compared with the existing provisions which do not do any more than exhort Telecom to perform a duty. They also provide for both the Minister and the representative of the Government and Austel to have a significant impact on the way that CSOs are carried out. So far from lessening Telecom's responsibilities, the legislation now before us will provide much greater scope for the Government to ensure that Telecom delivers its CSOs. The advent of Austel will provide that element of independent review of Telecom's performance which has been lacking.

The specific language which gives some concern to Senator Powell, the words `reasonably accessible', has not been more precisely defined in the legislation for essentially the same reasons that I described in the second reading reply in relation to the question of the definition of a standard telephone service. The Government, in defining the CSOs that it expects Telecom to meet in each of its corporate plans, needs to be able to respond to community needs and expectations in the light of new developments in technology, population spread changes and so on.

Austel has the mandate, as we have said, to report to Government on the appropriateness and adequacy of the particular strategies and policies that Telecom is following to carry out its community service obligations, including the obligation of reasonable accessibility, and its efficiency in carrying them out. As the Government determines the meaning of the phrase `in the corporate planning process', as it gives content to that notion, anyone who is not satisfied will have an avenue of appeal, an avenue of consultation with Austel. I think properly understood in that way, namely that the legislation is not intended to be a precise nuts and bolts code but is intended rather to state the obligation in a way that will enable flexibility and responsiveness to changing circumstances over time, the language makes perfect sense. Standing behind it is the fail-safe mechanism of Austel itself. Viewed that way, the Government believes that the present provisions in the legislation are perfectly adequate.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I understand the Minister correctly, he is saying that the Government is opposed to these amendments because Austel will be there at the end of the day to ensure that Telecom measures up to the mark. But I have not heard him indicate why it is has been thought necessary to change `available' to `readily accessible'. No doubt if one accepts the bona fides of the Government and the vigilance of Austel, Telecom will be held up to the mark. But why should a provision, which on its face is relaxation of Telecom's community service obligations, be included if the Minister is really saying that Telecom will be obliged to maintain the same level of universal service that has operated in the past?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not much more I can usefully add. If Senator Alston is determined to read in--
—Do you say that there is no difference between `available' and `accessible'?

—What matters is access so far as telephone users are concerned. We can quibble about the language, but it is not a very productive quibble. In the circumstances any language, whether it is the language of availability or the language of accessibility, has to be given content by practical corporate plans and by review processes. We believe that the concept of accessibility is one that is well understood in the community at large, that the language is perfectly adequate to describe what it is that we are trying to achieve in this way, and we see no need to delay the passage of this legislation by metaphysical quibbles of the kind that Senator Alston seems determined to get into.

—I want to be quite clear on this. I think we all acknowledge that this is a social charter, that it goes to the heart of Telecom's community service obligations. It is therefore the symbol of the Bill, it is the justification for the monopoly. Yet the Minister is not able to indicate why it has been thought necessary to change those hallowed words, which presumably have underpinned Telecom's CSOs since 1975. If it is not for some malevolent reason, can we be told why it is necessary? If there is not any good reason, why can we not go back to what we had before?

—I support the remarks made by Senator Alston: if there is no reason to change the words, why not go back to the words that are clearly understood and which clearly have some meaning? I think we are entitled to draw the conclusion that the Government is attempting to make some change in the definition if it is in fact changing these words. So far I have heard nothing from the Minister but words which would convince me that the way we are expressing it, which is the way it has been expressed previously, is the way it should be. If he is serious in what he is saying now to this chamber, he should return to that. The words that the Minister has used this evening by way of explanation are words one would use if one were supporting exactly what it is that Senator Alston is putting forward.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The key words in the Opposition amendment, which as it says reflect the original language, are the words, `in so far as in its opinion'; that is, if in Telecom's opinion it is reasonably practicable to do so, the services should be made available. Our language in the amendment is much better than that so far as ordinary consumers are concerned, because there is no language about opinion here. It is an objective requirement of reasonable accessibility. It is not a matter of anybody's opinion, not of Telecom's opinion, but of whether or not the service is reasonably accessible to all people in Australia on an equitable basis, wherever they reside or carry on business. There is no opinion there; it is a matter of objective reality. That is the objective reality that has to be built into the corporate plan. That is what is subject to the overriding application of Austel's regulatory power. If we leave it with the language in the Opposition's amendment, which is, as Senator Alston says, the more familiar language, we are back to a situation where the statutory requirement is no more than to act in accordance with Telecom's opinion, however misconceived, misguided and insensitive to realities that may be. So there is in fact a quite significant difference. I was describing previously the general approach and thrust of the legislation-the way it might be expected to operate in practice. But as one looks more carefully at the detailed language of these provisions, it should become apparent that, far from representing any backsliding, the Government's language in the Bill represents a very substantial improvement from the consumer perspective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I test the genuineness of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) on this matter by offering to delete the words `in its opinion' so that we then revert to that time-honoured formula which would read:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in view of the social importance of the standard telephone service, that, insofar as it is reasonably practicable to do so, its telecommunications services are made available . . .

Then we would not have to worry about any acute distinction between `available' and `accessible' or any subjective assessment being made by Telecom; we would simply revert to language that is well understood and which can be applied in an objective manner.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a demonstration of how ill thought out the Opposition's approach to this legislation is. Having hung its heart and its hat on the pre-existing linguistic formula, which has served the nation well, it only takes two sentences from me for both the heart and the hat to be put back in the cupboard and a new offer made. The reality is that there may not be an awful lot of difference between the concept of `reasonably practicable to make available' on the one hand and `reasonably accessible' on the other. But the remaining language of the clause is, in our suggestion, much more attractive language. Senator Alston will appreciate that I am reading this language for the first time this evening so it has taken me a little while to get up to speed and appreciate the significance of this.
—I am very unimpressed. I do not appreciate it at all.

—What I am saying is that I am only just focusing on some of the detail of this language and the reasoning behind it. But it is perfectly obvious when one does focus on it that the language here is preferable because it talks about an equitable basis wherever people reside or wherever they carry on business. The language of equity, the language of wherever people reside, the language of whenever they carry on business is much more precise than the language that was in the previous clause. Senator Alston is really trying to make a mountain out of a molehill. The big difference was the question of whether the opinion was subjective or objective. If we strip that out we are confronted with an argument about the basic direction of the language. I concede that the basic direction of the language is very similar when we take out the `in its opinion', but the language of accessibility is really the essential thing from a consumer point of view. The language of equity, which is in here, makes it more precise, sharper, clearer and more attractive-and I am sure that that is the way this will be perceived by Australian telecommunications consumers. We will rest, accordingly, with the language we have got.
—Can the Minister indicate whether there has been any consumer discontent with the way in which that obligation had previously been expressed?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been very considerable consumer discontent with the way in which Telecom Australia was a law unto itself without any overriding capacity to have its actions scrutinised and without any criteria being articulated in legislation in a form which was meaningfully challengeable. We are talking about a very different institutional environment here. It changes the whole ball game. The institutional structure and dynamics of this are as I described them. Under those circumstances, Senator Alston's appeal to true conservative values falls on deaf ears.

—From what the Minister is saying, I take it that he is not aware of any complaints that have been made to the Government about any deficiency in Telecom's social charter as spelt out in the current Telecommunications Act. Therefore, I take it that he is not able to give us any reason why one should change from `availability' to `accessibility'. If that is the case, why should we not fear the worst? Why should the Northern Territory Government and others proceed on the basis that what Telecom has in mind is distancing itself from the provision of certain services? Given the sorts of problems that already exist in the Northern Territory where Telecom is providing digital remote concentrator services at its great leisure-it will be about another three years before it finally services those 70 remaining Aboriginal communities-when they could be provided within three months by satellite, why is one not entitled to presume that Telecom is simply reducing its social obligations and is not prepared to adhere to the previous language because it regards it as to onerous?

—I always get worried when people such as the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) start talking about equity because one is never quite sure what they mean by it. For example, is the Minister evaluating the interests of the total number of subscribers in Sydney or Melbourne against those of two or three subscribers somewhere west of the Black Stump? I rather fear that, in general, in this instance he comes down on the side of the bulk of subscribers in one place and feels that there is no reason for the small number in another place to have any consideration at all. For that reason, I come back to the wording that we have proposed as being more likely to be of assistance to people who need some support from Telecom Australia than his qualified use of the word `equity', which is not clearly defined in this instance.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The word `equity' does not stand by itself. It is there in the context of accessibility. That is the key phrase, and it is the one that makes clear-and it is very much the international language of telecommunications which has been picked up and written into the legislation by the draftsmen-that the equity is equity of access, not some broader, larger and looser concept; it does depend on physical access to services. Under those circumstances, we believe that the very rich concepts that are contained in this clause are perfectly capable of being thoroughly sensibly applied in practice and will be so.
—Senator Alston, you did offer to take three words out. Do you wish to take the words `in its opinion' out?
—Yes, I do.
—You will need leave of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 7, clause 30, lines 32 to 36, leave out the clause.

This amendment deals squarely with the question of Telecom Australia's immunity from suit. I must say that, in the deregulated and competitive environment in which we live, it strikes me as extraordinary that one can be seriously asked to support a clause which provides:

An action or proceeding does not lie against Telecom or any other person in relation to any loss or damage suffered, or that may be suffered, by a person because of any act or omission (whether negligent or otherwise) by or on behalf of Telecom in relation to the supply of a reserved service.

Telecom is about to declare a profit of around $1 billion and it should have had a profit of $1.3 billion last year. It has money coming out of its ears, yet the Government tells us that somehow it should have immunity from suit-in other words, a licence to be negligent and to act in any manner it likes in the performance of a reserved service which consumers have no choice but to use. It seems extraordinary that in this day and age one can talk about immunity from suit. All the pressures are the other way. There are class actions and strict liability suggestions with the Law Reform Commission. We are being told that product liability suits should be extended. Yet here we have the great monopolists asking for immunity from suit. It strikes me as anachronistic in the extreme and quite insulting to the intelligence of the electorate that in this day and age we can be the victims of negligence on the part of Telecom when we have no choice but to use its services and no recourse in law.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I should point out that this provision which the Opposition seeks to delete is far more limited than that currently provided in section 101 of the Telecommunications Act, which applies to telecommunications messages and services. The reason for the continued immunity for reserved services for Telecom Australia is the disproportionate damages that could flow from a simple technical failure for a short period. Telecom is under an obligation to supply services throughout Australia and these standard telephone services are provided at uniform prices. In these circumstances it is not reasonable that Telecom should be liable for the consequences if a call or a fax does not get through. I should stress, however, that where Telecom is supplying services in competition with other providers there is no such immunity. So that is the explanation. I believe that it ought to be acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —One can envisage situations in which events could happen beyond the control of Telecom Australia. In those situations there is no suggestion that it would be liable, because there is no doctrine of strict liability applying to the actions of government instrumentalities. Indeed, the whole notion of Crown privilege and the shield of the Crown is such that government instrumentalities have generally been very much protected. Surely the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade cannot be saying that, even where negligence is the cause of loss, the consumer is simply left to his, her or its own devices? It just seems extraordinarily unfair, if we are in the business of talking about equity, that someone can be the victim of blatant negligence and yet have no recourse. We are not talking about limits on the amounts of damages recovered.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister will know from his visit to the United Kingdom early last year and from discussions with Professor Carsberg, as he then was, that the Office of Telecommunications, or, Oftel, has recently introduced a whole series of legal obligations which are imposed on British Telecom and which do provide for measures of damages for persons who do not receive services within a specified period. It seems to me that that is a normal commercial practice. If one is in the business of charging for a service, then surely one is accountable if one does not deliver the service? For the Government to say that somehow it has a monopoly over the service, that it can effectively charge what it likes until Austel comes along and disallows it, and then ultimately rub salt in the wound by saying, `Well, we did not even bother to do our best, we were negligent, but you are not going to get any damages', seems to me to be an outrageous proposition. If the Minister is prepared to defend that, he really is not showing much sensitivity to those consumers that he used to be so concerned about once upon a time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is so much synthetic indignation I can live with at 10 o'clock at night-but it is synthetic indignation and has no justification in fact. Imagine a simple technical fault which is, let us say, the product of some linesman's negligence and which results in a phone call or a fax not getting through, some massive multi-billion dollar John Elliott-style deal not getting through as a result. That is the kind of circumstance, to take the hypothesis--
—Why should they miss out?

—Because the consequences of the burden will then be borne by the whole of the taxpaying and telephone service consuming community, which is a very socialist principle that I am glad to hear Senator Alston is adopting. It is the telecommunications equivalent of the whole kingdom being lost for want of a horseshoe nail. We are all familiar with that childhood parable. It was pretty persuasive in my primary school and I am sure that, if the honourable senator really concentrates very hard, he will appreciate the force of the very simple point that is there being made. A traditional immunity has been involved here in relation to the services of this kind. We believe that that immunity should be continued in the interests of the larger community, whatever Senator Alston's mates happened to think about the consequences of it.

—Just for the record, the Minister is saying, `We cannot give you any indication of how such an event is likely to happen but, in the best notions of conservative legal practice, we say ``floodgates''. If there is any possibility of anything going wrong, we err on the side of protecting an organisation that has net operating profits in the region of $1 billion and we say that it should not be required to bear any burden of loss even if the sufferer is a company that might go out of business as a result. Even if it is a small consumer whose damages might be modest, we say that, just because you might theoretically be able to imagine some large corporation sustaining substantial damages, we will protect the monopoly at all costs'. If that is the Minister's position, I am interested to hear it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just inform the Committee that, while we can understand Senator Alston going hard on this amendment because he imagines he has found the Achilles heel that would be necessary to finally bring down what is left of the Telecom Australia monopoly, we do not support the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Page 25, after subclause 87 (3), add the following new subclause:
``(4) for the purposes of this section, the purposes of Telecom are purposes related to, or connected with, the basic telephone service.''.
(6) Page 25, subclause 88 (1), line 14, leave out ``telecommunications service'', insert ``basic telephone service''.
(7) Page 25, subclause 88 (2), line 19, leave out ``facility'', insert ``basic telephone service''.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can move the remaining ones as well.

—It is not that easy; the Minister will still get away by Wednesday. These amendments are necessary because, while one can understand that Telecom should have certain powers to enable it to trespass on land and certain powers to intrude on various facilities, to suggest that somehow these powers should not be connected with the basic telephone service but should be simply for the purpose of determining whether any land is suitable for its purposes seems to us to provide carte blanche to Telecom to enable it to trample where it has no need or justification to intrude. In all conscience, if it is to be given these extraordinary powers, which Senator Evans when he was a high flying office bearer of the Victorian Council for Civil Liberties would have found to be utterly outrageous, then--
—A long time ago.
—I see. We have recanted, have we? You old authoritarian, you.
—I asked you to join me as patron of a new civil liberties organisation but you refused.

—I have not actually refused. I am in the process of writing. It just seems to us that if there is a justification then it should be kept very narrow. It may well be justified in relation to telecommunications services and basic telephone services but to suggest that somehow it can allow Telecom to roam at large is quite unacceptable. I have therefore moved those amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (10.07)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this particular series of amendments shows that the Opposition simply does not understand the way in which telecommunications services are provided in this country. Standard telephone services run over the same network as that used to deliver Telecom's competitive services and the telecommunications services provided by other parties are carried over the same network. The distinction that is sought by the Opposition is just not feasible or realistic.

SPEECH.PARA: The more important point is that made by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The Committee noted that clauses 87, 88 and 90 appear to permit infringement of private rights because Telecom is allowed to enter land for the purposes of inspection, installation and repairs. However, the Committee commented that clause 92 allows for compensation for damage done by Telecom and that it was prepared to accept the provisions on that basis. Clearly, with the prospect of compensation payments if it causes damage, Telecom will not use its powers carelessly or without regard to the interests of landowners. Telecom must also give notice to the owner or occupier before it exercises its powers to enter on land or construct or attach facilities although maintenance and repairs can be carried out at any time. Honourable senators, and indeed members of the community, should not be concerned that they will come home and find that their houses are swamped by huge satellite dishes or other exercises of overweaning Telecom power in that respect. The concern that is being articulated by Senator Alston is a nonsense. Accordingly, I ask the Senate to reject the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Committee that the view of the Australian Democrats on this group of amendments is that they are in fact consistent with the major thrust of all of the Opposition's activities on this package of Bills; that is, to limit, as far as possible, those activities which are available to Telecom. We believe this, as we believe of many of the others, is an unreasonable limitation. We therefore do not support the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 5, subclause 16 (1), line 29, before ``The functions of Australia Post include'', insert ``Subject to subsection (3),''.
(2) Page 5, subclause 16 (2), line 33, before ``Without limiting subsection (1)'', insert ``Subject to subsection (3),''.
(3) Page 6, after subclause 16 (2), add the following new subclause:

``(3) For the purposes of this section, the functions of Australia Post, insofar as they include an incidental business or activity, are limited to such business or activity as is related to postal services.''.

Amendments Nos 1 and 2 are simply machinery provisions that put amendment No. 3 in place. Amendment No. 3 is designed to limit the functions of Australia Post to postal services and related activities. Clauses 15 and 16-and this is a re-run of the argument that we had a short time ago in relation to the Australian Telecommunications Corporations Bill--

TALK.START.PARA: —Take it as read.

—No, I think it is too good to waste, so I will have a quick run through it. Clauses 15 and 16 set up an elaborate structure of principal and subsidiary functions but, at the end of the day, a back-door method-a so-called incidental service-effectively enables Australia Post to engage in any activities inside or outside Australia as long as it has a few spare dollars up its sleeve. We regard that as an elaborate subterfuge. It pretends solemnly that it can carry on postal services which are related or incidental but ultimately seeks to substantially broaden its commercial activities into fields where it may have no previous experience, and to do that with funds gained from monopoly activities. If there is such a thing as a community service obligation in the postal area, those funds should be carefully husbanded and applied accordingly to ensure that those CSOs are properly delivered and not risked on venture capital exercises.

SPEECH.PARA: We take the view that clause 16 (2) is a carte blanche, essentially dishonest provision. Apart from suggesting that Australia Post should give priority to its core businesses, this provision is an open ticket to enable it to get into anything that moves. The alleged justification for the monopoly, if it does exist, surely has to be on the basis that those funds are set aside to enable the provision of cross-subsidies to those services that are effectively priced below cost. The last thing that we would want to see would be further Victorian Economic Development Corporation or rural finance licences get into commercial areas where there are essentially very large risks to be taken. The Minister's second reading speech gave no hint of the secret agenda which is effectively contained in clause 16. Therefore, we propose an amendment which would limit Australia Post's activities to its principal and subsidiary functions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia Post has no more conspiratorial an objective than to realise efficiency gains, and to do that it has to make maximum use of its assets. The Bill provides for Australia Post to perform incidental functions to give it every opportunity possible to do just that. It does not mean that the Government expects, or Australia Post will be able, to get out of postal business in favour of something more lucrative just for the sheer heck of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple answer to Senator Alston's amendment is that it is redundant. As I said in the context of the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill, subclause 16 (2) contains the prefatory language without limiting subclause (1). Subclause (1) is the language which makes it absolutely clear that any such business activity here referred to has to be business or activity that is incidental to the supplying of postal services or the carrying on of an activity or business which is itself related to postal services. All the clauses are intertwined, interconnected, in this way, as Senator Alston should appreciate from his earlier barristerial incarnations. There is simply no need for the rhetorical overkill that is involved in his supplementary amendment before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the reasons expressed when we debated the Opposition's similar amendment on the previous Bill, the Australian Democrats will not be supporting these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 6, paragraph 18 (d), lines 15 and 16, leave out `and telecommunications value added services'.

This amendment seeks to limit the Australian Postal Commission to its own field of endeavour. In other words, it should stick to its knitting. Why should Australia Post be in the business of providing telecommunications value added services? We do not mind it supplying electronic mail services because, by definition, they are postal activities although they are provided in electronic form. But to suggest that somehow it now has a specific charter to engage in the supply of telecommunications value added services seems to us to go well beyond its traditional fields of endeavour, to put it into uncharted waters. It has no track record that would suggest that it has any degree of commercial competence that would enable it to provide those services. It is a highly competitive area. There is no shortage of providers in the private sector, and we regard it as quite unnecessary for Australia Post's charter to be expanded in that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pretty startling to see the extent to which the Opposition runs squawking to water when it is given a chance to give a real competitive fillip to a statutory authority to enable it to get into a commercial activity, to spread its wings, to do things which are relevant to its basic charter which will, in fact, involve the modernisation of the organisation, increase its efficiency, its capacity to deliver services and create additional layers of competitiveness in the community as a whole. It dives in wanting to bury its head beneath the surface and says, `This is an inappropriate thing for this sort of body to do'. It cannot have it both ways. This is the business of making these organisations more commercial, of giving them broader and more wide-ranging opportunities-not open-ended, though, because there are limitations in the way in which the legislation is cast-to do effective and useful community business. The kinds of things that are envisaged by this clause, which the Opposition would limit, include the opportunity to use facilities necessary to provide electronic mail and other value added business incidental to its functions. The same applies to a later provision, clause 18 (h), which I think the Opposition is also keen to remove.
—It is 18 (e) and (h).

—Essentially, it is the same concept. The Opposition wants to leave out clause 18 (e). Exactly the same sort of point can be made. An example of this, which will do for what I want to say in relation to the next amendment, is that Australia Post has developed a computer-based asset valuation program in the course of preparing for the new financial and accountability provisions in this Bill. The program could be used by a variety of Australian businesses. Australia Post could develop a service to use the program to assist other businesses in their revaluation exercises, but the Opposition's amendment would limit the availability of that program to governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the powers conferred throughout clause 18 are only available to Australia Post in connection with the performance of its functions. Again, this preserves the balance between productive use of resources by Australia Post and ensures that the major effort is concentrated-as we hope it will be-on its principal function.

TALK.START.PARA: —There seems to be a degree of almost wilful misunderstanding of our position. Certainly, the Australian Democrats have consistently indicated that they refuse to comprehend the position that we have adopted in these areas. I would like to make it clear: we do not have any objection to anyone engaging in any competitive activity as long as they are operating on a level playing field. To use Senator Evans's classic words, what we manifestly do not have here is a level playing field. The Government is providing a monopoly which guarantees an organisation a level of revenue which simply is not available to others and which it can get without any risk. If that is the case, there has to be a quid pro quo. If this organisation is being provided with that monopoly protection in order to deliver the cost of its community service obligations (CSOs) then it does not need to risk any profits that it might make on commercial activities. After all, if it is there to provide that specialised service, let it provide it. If it wants to get into business generally, that is fine, but the Government should not start talking about CSOs and using them as an excuse for the monopoly. Let us cost the CSOs. Let us do a bit better than we have done with the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economic Study to date and let us quantify that cost so that we understand what is involved. We will then have some transparency and appropriate mechanisms for funding it. If we do that, the Opposition would have no objection at all to Australia Post being as any other provider in the business. That can apply to Telecom Australia and all the other government business enterprises that still remain in the public sector.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that Senator Alston might seek leave to consider amendments 4 (a) and 5 simultaneously with this amendment because exactly the same points are being made by both of us in relation to this and the next two amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4a) Page 6, paragraph 18 (e), lines 17 and 18, leave out the paragraph.
(5) Page 6, after paragraph 18 (h), lines 24 and 25, leave out ``foreign countries and other persons'', insert ``and foreign countries''.

In relation to amendment 5, which relates to clause 18 (h), the expression `other persons' is particularly vague. Once again, it almost makes a nonsense of the preceding qualifications because it states:
to supply any services other than postal services to or on behalf of the Commonwealth, the States and Territories, foreign countries and other persons; and . . .

It is almost a throwaway line, but one that simply opens up the field beyond recognition. In the end it means that Australia Post has a charter to supply any business to any person at any time in any place. We regard that as quite extraordinarily wide. Either the Government is being snowed, or it is deliberately setting out to transform Australia Post into a major business trading enterprise under a deceptively narrow name.
